vignette:
1. A27-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She recently immigrated to the USA from Haiti. She feels well and is asymptomatic. She has a 6-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Treatment
with metformin was begun 3 weeks ago. She received all recommended vaccinations during childhood, including BCG vaccine 20 years ago. Her pulse is 74/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is
104/72 mm Hg. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 168 mg/dL. APPD skin test produces 12 mm of induration at 48 hours. An x-ray of the chest shows
no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat PPD skin test in 6 months
Repeat x-ray of the chest in 3 months
Begin isoniazid therapy only if the patient becomes symptomatic
Begin isoniazid, rifampin, and pyrazinamide therapy

correct_explanation:
This patient should begin isoniazid therapy for treatment of potential latent tuberculosis (TB) infection. Controlling the spread of TB relies on the diagnosis and management of patients with active TB infection and potential latent
infection, which has a risk for reactivating into symptomatic, transmissible disease. There is no definitive test for latent TB infection, and diagnosis is based on clinical risk factors and a demonstrable immune response to TB
antigens. The immune response may be disclosed using the PPD skin test or an interferon-gamma release assay. In this patient, receipt of the BCG vaccine in childhood can make interpretation of the PPD skin test challenging, as
the immune response may be caused by the presence of latent TB or because of prior BCG vaccination. Given this, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends interpreting PPD skin tests the same for
BCG-vaccinated and non-BCG-vaccinated individuals. For patients with greater than 10 mm induration on PPD skin test or a positive serum interferon-gamma release assay and a negative chest x-ray, treatment for latent TB
infection should be initiated if they fall into one of the following high-risk groups: recent immigration from a high-prevalence country, intravenous substance use, resident or employee of a setting in which people are in close contact
(eg, correctional facility, nursing care facility, homeless shelter, hospital), presence of significant medical comorbidities, or pediatric patients exposed to high-risk adults. CDC guidelines now favor a shorter (3 to 4 months) rifamycin-
based and isoniazid combination regimen over isoniazid monotherapy, though of the options presented, only isoniazid monotherapy presents a correct choice. Rifamycin-based regimens are preferred given their efficacy, favorable
treatment completion rates, and relatively low hepatotoxicity rates.
educational_objective:
Latent tuberculosis infection is a clinical diagnosis based on a positive immune response to tuberculosis antigens and patient risk factors. Treatment with isoniazid or rifamycin should be initiated for patients
with a positive PPD skin test or serum interferon-gamma release assay, negative chest x-ray, and positive risk factors.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
Y 2A

vignette:
3. A37-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of urinary frequency and moderate pain and burning with urination. She has not had fever, abdominal or flank pain,
or abnormal vaginal discharge. During the past year, she has had five urinary tract infections that began within 3 days of having sexual intercourse; each episode resolved after 1 day of treatment with ciprofloxacin or
trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including pelvic
examination, shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows numerous WBCs and bacteria. The patient is prescribed a 7-day course of nitrofurantoin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for
the remainder of this patient's pregnancy?
correct_explanation:
Urinary tract infections (UTIs) classically present in women with dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic discomfort. They are often caused by Escherichia coli and gram-negative enteric flora. If untreated, bacteria can
travel up the ureter to infect the kidney, resulting in pyelonephritis. Urinalysis typically shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites along with WBCs on microscopy, such as in this patient. Treatment includes antibiotics covering common
pathogens. UTIs are more common in women due to the shorter urethra and favorable regional environment for bacterial growth. In addition, sexual intercourse can introduce bacteria into the urethra, leading to recurrent UTIs.
Because this patient’s UTIs are reliably triggered by sexual intercourse, prescribing an antibiotic to take following sexual intercourse is appropriate. Nitrofurantoin is a common antibiotic that reliably treats cystitis and is safe to be
used during pregnancy.
educational_objective:
Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are more common in women due to the shorter urethra and favorable regional environment for bacterial growth. In addition, sexual intercourse can introduce bacteria into the
urethra, leading to recurrent UTIs. Patients with frequent, recurrent, persistent UTIs triggered by sexual intercourse may be candidates for postcoital antibiotic prophylaxis. For pregnant patients, nitrofurantoin is a common antibiotic
that reliably treats cystitis and is safe to be used during pregnancy.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
4. An otherwise healthy 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 4 hours after the sudden onset of severe pain in his right testis. There is no history of trauma. Vital signs are within normal limits. On
examination, the right testis is palpated in the upper hemiscrotum; it is exquisitely tender and twice the size of the left testis, which is normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete
blood count are within the reference ranges, and urinalysis shows no abnormalities. In addition to administration of morphine, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Technetium 99m scan of the right testis

correct_explanation:
Testicular torsion is caused by rotation of the testes around the spermatic cord. Compression of the blood vessel supply leads to edema, ischemia, and subsequent necrosis. It classically presents with acute testicular pain,
tenderness to palpation, scrotal swelling, and a diminished or absent cremasteric reflex. The patient may also develop nausea, emesis, and/or lower abdominal pain prior to the onset of scrotal pain. Physical examination may show
a “high-riding” testis that is oriented transversely with surrounding erythema. Testicular torsion is typically a clinical diagnosis, although ultrasonography can be used for further evaluation if the diagnosis is unclear. Ultrasonography
will show diminished or absent blood flow to the testes. Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency and requires surgical evaluation when the diagnosis is suspected. Surgery will allow for detorsion of the testes and orchidopexy (ie,
testicular fixation) of both testes to prevent recurrent torsion. Thus, the most appropriate next step in management is emergency orchidopexy.
educational_objective:
Testicular torsion is caused by the rotation of the testes around the spermatic cord with consequent ischemia and necrosis. It classically presents acutely with severe testicular pain, tenderness to palpation,
scrotal swelling, and a negative cremasteric reflex. It is a clinical diagnosis, although ultrasonography can be used to confirm the diagnosis if there is uncertainty. Management includes emergent surgical consultation for detorsion
and orchiopexy.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
5. A 56-year-old woman with recurrent ovarian cancer is admitted to the hospital for management of inoperable small-bowel obstruction. Despite undergoing four courses of chemotherapy during the past 5 years, the cancer
continues to progress. She currently takes no medications. A nasogastric tube is placed. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Abdominal
examination shows distention and decreased bowel sounds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Placement of a percutaneous gastrostomy tube

correct_explanation:
As patients near the end of their life, medical complications commonly accumulate that decrease patients’ quality of life (eg, small-bowel obstruction requiring nasogastric tube, an invasive intervention). In these situations, it
becomes pertinent to weigh the benefits and drawbacks of further interventions to prolong life. Family meetings to determine goals of care can help clarify the patient’s wishes. Many patients opt to forgo invasive interventions that
prolong life but decrease quality of life and may elect hospice care. If a patient is incapacitated, then close family, durable powers of attorney, and advance directives should be consulted with regard to the decision to pursue
hospice care. Hospice care is a model of health care that prioritizes quality of life over prolongation of life, emphasizing the palliation of physical, emotional, and spiritual pain. Measures that prolong life without enhancing quality of
life (eg, invasive procedures) are incompatible with the hospice care model. Based on models of health care reimbursement in the United States, patients eligible for hospice care typically possess a terminal illness from which they
are expected to die within 6 months.
educational_objective:
As patients near the end of their life, physicians should facilitate discussions with the patient and their family to clarify their wishes for ongoing care. Some patients may favor life-prolonging interventions while
others may opt to prioritize quality of life. Hospice care is a model of health care that prioritizes quality of life over prolongation of life.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
6. A30-year-old primigravid woman at 11 weeks’ gestation comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of increasingly severe midline to right lower quadrant abdominal pain and increasing vaginal spotting.
She also has had pain with sexual intercourse during this time. She has no history of serious illness, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. While waiting to be examined, she has the onset of dizziness. Her
temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. The uterus is consistent in size with a 10-week gestation and tender to palpation. Tilt test is positive. Transvaginal
ultrasonography shows an intrauterine gestational sac to the right of midline and extending into the myometrium. There is free fluid in the cul-de-sac and no adnexal masses. Which of the following is the most likely
diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
This patient has an ectopic pregnancy in the fundus of her uterus, near where her fallopian tube meets her uterine body. This is referred to as a cornual, or interstitial, pregnancy. Ectopic pregnancy is an abnormal pregnancy in
which the fertilized ovum implants in the fallopian tube (most commonly) or myometrium, on the ovary, within the peritoneal cavity, or in any nonendometrial location. Ectopic pregnancy classically presents with vaginal bleeding and
abdominopelvic pain. Serum B-hCG concentrations do not increase as expected in ectopic pregnancy, often lagging the normal expected doubling. Ultrasonography can be used to confirm a viable intrauterine pregnancy and may
be able to visualize an ectopic pregnancy depending on its location. An ectopic pregnancy is nonviable. Ectopic pregnancy can be managed medically, using methotrexate for small, early pregnancies, but may require
salpingectomy or evacuation with laparoscopy for larger pregnancies, in cases of medical treatment failure, or in any case of complication. Complications of ectopic pregnancy include rupture, bleeding, and hemoperitoneum.
Severe cases can result in hemorrhagic shock, which may be beginning to develop in this patient given her evidence of hemodynamic instability with tachycardia and hypotension, as well as dizziness and free fluid in her cul-de-
sac. The next best step in treatment of this patient would likely be emergency evacuation of the pregnancy.
educational_objective:
Ectopic pregnancy is an abnormal extrauterine pregnancy (eg, in the fallopian tube, myometrium, ovary, or peritoneum) occurring in an anatomic location that cannot support a pregnancy. A cornual, or
interstitial, pregnancy is an ectopic pregnancy in which the embryo inserts in the myometrium near the area where the fallopian tube meets the uterine cavity. It commonly presents with vaginal bleeding, abdominopelvic pain, a
gestational sac that invades the myometrium, and an abnormally low serum B-hCG concentration. Complications include rupture and bleeding with consequent hemorrhagic shock in severe cases. Treatment includes methotrexate
for small, early pregnancies or surgical resection for larger, complicated pregnancies.

vignette:
7. A3402-g (7-lb 8-0z) male newborn has severe respiratory distress immediately after delivery. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He is gasping for air. The trachea is deviated to the
right. Breath sounds are markedly decreased over the left hemithorax compared with the right hemithorax. Heart sounds are shifted to the right. The abdomen is markedly scaphoid. This patient is at greatest risk for death
from which of the following?

choices.text: Congenital cardiac disease with low output

correct_explanation:
This newborn presents with a likely congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which places the newborn at risk for pulmonary hypoplasia. Herniation of abdominal organs into the thorax compresses the lungs while they are developing in
utero. Pulmonary hypoplasia is the result of a complex mechanism that involves direct compression of abdominal organs on the developing lungs. This affects bronchial and vascular architecture with reduced branching and blood
supply, and increased thickness of alveolar septa. Newborns with pulmonary hypoplasia commonly develop persistent pulmonary hypertension due to increased pulmonary vascular resistance, resulting in potentially severe heart
failure. This collection of respiratory and circulatory difficulties may be rapidly life-threatening to the newborn. Treatment involves surgical repair of the hernia, although the management of congenital diaphragmatic hernia must also
consider the multitude of secondary pulmonary and cardiovascular problems that result from the herniation of abdominal viscera into the developing thorax.
educational_objective:
Pulmonary hypoplasia occurs as a sequela of congenital diaphragmatic hernia and results in serious and potentially life-threatening consequences to pulmonary and cardiac function. Pulmonary hypoplasia is
caused by compression of the lungs by herniated abdominal organs with secondary changes in bronchial and vascular development

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
8. A68-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 4-day history of progressive shortness of breath. She has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and
osteoarthritis. Her medications are metformin, losartan, lovastatin, and acetaminophen. She also uses continuous home oxygen therapy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood
pressure is 100/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. On pulmonary examination, diffuse crackles are heard bilaterally. On cardiac examination, an S, gallop is heard. There is 4+
pitting edema of the lower extremities. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
This patient with dyspnea, hypoxia, diffuse crackles, and pitting edema has a presentation suggestive of decompensated congestive heart failure. Patients with heart failure are categorized by having either reduced ejection fraction
(systolic heart failure) or preserved ejection fraction (diastolic heart failure). Common causes of heart failure include ischemic heart disease, chronic hypertension, cardiomyopathies, thyrotoxicosis, substance use, and pulmonary
disease. Patients with left-sided heart failure eventually develop backup of blood flow into the pulmonary vasculature that leads them to develop pulmonary edema. These patients may present with cough, dyspnea, orthopnea, and
crackles may be heard on lung examination. Patients with right-sided heart failure (most commonly occurring secondary to left-sided heart failure) may present with increased jugular venous pressures, jugular venous distension,
peripheral edema, and hepatic congestion. On physical examination, patients may have bilateral crackles and the presence of an S3 or S4 heart sound on auscultation. Heart failure is diagnosed with echocardiography.
educational_objective:
Patients with heart failure classically present with dyspnea, orthopnea, lower extremity edema, and jugular venous distension. Physical examination may disclose pulmonary crackles and an S3 or Sy heart
sound. Heart failure is diagnosed with echocardiography.

vignette:
9. A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and fatigue. He has hemophilia A and requires recombinant factor VIII therapy, as needed. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F),
pulse is 90/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows exudative tonsillopharyngitis and bilateral lymphadenopathy. There is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant of
the abdomen. The liver span is 14 cm. The spleen tip is palpated at the left costal margin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Measurement of serum electrolyte and glucose concentrations

correct_explanation:
Infectious mononucleosis is a viral illness caused often by Epstein-Barr virus. Epstein-Barr virus is transmitted through respiratory secretions and saliva, and is commonly acquired by teenagers and young adults. While B
lymphocytes are the cell type infected, atypical lymphocytes seen on peripheral blood smear are actually cytotoxic, CD8+ T lymphocytes that are reacting to the viral infection. As a result, patients often have leukocytosis with a
lymphocytic predominance. Cytomegalovirus is another cause of infectious mononucleosis, and an acute HIV infection may present with a similar syndrome. Clinically, the syndrome is characterized by fever, lymphadenopathy
(typically involving the posterior cervical lymph nodes), and hepatosplenomegaly, along with pharyngitis. Patients with infectious mononucleosis will typically test positive on the monospot test, which detects heterophile antibodies
through the agglutination of sheep or horse erythrocytes. Patients with mononucleosis may present with cholestatic hepatitis. Liver function testing typically shows mildly increased serum concentrations of transaminases, alkaline
phosphatase, and bilirubin. Severely increased transaminase concentrations should prompt evaluation for other possible causes, such as cytomegalovirus or viral hepatitis. Liver function testing is not necessary for all patients with
infectious mononucleosis, but may be desirable in particular circumstances, such as in patients with underlying hepatic disease or coagulopathies, in whom an assessment of hepatic status is particularly important. Treatment is
supportive, and patients should be counseled to avoid any contact sports until the splenomegaly has resolved, because of the risk for splenic rupture.
educational_objective:
Infectious mononucleosis presents with fatigue, malaise, fever, chills, and sore throat, most commonly caused by Epstein-Barr virus. Physical examination may disclose pharyngitis with erythema and
exudates, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Patients with mononucleosis may present with cholestatic hepatitis. Liver function testing typically shows mildly increased serum concentrations of
transaminases, alkaline phosphatase, and bilirubin. Severely increased transaminase concentrations should prompt evaluation for other possible causes, such as cytomegalovirus or viral hepatitis. Treatment is supportive.

vignette:
10. A12-month-old girl is brought to the physician 6 hours after the onset of swelling of the lips and an itchy rash over her face and hands; she is drooling and has vomited twice during this period. Her mother says that her
daughter had a similar rash once before, but it resolved spontaneously within 1 hour. The girl is breast-fed and eats some table foods. Prior to her symptoms today, she ate ice cream for the first time. She appears alert
and active. Examination shows multiple erythematous macular lesions over the face, neck, hands, and wrists. Bilateral end-expiratory wheezing is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the
diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Anaphylaxis, a severe type | (immediate) hypersensitivity reaction, presents following exposure to an allergen, most commonly medications, foods, or insect stings. It is mediated by activation of IgE, which leads to the release of
histamine and cytokines from mast cells and basophils. This subsequently leads to acute inflammation and profound vasodilation in multiple organ systems, generally the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, and
integumentary systems. Symptoms include the rapid onset of bronchospasm with dyspnea or wheezing, urticaria, flushing, nausea and emesis, edematous lips and tongue, and hypotension with tachycardia. When severe and
untreated, it can progress to circulatory collapse with cardiovascular arrest or death due to asphyxiation and airway obstruction. Treatment includes the administration of epinephrine, antihistamines, bronchodilators, and
glucocorticoids, as well as intravenous fluids. Severe cases may require endotracheal intubation and the administration of vasopressors. Epinephrine, a potent vasoconstrictor, should be administered first as it decreases airway
edema and hypotension. Milk protein allergy, which can occur in both breast-fed and formula-fed infants, is a likely cause; however, the ice cream may have contained traces of another allergen. Radioallergosorbent testing, used to
identify antibodies against particular antigens, can be used to identify the specific trigger or triggers.
educational_objective:
Anaphylaxis is an lgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction that leads to extensive degranulation of mast cells and basophils, which results in acute multisystem inflammation and vasodilation. Symptoms
include bronchospasm with associated dyspnea or wheezing, urticaria, flushing, nausea and emesis, edematous lips and tongue, and hypotension with tachycardia. Treatment begins with urgent administration of epinephrine,
followed by antihistamines, bronchodilators, glucocorticoids, and fluids. Following acute treatment, radioallergosorbent testing can be used to identify triggers.

Y UA 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fever, progressive fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He also has had dark urine and clay-colored stools during this time. Six weeks
ago, he traveled to Central America where he ate the local food, including raw shellfish and vegetables. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is
110/85 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. The liver is tender and palpated 6 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 100 ums
Serum
Total bilirubin 7.1 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 105 U/L
AST 2000 U/L
ALT 1500 U/L
Without treatment, which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient's condition?
A) Chronic carrier state
B) Chronic hepatitis
C) Fulminant hepatitis
D) Hepatocellular carcinoma
Correct Answer: E.
This patient’s presenting findings of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, icterus, hepatomegaly, and right upper quadrant tenderness 6 weeks after traveling to Central America and eating raw shellfish is consistent with an acute
hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection. HAV is a nonenveloped, single-stranded RNA virus that is spread through fecal-oral transmission. It is commonly acquired through ingestion of poorly cooked, improperly handled, or raw foods,
including shellfish. HAV has an incubation period of several weeks. Presenting signs and symptoms include fever, nausea, vomiting, poor appetite, abdominal pain, jaundice, and hepatomegaly, although many patients are
asymptomatic. Laboratory findings include transaminitis, increased alkaline phosphatase, hyperbilirubinemia, and bilirubinuria. The diagnosis is confirmed by the serologic detection of anti-HAV IgM antibodies. HAV infection is
typically a self-limited illness and does not progress to chronic infection.
Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D.
Chronic carrier state (Choice A) is not associated with HAV. Generally, once a patient has been infected with HAV, the disease is self-limiting and confers immunity. It would be extremely rare to enter a chronic carrier state of HAV.
Chronic hepatitis (Choice B) and hepatocellular carcinoma (Choice D) are not associated with HAV. Hepatitis B is more commonly associated with chronic infection, leading to cirrhosis and potentially hepatocellular carcinoma. For
this reason, vaccination against hepatitis B is commonly administered to newborns, although it can also be given in adulthood and is recommended for health care workers, injection drug users, men who have sex with men, and
patients with HIV or hepatitis C.
Fulminant hepatitis (Choice C) is not commonly seen with HAV. Autoimmune hepatitis, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C are more likely to progress into fulminant hepatitis. In rare cases, HAV can become fulminant, but it is significantly
more likely to continue its course as a self-limited illness with no long-term effects.
Educational Objective: Hepatitis A virus is a common cause of food poisoning and traveler’s diarrhea among travelers in the developing world. The disease course of hepatitis Ais generally benign with fever, nausea, vomiting, and
diarrhea, and further complications are rare. Vaccination against hepatitis A virus is recommended to all travelers who visit developing countries. ————SS

vignette:
12. A35-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of sharp midchest pain that worsens with inspiration and lying on her back. Her only medication
is hydroxychloroquine. She appears mildly uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations ——————————
are clear to auscultation. On cardiac examination, a scratchy, high-pitched sound is heard over the lower left sternal border. There is erythema, swelling, and warmth of the wrists. An is shown. Which of the following
is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
correct_explanation:
This patient with lupus, now presenting with pleuritic chest pain that is better when leaning forward and an ECG showing diffuse ST segment elevation, likely has pericarditis. Pericarditis classically presents with central chest pain,
which is often pleuritic, is worse when supine, and improves with leaning forward. It can occur in patients with inflammatory, infectious, or malignant conditions, such as viral infection, systemic lupus erythematosus, tuberculosis,
and lymphoma, and can present as a complication of myocardial infarction. If not treated, pericarditis can lead to the development of pericardial effusions, which if large and quickly accumulating, can result in cardiac tamponade.
On cardiac examination, pericarditis discloses a diastolic friction rub, described as a harsh sound heard in diastole. The condition is diagnosed clinically and supported by increased inflammatory markers such as ESR and C-
reactive protein. ECG may show diffuse ST elevation with PR depressions. Treatment requires anti-inflammatory medications such as ibuprofen, glucocorticoids, and/or colchicine.

vignette:
43. A 70-year-old man is brought to the office by his niece because of a 6-month history of frequent falls. She says he has fallen backward suddenly while walking approximately once monthly during this time. She adds that

he has a tendency to look down at his feet while walking. Recently, his speech has become slurred and he has had several choking episodes while eating. He also has had difficulty reading. He has not had

light-headedness on standing, difficulty with urination, constipation, changes in mood, or hallucinations. Physical examination shows mild nuchal rigidity and symmetric rigidity of all extremities. There is no tremor. There is

impaired visual gaze that is worse when the patient attempts to look down. He has decreased stride length on gait testing and impaired balance while turning. His speech is soft. He has poor enunciation and impaired letter

fluency. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Progressive supranuclear palsy, an atypical parkinsonian disorder, is a neurodegenerative disease associated with tau-positive neurofibrillary tangles in the basal ganglia, cortex, and brainstem. Patients typically present around age
65 years with gait instability, oculomotor deficits (eg, classically vertical gaze palsy), frontal lobe deficits, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity. The gait pattern varies in step length and base width, though patients typically walk and
pivot too quickly as a result of impulsivity from frontal lobe damage, leading to backward falls. Definitive diagnosis occurs by neuropathologic examination illustrating a pattern of neurofibrillary tangles in the characteristic
distribution. Neuroimaging illustrating midbrain and/or cerebral cortex atrophy supports the diagnosis. Death typically occurs within 6 to 9 years after disease onset. Management is supportive and includes physical and occupational
therapy along with advanced care planning.
educational_objective:
Progressive supranuclear palsy, an atypical parkinsonian disorder, is a neurodegenerative disease associated with tau-positive neurofibrillary tangles in the basal ganglia, cortex, and brainstem. Patients
typically present around age 65 years with gait instability, oculomotor deficits (eg, classically vertical gaze palsy), frontal lobe deficits, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity. Management is supportive and includes physical and
occupational therapy along with advanced care planning.

vignette:
14. A35-year-old primigravid woman is brought to the emergency department (ED) by paramedics after a neighbor called emergency services because the patient was being disruptive and combative. En route to the ED,
fingerstick blood glucose concentration was 45 mg/dL; intravenous 50% dextrose was administered, and her mental status improved. On arrival, she is fully oriented. She has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus
treated with insulin. She says she is pregnant but does not know when she had her last menstrual period. She has not yet initiated prenatal care. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 23 years. She does not
drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the uterus is nontender; fundal height is 2 cm below the umbilicus. Fetal heart rate is 146/min. Pelvic ultrasonography shows a single
intrauterine fetus consistent in size with a 17-week gestation; the thighs and legs are fused, and there are two femoral and two tibial bones within a single soft-tissue and muscular compartment. The amniotic fluid index is
2 cm (N=10-20). Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient’s pregnancy?
correct_explanation:
Caudal regression syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by the partial or complete absence of the sacrum, and in some cases, the lower lumbar spine. Caudal regression syndrome falls under the umbrella of diabetic
embryopathies and includes conditions in which there is an anomaly in the embryo associated with diabetes in the mother. Most often, this is caused by poor control of diabetes and hyperglycemia prior to and during pregnancy. The
theorized pathophysiology of these disorders involves abnormal myoinositol uptake, which leads to abnormalities in the arachidonic acid and prostaglandin pathway. These abnormalities lead to birth defects and often early
pregnancy loss. In fetuses with caudal regression syndrome, clinical features and symptoms are dependent on the spinal lesion level as well as the severity of the abnormalities, and commonly include concurrent anorectal
malformations and aplasia of the sacrum. While it is possible for fetuses with caudal regression syndrome to survive birth and live a mostly functional life to some extent, those with significant abnormalities, such as the fetus in this
case, are not likely to survive gestation. This patient’s fetus has minimal differentiation of the bilateral lower extremities as well as an amniotic fluid index of 2 cm, which is 20% of the lower limit of normal and likely incompatible with
life.
educational_objective:
Caudal regression syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by the partial or complete absence of the sacrum, and in some cases the lower lumbar spine. This is most commonly caused by poorly
controlled diabetes prior to and during gestation. The clinical presentation and prognosis are dependent upon the severity of the lesion and the level of neurologic compromise.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
15. A92-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of generalized fatigue and weakness. She has been a resident in a skilled nursing care facility for 30 years and is nonambulatory.

This morning, she became agitated when the medical staff carefully lifted her arms and legs to move her on the bed. She has intestinal malabsorption syndrome, pulmonary fibrosis, dementia, and global deconditioning.

She receives chronic parenteral nutrition. She appears pale and is oriented to person but not to place or time. She can follow simple commands. Palpation of the upper extremities and thighs produces pain. She can flex

and extend the elbows and wrists and dorsiflex and plantarflex the ankles and extend the toes bilaterally. Sensation is intact over the extremities. Skeletal survey shows pseudofractures of the femur and proximal ulna

bilaterally. Which of the following serum concentrations is most likely to be increased in this patient?
correct_explanation:
This patient presents with signs of osteomalacia secondary to vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D plays a role in serum calcium and phosphate homeostasis by promoting intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate, increasing bone
mineralization at low concentrations, and bone resorption at higher concentrations. Vitamin D deficiency can be caused by malabsorption in the intestinal tract, malnutrition or insufficient dietary intake, and decreased sun exposure.
Elderly patients are at particularly increased risk for vitamin D deficiency as a result of decreased vitamin D synthesis with age and lack of sunlight exposure. Patients dependent on parenteral nutrition often have poor oral intake
and are very frequently vitamin D deficient. Decreased concentrations of vitamin D result in decreased intestinal calcium absorption and hypocalcemia, sensed by the parathyroid gland via calcium-sensing receptors, leading to an
increase in secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) to normalize serum calcium levels. Increased PTH stimulates osteoclastic bone reabsorption and distal convoluted tubular calcium reabsorption and phosphate excretion in the
kidney. These mechanisms are often inadequate to maintain calcium homeostasis and lead to osteomalacia, an adult form of vitamin D deficiency characterized by loss of bone mineral density and abnormal osteoid mineralization.
Patients with osteomalacia present with nonspecific symptoms including muscular weakness, myalgia, bone pain, and in later stages may have bone deformity, gait alteration, and falls. Patients may also have signs and symptoms
of hypocalcemia including confusion, memory difficulties, myalgias, and perioral and/or peripheral paresthesias. Pseudofractures, also known as looser zones, are a type of insufficiency fracture that are characteristic of
osteomalacia and are visible on x-rays as lines of lucency corresponding to areas of low bone mineral density. Pseudofractures typically occur in the ribs, posterior ulna, pubic and iliac bones, and in the femoral neck or shaft.
Treatment is with oral supplementation of both vitamin D and calcium, and typically results in improvement in symptoms of weakness and pain, as well as normalization of laboratory values.
educational_objective:
Vitamin D deficiency can be caused by intestinal malabsorption, malnutrition, insufficient dietary intake, and decreased sun exposure. Osteomalacia is an adult form of vitamin D defi 22====s=====s=====
loss of bone mineral density and abnormal osteoid mineralization. Patients with osteomalacia present with nonspecific symptoms including muscular weakness, myalgia, bone pain, and in later stages may} =— t
alteration, and falls, or may show signs of hypocalcemia. X-rays may show pseudofractures. ——

vignette:
16. A4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after he refused to walk or bear weight on his left leg this morning. She says he has been irritable during the past 3 days. He has a 3-month history
of episodes of moderate pain in his shoulders and ankles, but the pain has not been as severe as his current symptom. His mother says he bruises easily. He has not had recent trauma or fever. He was born at term by
spontaneous vaginal delivery following an uncomplicated pregnancy. He walked at the age of 11 months. He attends preschool. He is at the 70th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within
normal limits. There is no gingival bleeding, and the teeth are intact. There is a deep ecchymosis over the anterior aspect of the left thigh; the skin otherwise appears normal. The patient is unable to extend the left knee
because of pain. Laboratory studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings in this patient?
Platelet Partial
Count Prothrombin Thromboplastin
(/mm/3) Time (sec) Time (sec)
correct_explanation:
Factor VIII deficiency, also known as hemophilia A, most likely explains this patient's significant bruising and presumed presentation of hemarthrosis. Hemophilia A is an X-linked coagulopathy that arises because of a genetic
deficiency in factor VIII synthesis or activity. Patients often present with easy bruising and hemorrhage involving muscles and joints. Hemorrhage can be life-threatening, often requiring transfusions of factor VIII to replace the
deficient protein. Patients can acquire antibodies against exogenous factor VIII, which can necessitate larger transfusions to elicit the same hemostatic effect. As the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) measures the activity of the
intrinsic clotting cascade, which includes factor VIII, a deficiency of factor VIII leads to a prolonged PTT. However, the prothrombin time (PT) is normal as it measures the activity of the extrinsic clotting cascade, which remains
intact in patients with hemophilia A. There is no effect on the concentration or activity of platelets.
educational_objective:
Hemophilia A results from a genetically inherited deficiency in factor VIIIl synthesis or activity. Patients present with easy bruising and hemorrhage into muscle and joints. Laboratory studies show an
increased partial thromboplastin time, but a normal prothrombin time. Treatment is with recombinant factor VIII.

vignette:
17. A37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 2 hours after cutting her hand while working in the garden. She received a tetanus vaccine 3 months ago. Examination shows a clean wound. After the wound is

treated, the patient insists on receiving another tetanus shot. The physician explains that the previous vaccine adequately protects her, but the patient insists that it be repeated. Which of the following is the most appropriate

next step?

choices.text: Administer 0.9% saline and tell the patient that it is tetanus toxoid
Administer tetanus toxoid and bill it to the patient's insurance
Explain that the patient will have to pay the full fee if she receives the vaccine
Tell the patient to find another physician in the emergency department who will administer the vaccine

correct_explanation:
Routine tetanus toxoid vaccination is recommended for all previously immunized adults every 10 years. Tetanus toxoid should be given following injuries in previously vaccinated patients if the wound is minor and clean and the
most recent vaccination was greater than 10 years ago, or if the wound is severe or contaminated and the most recent vaccination was greater than 5 years ago. In this case, the patient recently received vaccination and presents
with a clean, minor wound. Repeat administration of tetanus toxoid is not indicated in this instance. While tetanus toxoid is generally extremely safe, rare adverse events have been reported, including fever, febrile seizures,
transverse myelitis, polyneuritis, urticaria, and anaphylaxis. Patients requesting nonindicated or unnecessary medical care is a common ethical challenge that most physicians will face. The physician must balance between the
ethical principles of autonomy (the patient should be allowed to make decisions regarding their own health care) and nonmaleficence (the physician should not take actions that will harm the patient). Physicians are not obligated to
provide medical services that are not indicated, not necessary, or are potentially harmful. Additionally, billing for unnecessary services may be construed as fraud. The best approach in this instance is for the physician to try to
understand the patient's reasoning for wanting vaccination, reiterate that vaccination will not be beneficial and will expose the patient to avoidable risk, and to refuse to administer the vaccine.

vignette:
18. A32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of palpitations, tremors, light-headedness, and sweating. She has not had loss of consciousness, chest pain, or shortness of
breath. She has had similar episodes in the past, which were relieved by eating and with rest. Her only medication is lorazepam as needed for generalized anxiety disorder. There is no family history of similar episodes.
Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 138/90 mm Hg. Physical and mental status examinations show no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Nat 138 mEq/L
K+ 4 mEq/L
Cl- 99 mEq/L
HCO,” 24 mEq/L
Mg2* 1.9 mEq/L

Glucose 45 mg/dL
Phosphorus 3.8 mg/dL

choices.text: 24-Hour urine collection for measurement of catecholamines

correct_explanation:
Measurement of serum C peptide and glucose concentrations are obtained when there are concerns for an insulinoma. Insulinomas are a rare tumor of the pancreatic islet cells that inappropriately produce excess amounts of
insulin and C peptide, resulting in hypoglycemia. Signs and symptoms of an insulinoma include confusion, difficulty concentrating, sweating, fatigue, weakness, and fainting as a result of hypoglycemia. Symptoms are often
precipitated either by a period of fasting or by strenuous exercise. Acute management of hypoglycemia is paramount for these patients to avoid more serious complications, such as seizures or fainting. Insulinomas are generally
small and benign but have been found on occasion to grow larger and metastasize. Diagnosis can be made by measuring 72-hour fasting serum insulin and glucose concentrations, C peptide concentration, as well as CT scan,
MRI, or ultrasonography to locate and characterize the tumor. Definitive treatment is surgical removal, though diazoxide can be used to decrease insulin production in the interim.

vignette:
19. A24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of progressive right-sided weakness and numbness. One year ago while traveling overseas, she had loss of vision in the left eye that developed

gradually during the course of 1 week, persisted for 1 month, and resolved gradually and spontaneously during the following 3 weeks. At its worst, her vision in the left eye was severely blurred and colors appeared

washed out. Her vision recovered completely, and she did not see a physician. She has not had similar symptoms since that time. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. Examination shows

mild weakness of the right lower aspect of the face. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the right extremities. Sensation to light touch is mildly decreased over the right side of the face and body. Examination shows no abnormalities

on the left. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to decrease the recurrence of similar symptoms in this patient?
correct_explanation:
The patient’s presentation with neurologic symptoms at various times and locations, as well as an MRI showing T2 hyperintense lesions in the white matter, suggests a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an
immune-mediated demyelinating disease. Onset usually occurs between the ages of 20 to 40 years and is most common in those assigned female at birth. Additional risk factors include residing in temperate climates and having a
family history of MS. Presenting symptoms depend on the location of the lesion. Optic neuritis is a common initial manifestation and typically presents with poor visual acuity and a consequent afferent pupillary defect on physical
examination. According to the McDonald criteria for diagnosing MS, the patient must have evidence of demyelinating lesions that are separated in time and location. This evidence can be based on subjective symptoms and/or
imaging evidence. This patient presents with episodic neurologic symptoms that could be localized to different central nervous system locations (eg, optic nerve, cerebral white matter) at different times. Oligoclonal bands of
immunoglobulins, indicating immune overactivation, can be found in the cerebrospinal fluid, but are not necessary for diagnosis. Treatment includes corticosteroids for symptomatic management of acute flares and long-term
disease-modifying treatments, such as interferons, monoclonal antibodies, and immunomodulators (eg, subcutaneous glatiramer).
educational_objective:
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a progressive autoimmune demyelinating disease that affects neurons of the central nervous system, resulting in neurologic symptoms that are separated in time and location. Optic
neuritis is a common initial manifestation and typically presents with poor visual acuity and a consequent afferent pupillary defect on physical examination. Treatment of MS includes corticosteroids to decrease the duration of acute
flares and immune-modulating therapies (eg, subcutaneous glatiramer) to prevent future recurrences.

vignette:
20. Apreviously healthy 1-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty breathing for 12 hours. Over the past 2 days, he has had a cough and clear nasal discharge. His temperature is
36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/46 mm Hg. He appears extremely anxious and apprehensive. Examination shows cool, pale, and mottled extremities. Pulses are thready.
Scattered wheezes and bilateral basilar crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest; there is a gallop with no murmur. The liver is tender and palpated 6 cm below the right costal margin. Capillary blood gas analysis
while breathing supplemental oxygen shows:
pH 7.02
Pco, 28 mm Hg
Po, 80 mm Hg
An x-ray of the chest shows mild cardiomegaly and hilar infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
This infant with a recent history of an upper respiratory infection now presenting in cardiogenic shock has symptoms consistent with heart failure secondary to myocarditis. Patients classically present with evidence of
decompensated heart failure, including dyspnea, orthopnea, peripheral edema, and potentially with evidence of shock (eg, poor peripheral perfusion, increased lactic acid, hypotension). With this patient's recent respiratory illness,
the cause of his heart failure is most likely viral myocarditis. Myocarditis refers to inflammation of the cardiac myocytes; notable causes of viral myocarditis include coxsackievirus group B, parvovirus B19, human herpesvirus 6,
adenovirus, and HIV. Further diagnostic evaluation with x-ray and echocardiography can support this diagnosis by confirming cardiomegaly, pulmonary interstitial edema, and a decreased ejection fraction indicating abnormal
systolic function. Treatment is generally supportive as most cases remit with time. Some patients may require diuresis and, depending on severity, mechanical or pharmacologic inotropic support or transplant.
educational_objective:
Viral myocarditis can present in children with fever and signs and symptoms characteristic of heart failure, including volume overload, chest pain, shortness of breath, pulmonary edema, and an S3 gallop on
physical examination.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
94. A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of mild lower abdominal pain that is relieved with defecation. During this time, she also has had nonfatty, nongreasy diarrhea with mucus but no

blood. She does not have bowel movements during the night. She is otherwise asymptomatic. She has generalized anxiety disorder treated with citalopram. There is no family history of colon cancer. The patient's vital

signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is not distended or tender. There are no masses, and bowel sounds are normal. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. Results of serum

antiendomysial IgA and anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody testing are negative. Tests of the stool for occult blood, ova, parasites, and leukocytes are negative. Sigmoidoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the

following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is diagnosed using the Rome-IV criteria, which includes the presence of abdominal pain at least once weekly that is associated with (and generally relieved by) defecation, along with a change in stool
appearance or frequency. At least two of the three criteria are required for diagnosis. IBS is further subdivided into IBS with constipation (IBS-C), with diarrhea (IBS-D), or mixed (IBS-M). IBS often presents with intermittent
abdominal pain that is relieved by bowel movements and associated alterations in bowel habits with intermittent episodes of diarrhea and/or constipation. Stress management may improve bowel habits in patients with IBS, which is
often associated with concomitant anxiety. In this patient, loperamide may help with diarrhea and improve regularity of bowel movements. Features that are suggestive of underlying organic pathology rather than IBS include the
presence of occult blood or melena, nocturnal diarrhea, worsening abdominal pain, weight loss, or a family history of inflammatory bowel disease or colon cancer. This patient does not have evidence of these symptoms, making
IBS the most likely diagnosis. In patients with IBS and diarrhea, dietary changes and symptom control with loperamide therapy are the first steps in management.
educational_objective:
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is characterized by abdominal pain and a change in stool appearance or frequency. In patients with IBS and diarrhea, dietary changes and symptom control with loperamide
therapy are the first steps in management. Features that are suggestive of underlying organic pathology rather than IBS include the presence of occult blood or melena, nocturnal diarrhea, worsening abdominal pain, weight loss, or
a family history of inflammatory bowel disease or colon cancer.

vignette:
22. A6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-day history of fever, sore throat, a rapidly spreading rash, and decreased oral intake. During the past 12 hours, he has refused to eat

or drink and has not voided. Medical history is remarkable for a 3-day hospitalization at age 2 months for enterovirus meningitis. The patient currently receives no medications and vaccinations are up-to-date. He appears

uncomfortable. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight; BMI is at the 40th percentile. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/70

mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination discloses oral lesions and dry mucous membranes. There is a blanching rash over the upper and lower extremities and

buttocks. The lesions appear as shown in the photographs. Cardiopulmonary examination discloses no abnormalities. Abdominal examination discloses no tenderness or hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following is the

most appropriate initial diagnostic study?

choices.text: Respiratory panel polymerase chain reaction test
Tzanck test of a skin vesicle

correct_explanation:
Coxsackievirus is an RNA enterovirus that is transmitted via oral secretions or feces. Coxsackievirus group A infection causes hand-foot-and-mouth disease and herpangina. Coxsackievirus group B infection may cause myocarditis
and pericarditis. Hand-foot-and-mouth disease presents with oral lesions, hand and foot lesions, fever, sore throat, and a progressive rash. The most common complication of hand-foot-and-mouth disease is decreased oral intake
and dehydration due to dysphagia. Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is a common, often benign, self-limited disease. No diagnostic study is indicated currently, and management involves symptom control with antipyretics, pain control,
and oral hydration.
educational_objective:
Coxsackievirus is transmitted via oral secretions or feces. Coxsackievirus group A infection causes hand-foot-and-mouth disease and herpangina. Both are generally benign and self-limiting and do not
require further diagnostic workup.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
23. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of a 1-year history of increasing facial hair growth and acne. Menses have occurred at irregular 60- to 90-day intervals since menarche at the age of

12 years. She takes no medications. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (155 Ib); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Examination shows acne vulgaris over the forehead and chin. Her Ferriman-Gallwey score for hair growth is

10 (N<8). Her serum testosterone concentration is 45 ng/dL (N<5—40). Results of other serum studies, including thyroid-stimulating hormone, prolactin, and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate concentrations, are within the

reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
correct_explanation:
The most likely cause of this patient’s condition is polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which presents classically with irregular menses, infertility, and hirsutism, often in patients with an increased body weight. It requires two of the
following for diagnosis: oligo/anovulation, polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography, and clinical or biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism. It is also associated with signs of insulin resistance, such as acanthosis nigricans and
increased blood glucose concentrations. PCOS is caused by an abnormal hypothalamic hormonal feedback response, which leads to increased luteinizing hormone compared with follicle-stimulating hormone, as well as markedly
increased testosterone production from the theca lutein cells. Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate concentrations are typically normal, as these androgens are secreted from the adrenal gland. Treatment includes weight loss, combined
oral contraceptives for menstrual regulation, and spironolactone or ketoconazole for hirsutism. Clomiphene stimulates increased ovulation and can also be used for individuals desiring pregnancy, as can metformin. If the patient is
diagnosed with diabetes mellitus, oral antihyperglycemic medications or insulin may also be necessary. A potential complication of long-standing PCOS is endometrial cancer as a result of the prolonged exposure of the
endometrium to unopposed estrogen.
educational_objective:
Polycystic ovarian syndrome presents with menstrual irregularities, signs of androgen excess, obesity, insulin resistance, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography. It is associated with increased
concentrations of testosterone but normal concentrations of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate. Treatment includes weight loss and combined oral contraceptives for menstrual regulation, and antihyperglycemic medications or insulin
for the management of diabetes mellitus, if diagnosed.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
24. Arandomized clinical trial is planned to determine whether a new form of chemotherapy increases the survival time for patients with pancreatic cancer. The investigators intend to randomize 300 patients aged 40 to 70

years into two groups. One group will receive the new chemotherapy and the other group will receive standard therapy. Patients will be observed for up to 5 years. Interim analyses will be conducted on an annual basis, and

the trial will be terminated if sufficient evidence of efficacy is noted at any of the interim analyses. This interim analysis plan will most likely lead to which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased chance of a type | error overall
Decreased chance of a type II error overall
Increased chance of a type II error overall

correct_explanation:
The likelihood of erroneously rejecting the null hypothesis (ie, concluding that the alternative hypothesis is true) is called a type | error. The acceptable rate of a type | error is a percentage called the a level and is set by the
investigators. When the a level is converted to a decimal, it can be compared to the P-value of the experiment. An a level of 5% or 0.05 indicates that if the null hypothesis is true, there is a 5% chance that the investigators will
erroneously reject it based on the study results. Interim analyses can sometimes be desirable for several reasons, such as efficiency, cost savings associated with longer clinical trials, and minimizing patient exposure to
experimental treatments. However, it is important to consider that the a level describes the chance of a type | error each time data analysis is performed. Therefore, repeated interim analyses inherently increase the chance of type |
error. An a level adjustment may be necessary if interim analysis is planned. Furthermore, terminating a trial early may lead to erroneous conclusions if the period of follow-up is inadequate. The structure of the study in the example
involves multiple interim analyses conducted annually, which will increase the risk of type | error.
educational_objective:
The likelihood of erroneously rejecting the null hypothesis (ie, concluding that the alternative hypothesis is true) is called a type | error. The acceptable rate of a type | error is a percentage called the a level
and is set by the investigators. Interim analyses can sometimes be desirable for several reasons, such as efficiency, cost savings associated with longer clinical trials, and minimizing patient exposure to experimental treatments.
However, it is important to consider that the a level describes the chance of type | error each time data analysis is performed. Therefore, repeated interim analyses inherently increase the chance of type | error.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
Y

vignette:
25. Six weeks after undergoing triple coronary artery bypass grafting after suffering an acute myocardial infarction, a 57-year-old man comes to the office with his wife for a follow-up examination. Since the surgery, the patient

has had left leg pain and numbness and a 9-kg (20-Ib) weight loss. He reports that he has not been sleeping well and has had an intermittent cough. His energy has been decreased and he has lost interest in his usual

activities. He has not had chest pain. A low-impact exercise program was prescribed at the time of discharge. The patient's wife says that he has not maintained the suggested exercise program, stating that he was too

tired. Medications include atenolol, atorvastatin, and 81-mg aspirin daily. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 91 kg (200 Ib); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 62/min, respirations

14/min, and blood pressure 140/80 mm Hg. Physical examination discloses well-healed surgical incisions. Total serum cholesterol concentration is 180 mg/dL, and fasting blood glucose concentration is 128 mg/dL. Which

of the following is the most appropriate change in the patient's therapy?
correct_explanation:
This patient meets the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD). Diagnostic criteria include 2 or more weeks of at least five of the following symptoms: depressed mood, anhedonia, guilt or worthlessness, difficulty concentrating,
psychomotor delay, suicidal thoughts, and/or neurovegetative symptoms (eg, decreased energy, sleep disturbance, appetite disturbance leading to weight changes). These symptoms disrupt everyday functioning. MDD is common
after myocardial infarction (MI) and increases morbidity and mortality. Inflammation has been implicated in the pathogenesis. Symptoms of MDD and symptoms of heart disease commonly overlap (eg, fatigue, insomnia), making the
two difficult to distinguish. However, decreased interest, sad mood, and hopelessness are psychological symptoms that are somewhat specific to MDD and can assist physicians with the diagnosis. Treatment of MDD should include
psychotherapy and antidepressant medication. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, such as sertraline, are generally first-line treatments, especially for patients with heart disease, given their benign cardiac adverse effect
profiles. This patient's leg pain and numbness are likely secondary to catheterization.
educational_objective:
Major depressive disorder includes 2 or more weeks of five of the following symptoms: depressed mood, anhedonia, guilt or worthlessness, difficulty concentrating, psychomotor delay, suicidal thoughts,
and/or neurovegetative symptoms (eg, decreased energy, sleep disturbance, appetite disturbance). Psychological symptoms such as a sad and tearful mood, decreased interest, and hopelessness can distinguish symptoms of
major depressive disorder from symptoms of systemic medical illness. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, such as sertraline, are generally first-line treatments, especially for patients with heart disease, given their benign
cardiac adverse effect profiles.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
26. A 42-year-old primigravid woman at 26 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She feels well, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Prior to conception, she used an oral contraceptive

and drank two cups of coffee daily. She plans to resume using an oral contraceptive and drinking coffee after delivery. She states that after delivery, she will be taking a 6-month maternity leave from work and plans to

breast-feed exclusively during this time. Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 26-week gestation. The most appropriate recommendation for the infant during breast-feeding is supplementation with which of

the following?
correct_explanation:
Breast milk meets the full nutritional needs of an infant up to age 6 months, although infant formula can also be used. However, breast milk does not contain an adequate quantity of vitamin D for infants who are fed solely on breast
milk. For exclusively breast-fed infants, vitamin D supplementation should be encouraged, as should the supplementation of iron after approximately 4 to 6 months. Vitamin D supplementation is important for preventing childhood
vitamin D deficiency, also known as rickets, which can present with multiple skeletal deformities including frontal bossing, dental hypoplasia and caries, nodules at the costochondral junctions of the anterior chest, delayed closure of
the growth plates, and bowing of the tibia and femur. After age 6 months, complementary foods are introduced to a breast milk or formula-based diet, which provide further vitamins, energy, and iron supplementation.
educational_objective:
While breast-feeding can meet the full nutritional needs of an infant for the first 6 months of life, vitamin D supplementation should be encouraged for exclusively breast-fed infants. Vitamin D supplementation
is important because breast milk does not contain sufficient quantities of vitamin D, deficiency of which can lead to childhood rickets. After age 6 months, complementary foods are introduced to a breast milk or formula-based diet,
which provide further vitamins, energy, and iron supplementation.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
27. A57-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine examination. He feels well. He has mild hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He underwent an uncomplicated total right knee arthroplasty 2 years ago. Repair

of a chipped molar tooth is scheduled in 1 week, and the patient requests antibiotics to prevent infection around his prosthetic joint. General health screening measures are up-to-date. The patient is allergic to penicillin.

Current medications are hydrochlorothiazide, enalapril, and insulin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 145/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a well-healed scar

over the right knee. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
The routine administration of prophylactic antibiotics prior to dental procedures is controversial. The rationale for administering antibiotic prophylaxis is based on the fact that manipulation of oral mucosa can result in hematogenous
spread of oral flora, potentially seeding infections in susceptible organs, such as heart valves or any implanted prosthetic hardware. Current guidelines from the American Dental Association recommend against routine use of
antibiotic prophylaxis prior to dental procedures in patients with prosthetic joints. This recommendation is based on a review of current evidence, which has not been found to support a relationship between dental procedures and
prosthetic joint infection. Routine administration of antibiotics preoperatively is therefore of uncertain benefit for this indication, and it also exposes patients to greater risk for adverse effects and events ranging from nausea,
vomiting, and diarrhea to Clostridioides difficile colitis. Additionally, antibiotic prophylaxis contributes to microbial antibiotic resistance and incurs unnecessary medical costs, with some estimates of expenditures on routine antibiotic
prophylaxis prior to dental procedures exceeding $50 million annually in the United States. The best option is to reassure this patient that he is at low risk for developing a joint infection following his dental procedure.
educational_objective:
Antibiotic prophylaxis is of uncertain benefit prior to dental procedures. Current guidelines recommend against routine antibiotic prophylaxis in patients for prevention of prosthetic joint infection. Unnecessary
use of antibiotics preoperatively is associated with adverse effects, antibiotic resistance, and unnecessary medical costs. The best option for a patient concerned about the risk for developing a joint infection following a dental
procedure is reassurance.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
Y 28, A'52-year-old woman with long-standing alcohol Use disorder is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of severe abdominal cramps, fever, nausea, vomiting, and tremulousness. She has drunk
1 L of vodka daily during the past week; her last glass of vodka was 2 days ago. On arrival, the patient is mildly confused and is unable to provide further history. She is oriented to person and place but not to time. Her
temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 152/92 mm Hg. Examination shows marked scleral icterus. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation over the
right upper quadrant. The liver span is 14 cm. There is no fluid wave or asterixis. Laboratory studies show:
Prothrombin time 32 sec (INR=4.5)
Serum
Protein, total 6.2 g/dL
Albumin 2.2 g/dL
Total bilirubin 19.8 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 130 U/L
AST 210 U/L
ALT 101 U/L
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
B) Disulfiram
C) Fresh frozen plasma
D) Lactulose
E) Propranolol
Correct Answer: A.
Alcohol increases the central nervous system activity of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the main inhibitory neurotransmitter. Abrupt discontinuation of alcohol, as seen in this patient who has not had a drink in 2 days, leads to
sympathetic (excitatory) excess. Uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal typically presents with tremors, anxiety, restlessness, headache, nausea, and diaphoresis, which can occur hours after the cessation of alcohol use. If left
untreated, alcohol withdrawal can be complicated by seizures and alcoholic hallucinosis (auditory or visual hallucinations). Delirium tremens, the most concerning and life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, involves
severe confusion and disorientation, fluctuations in consciousness, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability (fluctuations in heart rate and blood pressure with hyperthermia). Alcohol withdrawal is managed with
benzodiazepines (eg, diazepam) to prevent or treat the symptoms of withdrawal, including agitation, and reduce risk for seizures. Additional supportive care is with fluids, nutritional supplementation, and frequent assessment
including vital sign checks.
Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E.
Disulfiram (Choice B) inhibits some isoforms of aldehyde dehydrogenase, resulting in acetaldehyde accumulation. This accumulation causes nausea and vomiting in patients who concurrently take the medication and drink alcohol.
This would not be beneficial in a patient with acute alcohol withdrawal.
Fresh frozen plasma (Choice C) contains clotting factors in addition to fibrinogen, antithrombin III, and other plasma proteins. It has traditionally been used to replace clotting factors in a variety of coagulant-deficient diseases, such
as disseminated intravascular coagulation, but the use of cryoprecipitate and/or prothrombin complex concentrates have largely supplanted its use. It would not be beneficial in this patient.
Lactulose (Choice D) is the treatment of choice for hepatic encephalopathy. This is most commonly seen in patients with cirrhosis whose ability to process ammonia from the gastrointestinal tract is impaired. It is not generally used
in patients with acute alcohol withdrawal.
Propranolol (Choice E) is a nonselective B-adrenergic antagonist with similar activity at 8B; and By receptors. It may be used in the treatment of hypertension, arrhythmias, migraines, essential tremor, and hyperthyroidism. While
propranolol may decrease this patient’s heart rate and control some symptoms related to her withdrawal, it will not improve her seizure risk, making diazepam a more appropriate option.
Educational Objective: Alcohol withdrawal typically presents with tremors, anxiety, restlessness, headache, nausea, and diaphoresis. It can be complicated by seizures, alcoholic hallucinosis, and delirium tremens. It is treated with
benzodiazepines.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
29. A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department from the nursing care facility where she resides, because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever, decreased appetite, and lethargy. She has type 2 diabetes

mellitus and cognitive impairment. Her only medication is metformin. The patient is drowsy and responds to questions with inconsistent answers. She is 152 cm (5 ft) tall and weighs 64 kg (140 Ib); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Her

temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Examination of the left lower extremity shows a

rapidly expanding area of red, shiny skin on the shin with a small fluid-filled bulla. The area is exquisitely tender and warm to the touch. In addition to intravenous antibiotic therapy, which of the following is the most

appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit the patient to the intensive care unit for vasopressor therapy
Discharge the patient back to the nursing care facility with a peripherally inserted central catheter for intravenous antibiotic therapy
Order culture and sensitivity of a tissue sample and await results before further therapy
Transfer the patient to a negative-pressure room

correct_explanation:
Beginning surgical exploration in the operating room is the most appropriate next step in this case. The patient’s presentation is suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis, which may occur following cellulitis, trauma, or invasive procedures.
Common causative organisms include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcal spp., Clostridium spp., and Bacteroides spp. Necrotizing fasciitis is characterized by tissue destruction spreading along fascial planes, may present with
sepsis and a rapidly progressive rash, and is associated with high morbidity and mortality. Clinical examination shows rapidly progressive erythema or purpura starting at the entry point of infection. Patients develop tissue necrosis,
bullae formation, and palpable crepitus resulting from bacterial gas production. Necrotizing fasciitis is life-threatening and must be treated aggressively with systemic antibiotic therapy and operative debridement of the affected
areas.
educational_objective:
Necrotizing fasciitis may be caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcal spp., Clostridium spp., or Bacteroides spp. infection following cellulitis, trauma, or invasive procedure. It is characterized by tissue
necrosis, may be associated with sepsis, and has a high morbidity and mortality. All patients with suspected necrotizing fasciitis must be aggressively treated with operative tissue debridement and empiric intravenous antibiotics.
During tissue debridement, tissue cultures should be obtained to inform subsequent targeted antibiotic therapy.

vignette:
30. One week after undergoing splenectomy for injuries sustained in a motorcycle collision, a 19-year-old man has a platelet count of 1,250,000/mm3. Examination shows normal healing wounds. Which of the following is the

most appropriate measure to prevent thrombotic events in this patient?

choices.text: Placement of a vena cava filter

correct_explanation:
This patient with significant thrombocytosis following a splenectomy likely has reactive thrombocytosis. Reactive thrombocytosis is the most common cause of thrombocytosis, and common etiologies include trauma, infection,
surgery, and malignancy. The spleen is the primary site of platelet destruction and plays a major role in platelet regulation. Post-splenectomy thrombocytosis is common, and platelet counts typically peak 1 to 3 weeks after surgery
before returning to normal in the following weeks to months. If severe, thrombocytosis may lead to thrombotic events such as myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and mesenteric ischemia due to increased platelet
aggregation. Patients with severe thrombocytosis should be started on an antiplatelet agent, such as aspirin, to prevent these complications.
educational_objective:
Reactive thrombocytosis occurs commonly after splenectomy, and platelet counts typically peak in the first 1 to 3 weeks after surgery. Extreme thrombocytosis may lead to thrombotic events due to increased
platelet aggregation, and this can be prevented by taking an antiplatelet agent.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
