a cross but not a square. She can count three objects correctly. She is able to stand, but not hop, on one foot. She speaks in five-word sentences. During the examination, she shares a toy with her sibling. Which of the
following is the most accurate assessment of her development?
Fine Motor Gross Motor Language Social
Development Development Development Development
correct_explanation:
Developmental milestones are an important aspect of the well-child examination; they are categorized into fine motor, gross motor, social development, and language findings. Expected fine motor findings at age 3 years include
drawing a circle, with the ability to copy a cross or draw a square by age

vignette: TBD
TBD

educational_objective:
Developmental milestones are categorized into fine motor, gross motor, social development, and language findings. In a 3-year-old child, expected abilities include the ability to ride a tricycle or ascend
stairs with alternating legs, use two- to three-word sentences or use greater than 300 words, and draw a circle.

vignette:
25. A study is conducted to assess whether a new drug used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus is associated with an increased risk for developing cancer. In the study, a meta-analysis is performed of six small clinical trials of the

new drug, and the relative risk for cancer development is determined. The results of the meta-analysis are shown in the graph. Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from these data?

choices.text: The drug is associated with a decreased cancer risk, but the result is not significant
The drug is associated with an increased cancer risk, but the result is not significant
The drug is significantly associated with an increased cancer risk
The association between the drug and cancer risk cannot be determined from the data provided

correct_explanation:
While randomized controlled trials form the gold standard of medical research and generate more powerful evidence than other forms of observational or descriptive studies, they remain susceptible to error. Acommon form of error
results from limitations in the number of study participants, which in turn limits statistical power, the ability of the study to detect a difference between groups if one exists. When the power of a study is increased, the incidence of a
type Il error decreases. A type II error occurs when a study demonstrates no difference between the null and alternative hypotheses, when in fact, a difference exists. The type II error rate is calculated by subtracting the power from
100%. A meta-analysis is a form of study in which statistical analysis is performed to combine the results of multiple studies addressing the same question. Meta-analysis is useful for overcoming limitations of the constituent
studies. By pooling the results of multiple studies, meta-analyses reduce the risk of type II error because of the smaller sample sizes within each constituent randomized controlled trial. However, meta-analyses are susceptible to
their own errors, primarily related to inclusion criteria, statistical methods, and the errors of constituent studies. The meta-analysis in this example provides a forest plot, which is a commonly used method of summarizing the results
of multiple studies in a single graphical representation. The dot and diamond shapes in the diagram represent measures of the effect observed in each individual study, bounded by confidence intervals represented as horizontal
lines. A vertical line centered on the relative risk of 1.0 may or may not be shown in the center of the forest plot representing the line of null effect. If the confidence interval crosses or includes the line of null effect, it implies that the
observed result was not statistically significant and may include the null value. In this example, the meta-analysis observed results that demonstrated a decreased relative risk for cancer in patients treated with the new drug. The
result is statistically significant and unlikely to be due to chance because the confidence interval of the combined result does not include 1.0.
educational_objective:
A meta-analysis is a form of study in which statistical analysis is performed to combine the results of multiple studies addressing the same question. Meta-analysis is useful for overcoming limitations of the
constituent studies. By pooling the results of multiple studies, meta-analyses reduce the risk of type II error due to the smaller sample sizes within each constituent randomized controlled trial. A vertical line centered on the relative
risk of 1.0 may or may not be shown in the center of the forest plot representing the line of null effect. A result is statistically significant and unlikely due to chance when its confidence intervals do not include 1.0 or the line of null
effect.

vignette:
27. A19-year-old woman comes to the office 2 days after a home urine pregnancy test was positive. She has a 2-week history of mild pelvic cramping and frequent urination. She has not had vaginal bleeding. She thinks her

last menstrual period was 7 or 8 weeks ago. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals and lasted 7 days. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with three male

partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 12-week gestation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of

the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Wet mount preparation of vaginal discharge

correct_explanation:
The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is transvaginal ultrasonography to confirm this patient's pregnancy. Pregnancy is suspected when there is a missed or delayed menstrual period, especially in patients who report
inconsistent use of contraception. B-hCG is produced by the placenta, is undetectable in the serum of nonpregnant patients, and doubles approximately every 48 hours during an early normal pregnancy. B-hCG is detected with
urine and serum pregnancy tests, while ultrasonography can be used to confirm an intrauterine pregnancy. In a normal pregnancy, an intrauterine gestational sac should be visible by 5 weeks gestational age on transvaginal
ultrasonography, or when the B-hCG concentration exceeds 1000 to 2000 mIU/mL. Additional symptoms in early pregnancy include the mild abdominal cramping and urinary frequency seen in this patient, as well as nausea, breast
tenderness, and fatigue. Dating a pregnancy based on patient history is often unreliable, as mild vaginal bleeding or spotting that is normal early in pregnancy can be mistaken for menstruation. Thus, ultrasonography is not only
used to confirm an intrauterine pregnancy but also to establish the gestational age of the fetus.
educational_objective:
Pregnancy is suspected when there is a missed or delayed menstrual period, especially in patients who report inconsistent use of contraception. In addition to amenorrhea, symptoms can include a small
amount of vaginal bleeding or spotting, mild abdominal cramping, urinary frequency, breast tenderness, nausea, and fatigue. B-hCG is produced by the placenta, and is the basis of serum and urine pregnancy tests.
Ultrasonography is used to confirm pregnancy and to establish the gestational age of the fetus.

vignette:
28. A68-year-old man comes to the physician because of sadness since his wife died 1 month ago. He says he feels lost without her and cries whenever he talks about her. He is reluctant to socialize with his bridge group

because the other members’ spouses are still alive. He still enjoys spending time with his children and grandchildren. He has difficulty falling asleep at night but sleeps his usual 6 to 7 hours without awakening. He also

takes one short nap daily. He has had a decreased appetite because he misses his wife’s cooking, resulting in a 2.3-kg (5-Ib) weight loss. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not drink

alcohol. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 Ib); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he has a sad mood and tearful affect. He says he longs to be

with his wife again but has not had suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Acute uncomplicated grief presents in diverse ways and can include sadness, shock, anguish, guilt, regret, difficulty concentrating, decreased interest in usual activities (eg, playing bridge), preoccupation with thoughts and
memories of the deceased, and neurovegetative symptoms, such as sleep, appetite, and energy disturbances. In some patients, these symptoms can endure for months. However, in uncomplicated grief reactions, the criteria for
major depressive disorder (MDD) are not met. This patient is not experiencing anhedonia (eg, he enjoys visits with his grandchildren) and appears to be functioning in his activities, which makes uncomplicated grief much more
likely than MDD. Management includes reassurance and normalization of his reaction (eg, saying “it is common to feel the way you do”), frequent reassessment for the development of suicidality and psychiatric disorders such as
MDD, and encouraging reconnection with family. In severe cases, the physician can facilitate referral for grief counseling. Acute uncomplicated grief ultimately becomes integrated grief, in which thoughts of the deceased continue to
engender sadness but acute symptoms resolve.
educational_objective:
For patients with acute uncomplicated grief reactions, the physician should normalize their reaction and schedule regular appointments to monitor the patient for suicidal ideation and psychiatric disorders,
such as major depressive disorder. Uncomplicated grief can include sadness, guilt, difficulty concentrating, preoccupation with thoughts and memories of the deceased, and neurovegetative symptoms, such as sleep, appetite, and
energy disturbances, without meeting the criteria for major depressive disorder. In severe cases, the physician can facilitate referral for grief counseling.

vignette:
29. A3-year-old African American boy is brought to the office because of a 3-day history of moderate pain of his chest, back, and legs. He receives no medications. He appears ill and is in moderate distress. On cardiac

examination, a grade 2/6, systolic ejection murmur is heard best along the left sternal border. Examination of the lower extremities shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 6.6 g/dL (N=11.5—14.5), and

hematocrit is 22% (N=33%—43%). A blood smear is shown. Serum hemoglobin electrophoresis is most likely to show which of the following findings in this patient?
correct_explanation:
Patients with sickle cell disease may develop pain secondary to vaso-occlusive events in nearly any part of the body. Pediatric patients tend to present with abdominal pain and dactylitis, while older patients may develop diffuse
pain in the arms and the legs. Polymerization of mutant hemoglobin is characteristic of the pathogenesis of sickle cell disease. Sickle cell disease is caused by mutations in globin genes that result in an abnormal hemoglobin S,
which polymerizes in the setting of hypoxia or illness and causes sickling of erythrocytes. Patients with sickle cell disease have a significant decrease or complete absence of hemoglobin A. Treatment should focus on aggressive
management of pain with the use of opiate and nonopiate medications and reversing any causes that may have triggered the pain crisis. The mainstay of therapy includes the administration of intravenous fluids to treat
hypovolemia, in addition to judicious use of supplemental oxygen and aggressive control of pain. Most patients respond well to these conservative measures, although some may develop additional complications such as acute
chest syndrome that require more aggressive treatment. Patients with frequent pain episodes should be considered for the use of hydroxyurea.
educational_objective:
Sickle cell disease is caused by mutations in globin genes that result in an abnormal hemoglobin S, which polymerizes in the setting of hypoxia and causes sickling of erythrocytes. These patients have
reduced or absent concentrations of hemoglobin A. This can result in sickle cell pain crisis, splenomegaly, and acute chest syndrome.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
30. A previously healthy 11-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of cough and difficulty breathing for 2 hours. His mother says that he has been irritable and has had little to eat or drink

since the onset of symptoms. He is agitated and difficult to examine. He has a deep, barking cough. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg. Mild

inspiratory stridor is heard. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of a cough syrup containing dextromethorphan

correct_explanation:
Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is an infection that occurs most commonly in children, presenting with fever, rhinorrhea, a barking cough, and inspiratory stridor. Stridor refers to a high-pitched sound caused by turbulent airflow
through obstructed or narrowed upper airway structures, such as the pharynx, larynx, or trachea. Croup is typically mild and self-limited, but severe inflammation of the upper airway can result in life-threatening airway obstruction. It
can be caused by viral or bacterial infections, most commonly the parainfluenza virus. Physical examination may disclose signs of respiratory distress, such as substernal or subcostal retractions. Laboratory studies commonly show
leukocytosis, and plain x-rays may show subglottic narrowing of the airway (steeple sign). Treatment options include supplemental oxygen, inhaled cool mist humidified air, nebulized racemic epinephrine, and systemic
corticosteroids. When airway obstruction is persistent and progressive or if the patient develops signs of respiratory failure and cyanosis, endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required. Care should be taken to
keep children calm in such a situation, as laryngospasm may be an inciting event to airway obstruction.
educational_objective:
Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is an infection that occurs most commonly in children, presenting with fever, rhinorrhea, a barking cough, and inspiratory stridor. Croup is generally self-limiting but can be
life-threatening in severe cases. Treatment options include oxygen therapy, inhaled cool mist humidified air, inhaled racemic epinephrine, systemic corticosteroids, and intubation if respiratory distress presents.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
31. A 32-year-old woman comes to the office 2 days after undergoing CT scan of the abdomen because of a 1-month history of recurrent urinary tract infections and intermittent left flank pain. Three days ago, she completed a

course of antibiotic therapy for her most recent urinary tract infection. Today, she feels well. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination discloses no

abnormalities. CT scan of the abdomen shows normal urogenital anatomy and no renal calculi, but an annular pancreas is noted. Which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this CT scan finding?
correct_explanation:
An annular pancreas is a relatively rare congenital abnormality. It is thought to develop from incomplete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development, which leads to pancreatic tissues surrounding the descending
portion of the duodenum. The majority of patients with an annular pancreas are asymptomatic. When symptomatic, the most common symptoms include abdominal pain, nonbilious vomiting, nausea, or feeding intolerance. These
symptoms can develop in the neonatal period or during adulthood, commonly between the ages of 20 to 50 years. Severe and more uncommon symptoms can include chronic pancreatitis, peptic ulcer development, and in rare
cases, biliary obstruction causing jaundice. An annular pancreas can be identified on CT scan or MRI of the abdomen. In cases of symptomatic annular pancreas, an operation can relieve potential duodenal or gastric outlet
obstructions. A benign course is the most likely expected outcome in an asymptomatic patient incidentally found to have an annular pancreas on imaging.
educational_objective:
Annular pancreas is a relatively rare congenital abnormality developed from incomplete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development. The majority of patients with an annular pancreas are
asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients can present with abdominal pain, nonbilious vomiting, nausea, food avoidance, and less commonly, chronic pancreatitis, peptic ulcer disease, or biliary obstruction. A benign course can be
expected in a patient who has been

vignette:
32. A 52-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer comes to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of severe left arm pain. She rates her pain as a 9 on a 10-point scale. Her only medication is

hydrocodone-acetaminophen (hydrocodone 5 mg/acetaminophen 500 mg, two tablets every 6 hours). Three years ago, she had upper gastrointestinal bleeding secondary to a gastric ulcer. Five years ago, she had a

bilateral mastectomy. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 44 kg (96 Ib); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. Examination

shows temporal wasting, protruding ribs, and well-healed bilateral mastectomy scars. There is guarding of the left upper extremity. An x-ray shows a pathologic fracture of the left proximal humerus. Which of the following is

the most appropriate next step in pain management?

choices.text: Add oral gabapentin to the medication regimen
Add oral ketorolac to the medication regimen

correct_explanation:
Pain caused by cancer is associated with significant limitations in functional status and quality of life. Opioids are potent analgesics that reduce the sensation of pain via delta, kappa, and particularly mu opioid receptor agonism
throughout the central and peripheral nervous systems. Despite their potential for opioid use disorder and overdose death, opioid agonists are useful for the management of pain in certain situations, such as in the perioperative
period, following trauma, and in the setting of cancer, which can produce severe, chronic pain that is often intractable to other modalities. The World Health Organization has outlined a framework, known as the analgesic ladder, to
guide escalating pain management strategies in cancer patients. Within this framework, initial management of mild pain is with nonopioid medications and adjuvant therapies. Moderate pain is treated with oral opioids, typically
administered on a fixed, scheduled dose. More severe pain is managed by increasing the dosage or frequency of oral opioids, or by switching to intravenous opioids. Opioid dosage often needs to be increased due to progression of
metastatic disease, as well as the development of opioid tolerance. The final step within the analgesic ladder involves invasive or minimally invasive procedures to achieve analgesia, such as nerve blocks, ablative procedures, or
intrathecal or epidural analgesia. This patient presents with an acute fracture of the left humerus, likely due to metastatic disease. This patient is already taking a high dose of scheduled hydrocodone-acetaminophen for her body
weight, and therefore switching to intravenous morphine is the most appropriate next step in pain management. Morphine is an opioid analgesic used to manage moderate-to-severe pain and can be administered orally or
intravenously. It is a potent analgesic that would be effective in treating pain in this patient who presents with an acute fracture.
educational_objective:
Pain caused by cancer is associated with significant limitations in functional status and quality of life. The World Health Organization has outlined a framework, known as the analgesic ladder, to guide
escalating pain management strategies in cancer patients. Moderate cancer pain is best treated with oral opioids on a fixed, scheduled dose. Severe pain that is refractory to high-dose oral opioids can often be managed acutely
with intravenous opioids. Morphine is an opioid analgesic used to manage moderate-to-severe pain and can be administered orally or intravenously. It is a potent analgesic that would be effective in treating pain in this patient who
presents with an acute fracture.

vignette:
33. A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 12 months and has been unable to conceive during this time. Her son was born by spontaneous vaginal
delivery 18 months ago, and she breast-fed him for 6 months. One month after delivery, she had profuse vaginal bleeding and underwent emergency dilatation and curettage for retained placental fragments. She has not
used any contraception since her delivery and currently takes no medications. She and her husband have sexual intercourse twice weekly. Analysis of the husband's semen has shown no abnormalities. The patient's vital
signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows a normal cervix, uterus, and adnexa. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 42%
Leukocyte count 8800/mm?
Serum
Thyroid-stimulating hormone 1.1 pU/mL
Follicle-stimulating hormone 10 mIU/mL
Luteinizing hormone 12 mlU/mL
Pelvic ultrasonography shows normal ovaries, no free fluid in the pelvis, and no distinct endometrial stripe. Treatment with oral progesterone for 10 days produces no uterine bleeding. Which of the following is the most
appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
The most appropriate next step in management is hysteroscopy. Uterine synechiae are fibrous adhesions that form within the uterine cavity as a sequela of injury to the endometrium. This condition is also known as Asherman
syndrome. Precipitants include endometrial trauma (in this case, curettage) and infections. The typical presentation includes infertility, spontaneous abortions, and menstrual irregularities, such as dysmenorrhea or amenorrhea.
Adhesions generally result from injury involving the endometrial basal layer, which leads to the formation of fibrous connective tissue bands that often bridge the endometrial cavity. Diagnosis is suspected based on the clinical
history of a precipitating factor (eg, prior curettage) plus consistent symptoms or complications. Laboratory studies will not show hormonal abnormalities in these patients. A progesterone challenge test may aid in the diagnosis, in
which the patient will have no withdrawal bleeding as a result of the endometrial damage. Ultrasonography may also be used, which would fail to show a distinct endometrial stripe, as it did in this patient, and may show the
synechiae. However, the diagnosis is confirmed by hysteroscopy, which allows direct visualization of the endometrium. Treatment includes removal of the adhesions to restore appropriate form and function of the endometrial cavity.
educational_objective:
Recurrent infections or endometrial trauma (eg, dilatation and curettage) can lead to damage of the endometrial basal layer, with consequent formation of fibrous connective tissue bands that often bridge the
endometrial cavity. These uterine synechiae present with infertility and menstrual irregularities, such as dysmenorrhea or amenorrhea. A progesterone challenge test will be negative in these patients. The diagnosis is confirmed with
hysteroscopy, and treatment includes surgical removal of the adhesions.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
34. A previously healthy 7-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a 1-week history of diffuse, mild abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. He has a constant urge to pass stools despite passing 10 small, bloody stools
daily. During this time, he has had decreased oral intake. He last urinated 12 hours ago. He has not had fever or vomiting. No other family members are ill. The patient appears tired. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F),
pulse is 120/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mm Hg. Examination shows pallor and tacky mucous membranes. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard. The
abdomen is soft and diffusely tender to palpation; there is no guarding or rebound. Examination of the perianal area shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 7 g/dL (N=11.5-14.5)
Hematocrit 21% (N=33%-43%)
Leukocyte count 12,000/mm3
Platelet count 14,000/mm?
Serum
Na* 147 mEd/L
K+ 4.2 mEq/L
Cl- 118 mEq/L
HCO, 14 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 72 mg/dL
Creatinine 8.2 mg/dL (N=0.22-0.59)
Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
correct_explanation:
Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) most likely explains this patient’s acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. HUS is typically seen in children and is often caused by infection with Shiga
toxin-producing Escherichia coli (0157:H7), which is usually accompanied by bloody diarrhea. There are also atypical variants of HUS, which are not preceded by a diarrheal illness and are the result of mutations in the complement
system (eg, mutations of C3 and CD46). Widespread microvascular thrombosis consumes platelets and predisposes circulating erythrocytes to shearing forces as a result of a disrupted vascular lumen. When erythrocytes come
into contact with microvascular clots, they are damaged, resulting in schistocytes, which are apparent on peripheral blood smear as fragmented cells. Thrombosis also occurs in the kidney vasculature due to underlying endothelial
damage, resulting in kidney injury. Differentiating HUS from disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is important and can be done by examining the prothrombin and partial thromboplastin time (normal in HUS and increased in
DIC as a result of clotting factor consumption). Treatment of HUS is supportive, although eculizumab, a human monoclonal IgG antibody against complement protein C5 that prevents formation of the membrane attack complex, has
been used in refractory cases. Antibiotics are avoided as they can result in an increased release of Shiga toxin and worsening clinical deterioration.
educational_objective:
Hemolytic uremic syndrome is most often triggered by infection with Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (0157:H7) although it may also occur as a result of genetic mutations in the complement system. It
typically presents with the triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. Treatment is supportive, although eculizumab, a human monoclonal IgG antibody against complement protein C5
that prevents formation of the membrane attack complex, has been used in refractory cases.

vignette:
35. A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive muscle weakness over the past 6 months. Examination shows a fish-like mouth with a high-arched palate, wasting of distal muscles,

and hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are intact and symmetric. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Glycogen storage disease, type II (Pompe disease)

correct_explanation:
Myotonic dystrophy is a genetic disorder caused by expansion of a trinucleotide repeat, which occurs when a series of three nucleotides in repetition are replicated incorrectly and too many repeats are included in the replicated
product. Myotonic dystrophy has several phenotypes but all are characterized by muscle weakness and myotonia, defined as delayed relaxation following a normal contraction of the muscle. The most frequently affected muscles
include the facial muscles (where muscle weakness can present with a fish-like mouth and high-arched palate), sternocleidomastoid, distal forearm muscles, intrinsic hand muscles, and ankle dorsiflexors. Classic myotonic
dystrophy presents during the second, third, or fourth decades of life with muscle weakness, myotonia, cataracts, frontal balding, cardiac arrhythmias, and hypogonadism. However, symptom onset in the first few years of life is also
common. Life expectancy is slightly reduced for patients with classic myotonic dystrophy, and premature death is most commonly caused by respiratory or cardiac dysfunction.
educational_objective:
Myotonic dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness, myotonia, cataracts, frontal balding, cardiac arrhythmias, and hypogonadism. Myotonic dystrophy has several
phenotypes, but all are characterized by muscle weakness and myotonia (ie, delayed relaxation following a normal contraction of the muscle). Life expectancy is slightly reduced for patients with classic myotonic dystrophy, and
premature death is most commonly caused by respiratory or cardiac dysfunction.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
36. A 77-year-old man comes to the physician for an initial visit. He has a history of gout and surgical repair of a hernia. He has been told that he has a mild cardiac murmur, and he thinks that he had rheumatic fever as a

child. He takes no medications. His pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. A grade 4/6 systolic murmur is heard best at the second right intercostal space; it decreases in intensity

with Valsalva maneuver and with handgrip and increases in intensity when he squats. There is an S,, and a systolic thrill is palpable at the base. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
correct_explanation:
Aortic stenosis is a common disorder of the aortic valve that results from fibrosis and calcification. These changes of the aortic valve are a pathologic consequence of mechanical stresses on the heart valves and result from
repetitive microtrauma from the opening and closing of valve leaflets with associated chronic inflammation. Many people will develop some degree of aortic stenosis over time, but structural abnormalities of the valve, such as a
bicuspid aortic valve, alter the biomechanics of valve opening and closing and increase the likelihood of earlier fibrosis and calcification with consequent stenosis. While many patients may be asymptomatic, those with severe aortic
stenosis may experience fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, diminished exercise tolerance, angina, or syncope with exertion. Cardiac examination will disclose a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the upper
right sternal border with radiation to the carotids, and pulsus parvus et tardus (weak and delayed) may be noted on examination of peripheral pulses. The murmur of aortic stenosis decreases in intensity with increasing afterload
(eg, hand grip) and decreasing preload (eg, Valsalva maneuver), and increases in intensity with increased preload (eg, squatting).
educational_objective:
Aortic stenosis presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that is best heard at the upper right sternal border and radiates to the carotid arteries. It classically occurs secondary to age-related
fibrotic and calcific changes of the valve but can occur earlier in life in cases of bicuspid aortic valve or chronic rheumatic disease.

vignette:
37. A 54-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-day history of increasingly severe pain in her right ear; she rates the pain as a 9 on a 10-point scale. She also has a mild ringing sensation in her right ear. She
adds that this morning, her usual cereal tasted awful to her, and she vomited once. She has no symptoms in her left ear and has not had fever, headache, neck stiffness, or symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection.
Her most recent vaccination was 3 years ago for influenza. She has no history of serious illness, takes no medications, and has no known allergies. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (158 Ib); BMI is 26 kg/m2.
Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Examination of the left pinna and tympanic membrane discloses no abnormalities. Examination of the right
ear shows erythema and edema of exterior auditory canal and pinna; light touch of the right pinna produces pain. The right tympanic membrane cannot be observed because of pain and edema. Cranial nerve testing
discloses a widened right palpebral fissure. The patient has decreased ability to close her right eye, wrinkle her forehead, and smile. Visual acuity and visual field testing disclose no abnormalities. Sensation to light touch
and pinprick is intact over the face. The remainder of the examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following conditions is most likely to develop in this patient during the next 24 hours?
correct_explanation:
Auricular vesicles associated with ear pain, tinnitus, altered taste perception, and facial nerve palsy are suggestive of Ramsey Hunt syndrome. Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also called zoster oticus, results from reactivation of the
varicella zoster virus within the geniculate ganglion. The geniculate ganglion is associated with the facial nerve, but inflammation may spread to the vestibulocochlear nerve nearby. Patients with Ramsay Hunt syndrome develop a
constellation of symptoms including facial nerve palsy, ear pain, hearing abnormalities, vertigo, ipsilateral altered taste perception, and development of vesicles within or on the auricle. The diagnosis may be made clinically.
However, diagnosis can be confirmed with polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing using a swab obtained from vesicular fluid. In patients with suspected Ramsey Hunt syndrome, antiviral drugs including acyclovir or valacyclovir
are recommended, in addition to systemic steroids.
educational_objective:
Ramsey Hunt syndrome is caused by varicella zoster virus reactivation within the geniculate ganglion. Patients who develop Ramsay Hunt syndrome may present with auricular vesigleuiemsienisitleteenctelicialis
altered taste perception, vertigo, and ear pain. Diagnosis can be made based on the clinical constellation of findings or following confirmatory polymerase chain reaction testing of a vesicle showing varicellf “====s=ssss=ss=s="
with suspected Ramsey Hunt syndrome should be treated with antiviral drugs such as acyclovir or valacyclovir, and systemic corticosteroids. —————

vignette:
38. A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by paramedics 30 minutes after she was struck by a car while she was riding her bicycle. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She
is alert and fully oriented. She has moderate left upper abdominal and flank pain. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 88/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air
shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is a 5 x 7-in, tender ecchymosis over the left upper abdominal quadrant and left flank. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the physical examination shows no
abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. After administration of 2 L of lactated Ringer solution, pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 95/70 mm Hg. Transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells
is begun. Thirty minutes later, pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 124/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on an Fio, of 1.0 via nonrebreather face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 100%. CT scan of the abdomen shows a
grade 3 splenic laceration. The patient is admitted to the surgical intensive care unit for nonoperative management. Three hours later, she has progressive difficulty breathing. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is
90/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry now shows an oxygen saturation of 87%. On pulmonary examination, breath sounds and diffuse crackles are heard bilaterally. Heart
sounds are normal. Abdominal examination is unchanged. Chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Acute congestive heart failure caused by myocardial contusion

correct_explanation:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a rare complication of blood product transfusion, but a common cause of death related to transfusion. It commonly presents during or within 6 hours after a transfusion, with
symptoms including fever, cyanosis, hypotension, and hypoxemia. Physical examination may disclose crackles on auscultation of the lungs. Chest x-rays will show new bilateral pulmonary infiltrates unrelated to cardiac
dysfunction. The pathology is thought to be caused by activation of neutrophils in the pulmonary vasculature by antibodies in the transfused product, which leads to the release of cytokines and inflammatory mediators. Risk
factors for its development include patient risk factors, such as tobacco use, fluid overload, shock, and alcohol use disorder. Platelets, plasma, and whole blood carry the greatest risk for causing TRALI. Treatment includes
discontinuation of the transfusion, oxygen supplementation in the form of noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation or intubation, and hemodynamic support.
educational_objective:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury is a rare complication of blood product transfusion that presents with fever, cyanosis, hypotension, hypoxemia, and new bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-rays. It
is caused by activation of neutrophils in the pulmonary vasculature by antibodies in the transfused product, which leads to the release of inflammatory mediators. Treatment includes discontinuation of the transfusion, oxygen
supplementation in the form of noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation or intubation, and hemodynamic support.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
39. A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by paramedics 10 minutes after she was stabbed in the chest with a steak knife by another girl after school. The patient's medical history is unknown. She is

gasping for breath but able to say her name. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on an Fio, of 1.0 by nonrebreather face mask

shows an oxygen saturation of 86%. Examination discloses a 2-cm stab wound to the left of the lower sternum. Jugular venous pressure is 12 cm HO (N=5-9). Breath sounds are equal bilaterally. Heart sounds are

decreased. The abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender. Pulses are decreased in all extremities. Pericardiocentesis yields 30 mL of non-clotting blood. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation and typing and

crossmatching of the patient's blood, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
This patient with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distension after penetrating trauma likely has cardiac tamponade secondary to ventricular injury. Cardiac tamponade is characterized by rapid accumulation of
blood or fluid in the pericardial space that prevents diastolic filling of the cardiac chambers, leading to low cardiac output due to low stroke volume. The speed of accumulation is important in the pathophysiology of tamponade in
that gradual accumulation (eg, in states of malignancy or tuberculosis) permits stretching and expansion of the parietal pericardium without necessarily impairing chamber expansion. In cases of hemodynamic instability when the
pretest probability of the condition is high, the pericardial space should be decompressed without delay. This is accomplished via pericardiocentesis, in which a large needle or angiocatheter is inserted into the pericardial space via
a subxiphoid or parasternal approach to evacuate the fluid or blood and permit chamber expansion. Echocardiography permits visualization of the heart and its chambers, and in cases of tamponade, will show a pericardial effusion
of variable size, with right ventricular collapse during diastole. In general, the patient in this case may receive bedside emergency echocardiography while preparing for pericardiocentesis, but imaging should not delay intervention
in an unstable patient (as in this case). After initial stabilization with pericardiocentesis, the patient should be emergently taken to the operating room for open sternotomy or thoracotomy and definitive repair of any cardiac defects.
educational_objective:
Cardiac tamponade classically presents with hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds. When it occurs in the setting of penetrating trauma, immediate stabilization is with
pericardiocentesis, followed by sternotomy or thoracotomy and definitive repair of any cardiac defects. This should not be delayed by obtaining imaging.

vignette:
40. A68-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine examination. She says she has felt well. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications are hydrochlorothiazide,

atorvastatin, and insulin. Pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/60 mm Hg. Physical examination discloses a 2-cm mass in the right groin below the inguinal ligament; the mass is mildly tender

to palpation and does not reduce with attempts at manual reduction. The mass is not fluctuant. The patient says she has noticed this abnormality during the past several weeks but has not been bothered by it. The

remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Fasting serum glucose concentration obtained in preparation for today's visit is within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate

recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Reevaluation in the office if symptoms develop

correct_explanation:
Femoral hernias occur much less frequently than inguinal hernias. In general, hernias occur secondary to weakness in the muscle and connective tissue of the anterior abdominal wall. Hernia contents can include preperitoneal fat
or may contain intra-abdominal contents, such as small bowel, omentum, peritoneum, or large bowel. Femoral hernias occur in the femoral canal and are often identified as a bulge below the inguinal ligament. Many hernias are
easily reducible and asymptomatic. However, if the hernia contents become incarcerated within the hernia sac or if strangulation occurs impeding blood supply, an operative emergency arises. Femoral hernias have the highest rate
of strangulation or incarceration. A strangulated hernia presents with severe pain in the hernia site, often with overlying reactive erythema, fever, and a tender, irreducible mass on examination. It is recommended that femoral
hernias be repaired operatively rather than after watchful waiting. In this case, elective operative repair within the next week is the most appropriate recommendation because of the high frequency of femoral hernias becoming
incarcerated.
educational_objective:
Femoral hernias occur much less frequently than inguinal hernias but come with a higher rate of incarceration or strangulation. Femoral hernias develop in the femoral canal and are often identified as a bulge
below the inguinal ligament. It is recommended that femoral hernias be treated with operative management because of their high rate of strangulation and incarceration.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
41. An 18-year-old woman comes to the physician to request a prescription for an oral contraceptive. She has been sexually active since the age of 17 years and has never used contraception. Menarche was at the age of

12 years. Menses occur at regular 29-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She has received all appropriate childhood immunizations but none since the age of 6 years. She has smoked one pack of

cigarettes daily for 1 year. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. In addition to recommending condom use by her partners, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in

management?

choices.text: Inform the patient's parents about her request
Refuse to prescribe an oral contraceptive until she stops smoking

correct_explanation:
Many methods of contraception exist, including temporary and permanent options, hormonal and nonhormonal devices, oral medications, injections, implants, and ovulation tracking. The most appropriate contraceptive method is
dependent on the patient and their goals of care. Counseling regarding contraceptive options should determine if the patient wants long-term or temporary contraception, whether they are able to be compliant with medication every
day, their menstrual history, and any comorbidities that may make some options contraindicated. Oral contraceptives are a temporary form of birth control that must be taken every day. They most commonly include a combination of
ethinyl estradiol and progestin, although progestin-only options are available. Oral contraceptives work to prevent pregnancy by thickening the cervical mucus, thinning the endometrial lining, and decreasing ovulation. While very
effective in preventing pregnancy when taken as instructed, there are important contraindications to prevent cardiovascular morbidity and venous thromboembolism. For example, oral contraceptives are contraindicated for patients
who are age 35 years or older and smoke at least 15 cigarettes daily, although they are not contraindicated for younger patients who smoke. They are also contraindicated for patients with increased risk for cardiovascular events
(eg, severe hypertension, ischemic heart disease, valvular disease, diabetes mellitus with end-organ damage), history of stroke or other thromboembolism, cirrhosis, migraine with aura, and breast malignancy with estrogen or
progesterone receptor positivity, none of which is present in this case. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to prescribe an oral contraceptive.
educational_objective:
Many methods of contraception exist, and counseling regarding the options should determine if the patient wants long-term or temporary contraception, whether they are able to be compliant with medication
every day, their menstrual history, and any comorbidities that may make some options contraindicated. Oral contraceptives are very effective when taken as directed. They are contraindicated in patients over age 35 years who
smoke and in those who are at increased risk for cardiovascular events or stroke. Neither a pelvic examination nor a speculum examination is necessary to perform prior to prescribing oral contraceptives.

vignette:
42. A77-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He had bronchitis 3 years ago treated with amoxicillin and prednisone. He has not been
hospitalized during the past 3 years. He has a history of shortness of breath and cough but says these symptoms have subsided since he quit smoking cigarettes 5 years ago. His only medication is inhaled ipratropium.
Pulmonary function testing shows an FVC of 85% of predicted and FEV, of 75% of predicted. The patient says he heard about a new inhaled medication, called BreatheEZ, for management of COPD and asks if he would
benefit from this medication. The physician recalls a recent randomized controlled trial evaluating the efficacy of BreatheEZ in 7500 patients with COPD. Patients were randomized to receive BreatheEZ or placebo and
observed for 4 years. Data show:
BreatheEZ Placebo
Age, years + SD 65 + 7.2 65+ 7.4
FVC, % of predicted 64 66
FEV, % of predicted 31 30
Current smoker, % of patients 54 50
Former smoker, % of patients 46 50
Number of COPD exacerbations during 12 months prior 3 3
to study
Medications at baseline (% of patients)
Inhaled corticosteroid 15 77
Long-acting B-adrenergic agonist 69 67
Inhaled anticholinergic 50 54
Bronchodilator 24 22
Oral corticosteroid 8 9
23 Medications 40 43
Analysis shows a mortality rate of 12.2% for the patients receiving BreatheEZ and 15.4% for patients receiving placebo (hazard ratio of 0.79, 95% confidence interval of 0.63—0.98). Based on these data, which of the
following is the most appropriate action regarding BreatheEZ for this patient?

choices.text: Do not prescribe BreatheEZ because the medication is not efficacious
Do not prescribe BreatheEZ because the results are invalid as a result of differences between the placebo group and the treatment group
Do not prescribe BreatheEZ because the results are relevant only for younger patients
Do not prescribe BreatheEZ because the medication is not efficacious
Do not prescribe BreatheEZ because the results are invalid as a result of differences between the placebo group and the treatment group
Do not prescribe BreatheEZ because the results are relevant only for younger patients

correct_explanation:
To correctly apply the findings of a study, the persons to whom the study is applicable must be considered. Generalizability refers to the ability to apply the results of a study conducted with a sample population to the population at
large and reflects the external validity of the study. Typically, the results of a study are generalizable to a similar patient or population as those included in the study and with a similar clinical condition. In this scenario, a randomized,
placebo-controlled trial has evaluated the efficacy of BreatheEZ in patients with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) based on their spirometric values, moderate-to-severe exacerbation history, and multiple
medications The patient described in this case has much milder COPD as shown by pulmonary function testing and has minimal symptoms that are well-controlled on ipratropium. This patient is therefore dissimilar from those
included in the study. The reduced mortality rate observed in the study is statistically significant, but these results can only be generalized to patients with a similar disease status and severity, and therefore, do not apply to this
individual patient.
educational_objective:
Generalizability refers to the ability to apply the results of a study conducted with a sample population to the population at large and reflects the external validity of the study. Typically, the results of a study are
generalizable to a similar patient or population as those included in the study, and with a similar clinical condition. The patient in this scenario has mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), whereas the drug was studied
in patients with severe COPD. The study results are therefore not applicable to this patient.

vignette:
43. A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of dryness of her mouth. During this time, she often has consumed liquids to aid in swallowing food. She has not had a sore throat or fever. She
has not sustained head or neck trauma. She has rheumatoid arthritis. Her medications are low-dose prednisone and ibuprofen. Vital signs are within normal limits. Skin turgor is normal. Examination shows erythematous,
dry oral mucosa and atrophy of the filiform papillae on the dorsum of the tongue. Results of serum anti-Ro and anti-La antibody assays are positive. The patient is given water to drink. Which of the following is the most
appropriate pharmacotherapy?
correct_explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with Sjégren syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by chronic lymphocytic inflammation and destruction of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The presentation typically includes
xerophthalmia (dry eyes), xerostomia (dry mouth), and painless, bilateral parotid gland enlargement. Primary Sj6gren syndrome occurs in the absence of a concurrent rheumatologic disease, while secondary Sjogren syndrome
occurs in the setting of another rheumatologic disease such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, or scleroderma. The diagnosis is clinical and may be supported by a variety of laboratory studies, although no
single study is diagnostic. Autoantibodies against Ro (SSA) and La (SSB) (both RNA binding nuclear proteins) are present in most patients. Many patients are also positive for rheumatoid factor. Schirmer testing is performed by
placing a paper measuring strip in the lower fornix of the eyelid and measuring tear production over 5 minutes. Production of less than 5 mm of tears is considered abnormal and consistent with Sjogren syndrome. Salivary gland
biopsy is not necessary for the diagnosis, but classically shows foci of CD4+ lymphocytic aggregates and replacement of normal glandular architecture with lymphocytes. Treatment is with topical eye lubrication, as well as oral
pilocarpine. Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist that increases secretion of tears and saliva. Adverse effects of pilocarpine may include sweating, headache, dizziness, nausea, and diarrhea.
educational_objective:
Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by chronic lymphocytic inflammation and destruction of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The presentation typically includes xerophthalmia (dry
eyes), xerostomia (dry mouth), and painless, bilateral parotid gland enlargement. Treatment is with topical eye lubrication, as well as oral pilocarpine. Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist that increases secretion of tears and saliva.

vignette: TBD

3. She has a 10-year history of cocaine use but has not used cocaine during the past 12 months. She
used cocaine intermittently during her first pregnancy. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 6 months ago. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall. She weighed 49 kg (108 Ib) prior to her pregnancy; BMI was
18 kg/m2. She has had a 1.8-kg (4-Ib) weight gain during her pregnancy. Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 12-week gestation. The fetal heart rate is reassuring. This patient is at greatest risk for which
of the following complications during pregnancy?
correct_explanation:
This patient with a history of preterm labor and cervical surgery is at greatest risk for preterm delivery with this pregnancy. Preterm labor occurs after 20 and prior to 37 weeks of gestation with regular uterine contractions and
accompanied cervical change. The diagnosis is often based on history and physical examination, although ancillary tests such as measurement of cervicovaginal fetal fibronectin concentrations may be done to aid in evaluation.
Risk factors for its occurrence include a personal history of preterm delivery, previous cervical surgery or dilatation and curettage, a shortened cervix, extremes of age, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, multiple gestations, tobacco
use, and maternal malnutrition, among numerous other factors. In patients at high risk for preterm labor, prophylaxis is often accomplished with intravaginal progesterone supplementation in addition to treating any underlying risk
factors. If premature labor does occur, the degree of fetal morbidity and mortality is increased the earlier the preterm labor occurs. For this reason, it is usually treated with tocolytic therapy, hydration, and bed rest. Corticosteroids
are also given to promote fetal lung maturity if the gestational age is less than 34 weeks, and magnesium is given for neuroprotection if the gestational age is less than 32 weeks.
educational_objective: Preterm labor occurs after 20 and prior to 37 weeks of gestation with regular uterine contractions and accompanied cervical change. Risk factors include a personal history of preterm delivery,

vignette:
45. A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of changes in behavior during the past 6 months. Her parents say that during this time she has been hostile and unpleasant, frequently crying and
screaming about being treated unfairly no matter what they do. She also has alienated her friends. Her grades have declined from mostly B’s to C’s and D’s, and she has stopped participating in sports. The patient says
she is tired and does not sleep; her parents report she is sleeping more than usual. They add that she has been eating more, resulting in a 10-kg (22-Ib) weight gain, which bothers her. They say she was a “worrier” when
she was younger, but her worrying has decreased during the years. The patient is at the 45th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no
abnormalities. On mental status examination, she describes her mood as “okay” but appears dysphoric and has an irritable affect. She looks at her hands and responds slowly using monosyllabic words. She says, “I don’t
think I’m depressed. I’m bored and angry because no one likes me. | used to want to be an actress, but nothing ever works out for me. | could do it if my parents would let me.” Her thought process is goal directed. She
says that adults, especially her parents, do not understand her and make unreasonable demands. There is no evidence of psychosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
This patient meets criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD). Diagnostic criteria include 2 or more weeks of at least five of the following symptoms: depressed mood, anhedonia, guilt or worthlessness, difficulty concentrating,
psychomotor delay, suicidal thoughts, and/or neurovegetative symptoms (eg, decreased energy, sleep disturbance, appetite disturbance leading to weight changes). In children and adolescents, the diagnostic criteria allow for an
irritable mood to be present instead of a depressed mood. Depressed children and adolescents commonly externalize their MDD by acting out toward authority figures, as in this case. By definition, MDD symptoms disrupt everyday
functioning, including relationships, as in this case. Negative thoughts (eg, “nothing ever works out for me”) are common. Treatment of MDD should include psychotherapy and antidepressant pharmacotherapy. Selective serotonin
reuptake inhibitors, such as sertraline, are first-line treatments because of their effectiveness and benign adverse effect profiles.
educational_objective:
Major depressive disorder includes 2 or more weeks of five of the following symptoms: depressed or irritable mood, anhedonia, guilt or worthlessness, difficulty concentrating, psychomotor delay, suicidal
thoughts, and/or neurovegetative symptoms (eg, decreased energy, sleep disturbance, appetite disturbance). Children and adolescents commonly externalize their irritability to authority figures. Selective serotonin reuptake
inhibitors, such as sertraline, are first-line treatments because of their effectiveness and benign adverse effect profiles.

vignette:
47. A previously healthy 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-day history of fever. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is
95/60 mm Hg. Examination shows cracked, red lips and palmar erythema and edema. Cervical lymph nodes are enlarged. There is pharyngeal erythema and bilateral conjunctivitis without injection adjacent to the corneal
limbus. Rapid streptococcal testing is negative. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 45%
Leukocyte count 10,500/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 55%
Lymphocytes 40%
Monocytes 5%
Platelet count 300,000/mm?
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 35 mm/h
In addition to intravenous immune globulin, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Oral ibuprofen every 6 hours as needed to bring fever below 38.1°C (100.6°F)
8-Week course of daily, low-dose acetaminophen therapy

correct_explanation:
Kawasaki disease, also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome, is a multisystem vasculitic disease in children characterized by fever for at least 5 days, a polymorphous rash, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis,
erythema affecting the mucous membranes with dry, cracked lips, lymphadenopathy, and erythema and edema of the hands and feet. It is the most common of the childhood vasculitides and is a common cause of pediatric heart
disease. Laboratory studies may show thrombocytosis and increased ESR. Incomplete Kawasaki disease refers to the presence of some, but not all, of the diagnostic criteria, along with laboratory results showing thrombocytosis,
increased inflammatory markers, and/or sterile pyuria. Complications of Kawasaki disease include coronary artery aneurysms, and if untreated, can lead to aneurysmal expansion, rupture, or myocardial infarction. Therefore,
children suspected of having Kawasaki disease require immediate evaluation with ECG and echocardiography, treatment, and monitoring for progression or complications. Treatment of Kawasaki disease involves high-dose aspirin
and intravenous immunoglobulin; this is the only widely accepted indication for aspirin use in febrile children because of the risk for Reye syndrome.
educational_objective:
Kawasaki disease, also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome, is a multisystem vasculitic disease in children characterized by fever for at least 5 days, a polymorphous rash, bilateral nonexudative
conjunctivitis, erythema affecting the mucous membranes with dry, cracked lips, lymphadenopathy, and erythema and edema of the hands and feet. Treatment of Kawasaki disease involves high-dose aspirin and intravenous
immunoglobulin.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
48. A 35-year-old man, who works as an orthopaedic surgeon, comes to the office because of a 1-day history of severe low back pain after lifting heavy furniture. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications.

He requests a prescription for oxycodone because he is scheduled to give a lecture at a national meeting tomorrow and is worried he will be in "too much pain" to participate without medication. Vital signs are within

normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management by the physician?

choices.text: Obtain an MRI of the spine
Report the patient to the state medical board

correct_explanation:
This patient's subjective report of severe, acute, disabling pain is inconsistent with the absence of objective evidence of severe pain. Common causes of acute low back pain, such as muscle spasm, typically present with physical
examination signs, such as positive straight leg raise testing. Additionally, pain is commonly associated with tachycardia and/or hypertension, which is not seen in this patient. For patients seeking controlled substances (eg, opioids,
benzodiazepines) who demonstrate inconsistencies between subjective reports and objective evidence, the physician should screen the patient for substance use disorder. Substance use disorder is a clinical diagnosis made by the
presence of personal, professional, social, emotional, behavioral, and physical disturbances related to the use of a substance or attempts to reduce intake. Symptoms may be classified as mild, moderate, or severe depending on
the number of domains affected.
educational_objective:
For patients seeking controlled substances (eg, opioids, benzodiazepines) who demonstrate inconsistencies between subjective reports and objective evidence, the physician should screen the patient for
substance use disorder. Substance use disorder is a clinical diagnosis made by the presence of personal, professional, social, emotional, behavioral, and physical disturbances related to the use of a substance or attempts to
reduce intake. Symptoms may be classified as mild, moderate, or severe depending on the number of domains affected.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
49. A37-year-old woman comes to the physician in January for immunizations 6 weeks before beginning her new job as a nurse's aide in a skilled nursing care facility. She has no history of serious illness and takes no

medications. She has no known allergies. Four years ago, she completed the hepatitis B vaccine series and received a tetanus booster. She lives with her husband and two healthy school-aged children. Examination shows

no abnormalities. Which of the following is most appropriate to administer at this visit?

choices.text: No immunizations are indicated at this time

correct_explanation:
Influenza virus vaccination is the most appropriate next step in management for this otherwise healthy 37-year-old patient. The influenza vaccine comes in two forms: an intramuscular inactivated virus vaccine and an intranasal
live-attenuated virus vaccine. In most cases, patients should receive the inactivated form of the vaccine. Each vaccine is redesigned each year to protect against a variety of different influenza strains and should be given yearly,
usually at the beginning of the influenza season (generally September through February in the northern hemisphere). All patients over age 6 months should receive an annual influenza vaccination, particularly those who work in
high-risk settings such as hospitals or nursing care facilities, as in this case. The only contraindication to receiving the intramuscular influenza vaccine is a prior severe allergic reaction to the vaccine or its components.
educational_objective:
The intramuscular inactivated influenza virus vaccine should be given yearly to all patients over age 6 months. Vaccination is particularly important for patients with high occupational risk, including health care
workers. The only contraindication to receiving the intramuscular influenza vaccine is a prior severe allergic reaction to the vaccine or its components.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
50. A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after driving his automobile into a bridge abutment. Paramedics state that at the scene his blood pressure was 100/80 mm Hg, that he was alert, and that the

steering wheel was broken. On examination in the emergency department now, he is stuporous, cyanotic, and hypotensive, and has distended neck veins. Breath sounds are absent bilaterally. The trachea is midline.

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
correct_explanation:
Pneumothorax results from air entering the intrapleural space from either an external (eg, stab wound, open rib fracture, trauma) or internal (eg, ruptured bleb or bronchus, bronchopleural fistula) source. As the air accumulates
within the space, the lung parenchyma becomes compressed, resulting in respiratory distress, decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and in severe cases, tension on the mediastinal structures impeding venous
return resulting in hypotension. Signs of tension pneumothorax include tachycardia, hypotension, hypoxia, jugular venous distension, and tracheal deviation. However, in this patient with bilateral pneumothoraces, tracheal deviation
is not observed. In cases of acute tension pneumothorax, evacuating the accumulated air via needle decompression and aspiration permits expansion of the lung and eliminates tension on the great vessels. Needle decompression
is followed by tube thoracostomy, which prevents re-accumulation and promotes repair of the pleural defect. In a case of bilateral pneumothoraces, respiratory failure will occur imminently, especially once closed pneumothoraces
are converted to open pneumothoraces during needle decompression. Eliminating a pressure gradient across the thoracic wall requires the immediate need for tube thoracostomy and negative pressure, otherwise ventilatory failure
and respiratory arrest will rapidly ensue.
educational_objective:
Pneumothorax occurs when air can enter the pleural space but is prevented from exiting. This leads to an increasing amount of air trapped in the pleural space with subsequent collapse of the lung
parenchyma and mass effect on the mediastinum. Management involves needle decompression (in cases of tension physiology) followed by tube thoracostomy.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
1. A62-year-old man with large cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fatigue, headache, dizziness, and facial flushing that is exacerbated by bending forward. His
only medication is omeprazole. On arrival, he appears slightly cyanotic. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows brawny edema
of the neck and face. The veins over the anterior chest and shoulders are dilated. Breath sounds are normal. Heart sounds are distant. A CT scan of the chest shows clear progression in the size and distribution of
mediastinal and abdominal lymphadenopathy; the inferior vena cava is posteriorly displaced. Intravenous hydrocortisone therapy is started. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Superior vena cava syndrome (SVCS) is a rare condition that occurs due to the compression of the superior vena cava. Common causes include cancer, blood clots, or inflammation. Symptoms of SVCS include swelling of the face,
neck, and arm, shortness of breath, coughing, hoarseness, and difficulty swallowing. In severe cases, the patient may experience cyanosis, confusion, and loss of consciousness. Diagnosis of SVCS is made through a combination
of physical examination, CT scan or MRI, and serum laboratory studies. Treatment is dependent on the cause of the SVCS. In this patient who has begun to receive intravenous corticosteroids, it is appropriate to begin radiation
therapy to try to shrink the size of the mass to alleviate compression and restore normal venous flow. The prognosis of this condition depends on the cause. Malignant invasion or compression often carries a poor prognosis.
educational_objective:
Superior vena cava syndrome (SVCS) is a rare condition that occurs due to the compression of the superior vena cava, causing obstruction of venous return to the heart. Common causes include cancer,
blood clots, or inflammation. The treatment of SVCS depends on the cause. For patients with SVCS due to mass effect, radiation therapy is an appropriate step to try to minimize compression.

vignette:
2. A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasingly severe right heel pain and swelling since she stepped off balance onto the foot 4 weeks ago; the pain increases with weight-bearing and decreases with
rest. She has systemic lupus erythematosus and chronic renal failure. She receives hemodialysis. Her only medication is hydroxychloroquine. Vital signs are within normal limits. The skin over the lower extremities is intact.
Dorsalis pedis pulses are 1+ bilaterally. The posterior tuberosity of the right calcaneus is tender to palpation. Motor examination shows no abnormalities. There is pes planus bilaterally. Sensation to light touch is intact over
the lower extremities. An x-ray of the right ankle is shown. Serum studies are most likely to show an increased concentration of which of the following in this patient?
correct_explanation:
Chronic kidney failure can develop as a result of a variety of mechanisms, such as genetic factors, infection, autoimmune disease such as lupus, and as a sequela of other diseases, such as hypertension or diabetes mellitus.
General management includes blood pressure control, restriction of fluids and protein, smoking cessation, bicarbonate supplementation for chronic metabolic acidosis, treatment of contributing diseases, and hemodialysis in end-
stage kidney disease. Chronic kidney failure can be complicated by hyperkalemia, volume overload, metabolic acidosis, anemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperparathyroidism with subsequent changes in bone structure, such as
renal osteodystrophy. Hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism, as the injured kidney is unable to appropriately reabsorb calcium and secrete phosphate, causing the parathyroid to
increase its hormone production. Many patients require phosphate binders (such as sevelamer) when undergoing hemodialysis for this reason. In this case, the patient requires hemodialysis, with x-ray of the ankle showing
decreased bone mineralization and cortical irregularity of the posterior calcaneus indicating signs of renal osteodystrophy. She is most likely to have an increased concentration of serum parathyroid hormone in response to
electrolyte abnormalities secondary to end-stage kidney disease.
educational_objective:
Chronic kidney failure can be complicated by hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperparathyroidism with subsequent changes in bone structure, such as renal osteodystrophy. X-rays may show
decreased bone mineralization and cortical irregularity, which are signs of renal osteodystrophy.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
¥

vignette:
3. A72-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine follow-up examination. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and osteoarthritis of the knees. She says that she feels well except
for mild swelling of her feet, which has made her shoes feel tighter. Her medications are lisinopril, naproxen, acetaminophen, and metformin. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 81 kg (178 Ib); BMI is 28 kg/m2. She has
gained 2.3 kg (5 Ib) since her last examination 1 month ago. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 112/62 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no
abnormalities. There is 1+ pitting edema of the ankles. Her hemoglobin A,, is 6.1%, and serum creatinine concentration is 2.1 mg/dL, unchanged from last year. Metformin therapy is discontinued. Which of the following is the
most effective measure to improve this patient's renal function?

choices.text: Add furosemide to the medication regimen
Add hydrochlorothiazide to the medication regimen

correct_explanation:
Patients with chronic kidney disease typically should avoid nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as naproxen. This patient should discontinue naproxen because of her increased serum creatinine concentration. Use
of NSAIDs can precipitate acute kidney injury or progression of chronic kidney disease. NSAIDs such as naproxen are inhibitors of cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, which have a primary role in the synthesis of prostaglandins and
prostacyclins. These molecules modulate pain sensation and thermoregulation, maintain the gastric mucosal barrier, and regulate renal blood flow (RBF). If NSAID use occurs at higher doses, with more potent agents, or over a
prolonged time, acute kidney injury can occur due to deficiency in prostaglandins that would otherwise promote maintenance of RBF. Acute kidney injury sustained in this manner is especially likely if high-risk NSAID use is
accompanied by RBF-limiting pre-renal insults such as volume depletion or in the presence of other nephrotoxins. In a patient with chronic kidney disease, progression of disease can occur. NSAIDs are associated with renal
papillary necrosis, which is the sloughing and necrosis of renal papillae leading to gross hematuria and proteinuria. NSAIDs are also associated with acute interstitial nephritis, which is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to
medications (eg, NSAIDs, diuretics, sulfonamides) and is characterized by a rash, azotemia, sterile pyuria, hematuria, and eosinophiluria. Because of their many negative associations with kidney disease, avoiding NSAIDs is the
best next step for this patient to improve her renal function.
educational_objective:
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs play key roles in the modulation of pain sensation and thermoregulation, the maintenance of the gastric mucosal barrier, and the regulation of renal blood flow. Prolonged
use of NSAIDs can precipitate acute kidney injury or progression of chronic kidney disease.

vignette:
4. A 52-year-old woman who has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of double vision that resolves when she closes either eye. She has no other symptoms. Her
only medication is metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is unable to abduct her left eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is
the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Diabetic mononeuropathy of the abducens nerve is a complication of diabetes that affects abduction of the eye. The underlying mechanism of diabetic mononeuropathy is thought to be related to microvascular complications of
diabetes, particularly of the small vessels supplying the nerves, leading to ischemia and inflammation. This damage can lead to a loss of function of the nerve, resulting in abducens nerve palsy as in this case. Patients will typically
present with complaints of diplopia that improves with closing of either eye. Diagnosis can be made by thorough physical examination, particularly of the eye movements, as well as imaging studies, such as CT scan or MRI.
Treatment includes the use of glasses with prisms to correct the double vision and physical therapy to strengthen the lateral rectus musculature. In severe cases, surgical intervention may be required.
educational_objective:
Diabetic mononeuropathy is a complication of diabetes mellitus affecting the nerves. The underlying mechanism of diabetic mononeuropathy is thought to be related to microvascular complications of
diabetes, particularly of the small vessels supplying the nerves, leading to ischemia and inflammation. This damage can lead to a loss of function of the nerve. Treatment is based on symptoms, though tighter blood glucose control
is paramount.
