vignette:
6. Four days after admission to the hospital because of abdominal pain and dehydration, a 52-year-old man with metastatic colon cancer is demanding additional medication to relieve his pain. On admission, treatment with
intravenous crystalloid and acetaminophen was begun. On hospital day 2, his pain increased in severity, and he was switched to intravenous hydromorphone, which provided adequate analgesia. This morning, in
preparation for discharge, he was switched to oral hydromorphone at the same dose. Eight hours later, he said the pain relief was inadequate, but the oral medication was maintained. Since then, he anxiously has been
anticipating each dose of oral hydromorphone by watching the clock. He has no history of substance use disorder. On mental status examination, he has an anxious mood and is preoccupied with receiving pain medication.
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's inadequate pain relief?

choices.text: Increased volume of distribution of hydromorphone
Loss of placebo effect from the injection

correct_explanation:
Opioid dose titration is necessary after beginning initial therapy and when switching from intravenous to oral dosing of the same agent, or switching between opioid agents. By convention, the dose of an opioid is converted to its
morphine equivalent dose, allowing for comparison of and conversion between opioids of different potencies. Hydromorphone is a mu opioid agonist that is effective for moderate-to-severe cancer pain and is available in
intravenous or oral formulations. Oral hydromorphone is approximately four times as potent as oral morphine, such that 7.5 mg of oral hydromorphone provides an equivalent dose to 30 mg of oral morphine. Oral hydromorphone is
also less potent than intravenous hydromorphone, and approximately 5 mg of oral hydromorphone should be given for each 1 mg of intravenous hydromorphone when converting from intravenous to oral dosing to provide an
equianalgesic dose. Special caution should be used when switching between agents due to cross-tolerance, and it is common to start a new opioid agent at a reduced equianalgesic dose initially and then to titrate the dose upwards
based on clinical response and tolerability. This patient has been transitioned from intravenous hydromorphone to oral hydromorphone at the same dose. Given the reduced potency of oral hydromorphone, he is likely experiencing
inadequate analgesia and should have his dose of oral hydromorphone adjusted accordingly.
educational_objective:
Opioid dose titration is necessary after beginning initial therapy and when switching from intravenous to oral dosing of the same agent, or switching between opioid agents. By convention, the dose of an
opioid is converted to its morphine equivalent dose, allowing for comparison of and conversion between opioids of different potencies. Oral hydromorphone is less potent than intravenous hydromorphone, and approximately 5 mg of
oral hydromorphone should be given for each 1 mg of intravenous hydromorphone when converting from intravenous to oral dosing to provide an equianalgesic dose.

vignette:
7. Ten days after undergoing vagotomy, pyloroplasty, and oversewing for a bleeding duodenal ulcer, a 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fever, difficulty breathing, and left shoulder pain. He
was previously feeling well and tolerating a normal diet. His only medication is oxycodone with acetaminophen. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Breath
sounds are decreased over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows tenderness over the left upper quadrant; the incision site is healing well. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of
the chest shows a raised left hemidiaphragm. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these current findings?
correct_explanation:
Postoperative complications can include infection, bleeding, wound dehiscence, and thromboembolic disease among others. Common causes of postoperative fever are atelectasis, pneumonia, urinary tract infection, infections of
the surgical site, or intrathoracic or intra-abdominal infections related to the surgery. Thromboembolic disease with deep venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism can also present with a fever, and bacteremia can also cause
fever. In this patient, the most likely cause of fever is an intra-abdominal subphrenic abscess, abdominal tenderness in the left upper quadrant, and pain referred to the left shoulder. Infection or inflammation to the diaphragm
commonly presents as referred pain to the shoulder. To diagnose an intra-abdominal abscess, a CT scan of the abdomen with contrast should be performed. Typically, the right hemidiaphragm is more elevated than the left
hemidiaphragm because of the presence of the liver in the right upper quadrant. A raised left hemidiaphragm increases concern for a mass, hematoma, or abscess in the left upper quadrant (in this case, a subphrenic abscess on
the left side). Management involves intravenous antibiotics, and in some cases, percutaneous or operative drainage.
educational_objective:
Postoperative complications can include infections or abscesses. A subphrenic abscess can cause fever, upper quadrant abdominal pain, referred pain to the shoulder, and elevated hemidiaphragm.
Management involves intravenous antibiotics, and in some cases, percutaneous or operative drainage.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
8. A65-year-old man comes to the office for a routine examination. He sustained an ST-elevation myocardial infarction 1 year ago with subsequent revascularization and stent placement. The patient says he has felt well since
his coronary procedure, and he reports no exercise intolerance, chest pain, shortness of breath, or other symptoms. He also has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications are clopidogrel,
lisinopril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. The patient smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years but quit after his myocardial infarction. He drinks one glass of wine nightly and does not use illicit drugs. He does yard
work and walks for 20 minutes three times weekly. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 104 kg (229 Ib); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Repeat ECG is
unchanged from his last ECG. Which of the following is the most appropriate study for disease surveillance?
correct_explanation:
Common risk factors for coronary artery disease include age, tobacco use, history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. If significant coronary artery stenosis is present, patients may begin to experience symptoms
such as angina, dyspnea, and light-headedness with exertion. In patients with clinically significant stenotic lesions, coronary stenting may be performed, and often results in significant improvement in symptoms. Patients with stents
are often required to be on dual antiplatelet therapy, and noncompliance with these medications can lead to complications such as in-stent thrombosis. There is currently no recommendation for routine surveillance studies in
patients with coronary artery disease who have received intervention and are currently asymptomatic. Patients with coronary artery disease should focus on risk factor modification such as smoking cessation, exercise, and
management of chronic conditions such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus.
educational_objective:
There is currently no recommendation for routine surveillance studies in patients with coronary artery disease who have received intervention and are currently asymptomatic. Patients with coronary artery
disease should focus on risk factor modification such as smoking cessation, exercise, and management of chronic conditions such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus.

vignette:
9. A57-year-old woman with unresectable pancreatic cancer is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-month history of constant severe abdominal pain that radiates to her back. The pain has not decreased despite an 8-
week course of palliative chemotherapy and radiation therapy and treatment with transdermal fentanyl and oral oxycodone every 6 hours for breakthrough pain. She rates the pain as an 8 on a 10-point scale. She says
that the pain limits her daily activities and forces her to remain bedridden for 10 to 12 hours daily. She is able to eat but has occasional nausea. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min,
and blood pressure is 112/65 mm Hg. Examination shows mild scleral icterus. A 6-cm tender mass is palpated in the epigastrium. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next
step in management?
correct_explanation:
Pain caused by cancer is associated with significant limitations in functional status and quality of life. The World Health Organization has outlined a strategy, known as the analgesic ladder, to guide escalating pain management
strategies in cancer patients. Within this framework, initial management is with non-opioid medications and adjuvant therapies, followed by addition of opioids for more severe pain. Opioid dosage often needs to be increased due to
progression of metastatic disease, as well as the development of opioid tolerance. Cancer patients often experience pain that is refractory to treatment with opioids. The final step within the analgesic ladder involves invasive or
minimally invasive procedures to achieve analgesia, such as nerve blocks, ablative procedures, or intrathecal or epidural analgesia. Celiac plexus blockade is an effective, minimally invasive pain management approach for patients
with pain caused by pancreatic cancer that is refractory to high-dose opioids. The celiac plexus is located within the retroperitoneal space on the anterolateral surface of the aorta near the origin of the celiac trunk. It provides
autonomic and nociceptive innervation to the liver, gallbladder, stomach, pancreas, spleen, small bowel, proximal large bowel, and kidneys. The blockade is performed by injection of alcohol under fluoroscopic guidance, resulting in
neurolysis and effective pain control in most patients.
educational_objective:
Celiac plexus blockade is an effective pain management approach for patients with pain caused by pancreatic cancer that is refractory to high-dose opioids. The celiac plexus is located within the
retroperitoneal space on the anterolateral surface of the aorta near the origin of the celiac trunk. It provides autonomic and nociceptive innervation to the liver, gallbladder, stomach, pancreas, spleen, small bowel, proximal large
bowel, and kidneys. The blockade is performed by injection of alcohol under fluoroscopic guidance, resulting in neurolysis and effective pain control in most patients.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
Y

vignette:
40. A 67-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine examination. He has chronic lymphocytic leukemia and currently takes no medications. He feels well. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations
are 16/min, and blood pressure is 136/72 mm Hg. Examination shows several small, firm, nontender lymph nodes in the neck and axilla. Abdominal examination shows mild splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13 g/dL
Leukocyte count 84,000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 30%
Eosinophils 3%
Basophils 2%
Lymphocytes 60%
Monocytes 5%
Platelet count 149,000/mm3
This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
correct_explanation:
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a malignancy of mature, differentiated B lymphocytes. These abnormal cells can accumulate in the blood, lymph nodes, and other organs, leading to a variety of symptoms, such as fatigue,
weakness, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent infections. CLL is the most common type of leukemia in adults and is more common in people over age 60 years. The exact cause of CLL is unknown, but several factors, such as
genetic mutations, exposure to radiation, and certain infections, have been linked to its development. In terms of complications, infection is the most common complication associated with CLL. This is because CLL can weaken the
immune system, making patients more susceptible to bacterial, viral, and fungal infections. Infections can cause a range of symptoms, from mild to severe, and can be life-threatening in some cases, depending on the organ system
involved and the presence of additional comorbidities or immunocompromise.
educational_objective:
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is a malignancy of mature, differentiated B lymphocytes. These abnormal cells can accumulate in the blood, lymph nodes, and other organs, leading to a variety of symptoms,
such as fatigue, weakness, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent infections. The most common complication is infection.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
11. A52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of mild abdominal cramps and diarrhea containing blood and mucus. During this time, he also has had fecal urgency and mild pain with bowel
movements. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nondistended and nontender; there are no masses, and bowel sounds are
normal. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Results of stool culture and testing of the stool for Clostridium difficile, ova, and parasites are negative. Colonoscopy shows 30 cm of continuously friable, erythematous
rectal and sigmoid mucosa; no polyps or masses are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that results in inflammation and ulceration of the colonic mucosa and submucosa, typically beginning in the rectum and advancing proximally in a continuous distribution.
Symptoms include chronic abdominal pain, weight loss, bloody diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and tenesmus. This patient likely has ulcerative colitis as suggested by continuous friable rectal and sigmoid mucosa on colonoscopy
and symptoms of cramping, fecal urgency, and bloody diarrhea. Imaging typically shows loss of haustral markings. Diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is made through colonoscopy and biopsy, which demonstrates characteristic crypt
abscesses. Inflammatory bowel disease can also be associated with extraintestinal manifestations, including uveitis, arthritis, aphthous stomatitis, and pyoderma gangrenosum. Treatment includes immunomodulators, biologics, and
steroids. Mesalamine is an anti-inflammatory medication most often used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis.
educational_objective:
Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that results in inflammation and ulceration of the colonic mucosa and submucosa. Symptoms include chronic abdominal pain, weight loss, bloody diarrhea,
abdominal bloating, and tenesmus. Treatment includes immunomodulators, biologics, and steroids. Mesalamine is an anti-inflammatory medication most often used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
Y

vignette:
12. A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She had used a diaphragm for contraception for 10 years but switched to a combination oral contraceptive 6 months ago.

She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 Ib); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Her blood pressure has averaged 144/92 mm Hg on three visits during the past 3 months. Her pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood

pressure now is 145/90 mm Hg. Examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: 24-Hour urine collection for measurement of catecholamine concentration
Low-dose hydrochlorothiazide therapy and reexamination in 1 month

correct_explanation:
This patient presenting with a mild increase in her blood pressure on several office visits has a presentation suggestive of primary hypertension. Stage 1 hypertension is defined as a systolic blood pressure greater than 130 mm Hg
or a diastolic blood pressure greater than 80 mm Hg. The primary factors determining blood pressure are renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, sympathetic nervous system, and plasma blood volume. The onset of this patient's
increased blood pressure corresponds with the time she began to take her new oral contraceptive. Estrogen-containing oral contraceptives may cause a rise in blood pressure in some patients. While this rise in blood pressure is
often mild, some patients experience more significant elevations. Combined oral contraceptives also increase risk for venous thromboembolism, myocardial infarction, and stroke. If a patient taking a combined oral contraceptive
experiences significant elevation in blood pressure, they should be offered another form of contraception, such as a non-estrogen hormonal contraceptive or an intrauterine device. After the discontinuation of the estrogen-
containing medication, the patient should be monitored to ensure that their blood pressure returns to normal values.
educational_objective:
Estrogen-containing oral contraceptives may cause a rise in blood pressure. Although this rise is often mild, it rarely may cause significant elevation in some patients. If this occurs, the medication should be
discontinued, and an alternative method of contraception should be offered.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
¥

vignette:
13. A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of excessive daytime sleepiness. He is tired after sleeping more than 10 hours at night. He frequently falls asleep during class, and,
last week, he was involved in a motor vehicle collision after falling asleep while driving home from a party. He snores at night. His academic performance was good but has deteriorated to almost failing. Examination shows
no abnormalities except for mildly enlarged tonsils. Polysomnography shows normal airflow and gas exchange, normal sleep stages with short REM latency, and poor sleep continuity with multiple brief arousals and four
sustained awakenings. On the following day, multiple sleep latency testing shows REM episodes at the onset of sleep during three of four naps with a mean sleep latency of 1 minute. Which of the following is the most likely
explanation for these findings?
correct_explanation:
Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder characterized by daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis that responds to modafinil therapy. Narcolepsy arises from deficient production of orexins in the
hypothalamus, which may result from genetic or autoimmune causes. Orexins typically induce the secretion of monoamines, such as norepinephrine, throughout the brain to promote wakefulness. As a result, patients suddenly and
inappropriately transition into sleep during the day. Additionally, REM sleep features (eg, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) occur during wakefulness. Cataplexy refers to a sudden loss of muscle tone and
usually occurs in response to positive emotion. The clinical diagnosis should be confirmed by a polysomnogram to confirm the rapid transition into REM sleep and rule out other causes of daytime sleepiness, as well as a multiple
sleep latency test to confirm decreased sleep latency. Treatment includes maintaining a regular sleep schedule, avoidance of daytime naps, and in patients with severe daytime sleepiness, modafinil. Modafinil has an unclear
mechanism of action that involves increasing orexin and monoamine availability.
educational_objective:
Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder that involves deficient orexin secretion, leading to the intrusion of sleep phenomena (eg, sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) into times of
wakefulness. Clinical diagnosis is confirmed by a polysomnogram. Modafinil therapy, which likely increases orexin secretion, is the first-line therapy for patients with severe daytime sleepiness.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
14. A23-year-old primigravid woman at 18 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of heat intolerance and an inability to sit quietly for more than a few minutes. She also has had five to six bowel

movements daily and a 3.6-kg (8-Ib) weight loss despite an increased appetite during this period. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and now weighs 55 kg (122 Ib). Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 133/min,

respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 160/50 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse thyroid gland enlargement and a fine tremor of the outstretched hands. The uterus is 18 cm from the pubic symphysis. Fetal heart

tones are audible at 160/min. Her free thyroxine index is 14 (N=5—13). Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
correct_explanation:
Propylthiouracil is the most appropriate treatment of hyperthyroidism in pregnancy for this patient. Hyperthyroidism most commonly presents as it did in this patient, with heat intolerance, agitation, diarrhea, weight loss, tachycardia,
palpitations, and tremor. The most common cause in both pregnant and nonpregnant patients is Graves disease, which is caused by an antibody to the TSH receptor, leading to its activation and the production of increased thyroid
hormones. Pregnancy itself is also associated with increased thyroid hormones, due to stimulation of the thyroid by B-hCG and due to an increased production of thyroid-binding globulin. This leads to overall high concentrations of
total triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4), but not to increased free hormone concentrations. Thus, diagnosis is made with evaluation of TSH concentrations, which would be expected to be low, and free T, concentrations, which
would be expected to be high. Complications of untreated maternal hyperthyroidism include abnormalities in the neonatal thyroid function, spontaneous abortion, premature labor, preeclampsia, and a small-for-gestational-age
newborn. Treatment often consists of symptomatic management with a short course of B-adrenergic blockers and disease management with propylthiouracil or methimazole. Propylthiouracil is the preferred agent in the first
trimester, as it is associated with less teratogenicity than methimazole, which has been linked to omphalocele, tracheoesophageal fistulas, and choanal atresia in the newborn. Thyroidectomy in the second trimester is also a
treatment option.
educational_objective:
Hyperthyroidism in pregnancy presents with heat intolerance, agitation, diarrhea, weight loss, tachycardia, palpitations, and tremor. Laboratory studies most commonly show a decreased TSH and an
increased free thyroxine concentration. Complications of untreated maternal hyperthyroidism include abnormalities in the neonatal thyroid function, spontaneous abortion, premature labor, preeclampsia, and a small-for-gestational-
age newborn. Treatment often consists of symptomatic management with a short course of B-adrenergic blockers and disease management with propylthiouracil or methimazole, with propylthiouracil being the preferred treatment in
the first trimester.

vignette:
15. A40-year-old woman comes to the office to establish care. She has felt well and reports no symptoms. Medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. Family history is remarkable for kidney stones in her

mother. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Initial serum laboratory studies show a calcium concentration of 11 mg/dL. Further testing shows a serum intact parathyroid

hormone concentration of 75 pg/mL (N=10-60). Results of 24-hour urine collection show a calcium concentration of 50 mg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
correct_explanation:
Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) is a heritable, autosomal dominant disorder caused by inactivating mutations affecting the CASR gene encoding calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) on parathyroid and renal cells. As a
result of decreased CaSR activity, the parathyroid gland is rendered insensitive to normal or increased serum calcium and inappropriately releases parathyroid hormone (PTH) in order to respond to falsely perceived hypocalcemia.
This leads to increased osteoclastic bone resorption, increased gastrointestinal calcium absorption, increased renal tubular reabsorption of calcium and magnesium, and increased renal loss of phosphate. Patients are typically
asymptomatic or have mild symptoms of hypercalcemia, including fatigue, headache, abdominal pain, or constipation. Patients may rarely have pancreatitis as a result of abnormal pancreatic calcifications. The diagnosis is
established with genetic testing of the CASR gene. 24-Hour urine calcium excretion of less than 100 mg supports the diagnosis. Laboratory studies typically show mild hypercalcemia, hypermagnesemia, hypophosphatemia, and
hypocalciuria. There is often a family history of hypercalcemia. The condition is benign, and most patients do not require treatment, although patients with recurrent pancreatitis may benefit from subtotal parathyroidectomy.
educational_objective:
Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia is a heritable, autosomal dominant disorder caused by inactivating mutations affecting the CASR gene encoding calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) on parathyroid and
renal cells. As a result of decreased CaSR activity, the parathyroid gland is rendered insensitive to normal or increased serum calcium and inappropriately releases parathyroid hormone in order to respond to falsely perceived
hypocalcemia. Patients are typically asymptomatic or have mild symptoms of hypercalcemia. Laboratory studies typically show mild hypercalcemia, hypermagnesemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypocalciuria. The condition is
benign, and most patients can be observed without treatment.

vignette:
16. A27-year-old man with asthma comes to the physician as a new patient. He has a 10-year history of chronic cough productive of sputum and a 3-year history of intermittent diarrhea. He has nasal allergies. During the past

10 years, he has had numerous respiratory tract infections treated with antibiotics. He had three episodes of pneumonia during childhood. His medications are cetirizine, montelukast, and nasal fluticasone; he uses an

albuterol inhaler four times daily. He does not smoke cigarettes. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (115 Ib); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows erythematous, boggy nasal

mucosa. A few scattered rhonchi are heard in the lower lung fields bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the paranasal sinuses

correct_explanation:
Measurement of serum immunoglobulin concentrations is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient with recurrent sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections. This constellation of symptoms is suggestive of
common variable immunodeficiency disease (CVID). CVID classically presents in the second to fourth decades of life as multiple, recurrent sinus or pulmonary infections, including pneumonia, bronchitis, and sinusitis. Chronic lung
infections can result in bronchiectasis, and infections of the gastrointestinal tract are also frequently encountered. Patients with CVID are at an increased risk for the development of autoimmune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis,
autoimmune hemolytic anemia, and autoimmune thyroid disease. Additionally, they have a higher risk for cancer, especially gastric cancer, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The diagnosis is made by quantitative measurement of serum
immunoglobulins, which universally shows decreased concentrations of IgG and low concentrations of IgA and/or IgM. The pathogenesis involves impaired B lymphocyte differentiation into plasma cells, leading to impaired
production of immunoglobulins. As a result of failed antibody production, patients have a blunted and sometimes absent response to immunization, which is supportive of the diagnosis in patients with classic findings. Treatment is
with intravenous immunoglobulin.
educational_objective:
Common variable immunodeficiency disease occurs because of impaired B lymphocyte differentiation into plasma cells, leading to reduced or absent concentrations of IgG, IgA, and/or IgM. Patients usually
present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections but are also at risk for gastrointestinal infections, liver disease, autoimmune disease, and malignancies. Diagnosis is made by measuring immunoglobulin concentration and treatment
is with intravenous immunoglobulin.

vignette:
17. Astudy is conducted to assess the accuracy of a new rapid test to detect streptococcal pharyngitis. A total of 200 patients with sore throat undergo rapid testing; these results are compared with the results of subsequent
throat cultures for group A B-hemolytic streptococcus. The results show:
Culture
+ = Total
, + |” 55
Total 50 150 200

Which of the following best represents the prevalence of streptococcal pharyngitis within this population?
correct_explanation:
Prevalence defines the number of cases of a disease or condition as a fraction of a population in consideration at a point in time. Prevalence indicates the percentage of current cases of a condition within the population under
study. Mathematically, prevalence is calculated by dividing the number of existing cases by the number of people in the population under study or at risk for the condition. In this case, the condition or disease under study is
streptococcal pharyngitis. In this example, 50 total patients were found to have culture-confirmed streptococcal pharyngitis. This is then divided by the total study population, 200, resulting in a prevalence of 25%, or 50/200.
educational_objective:
Prevalence defines the number of cases of a disease or condition as a fraction of a population in consideration at a point in time. Prevalence indicates the percentage of current cases of a condition within the
population under study. Mathematically, prevalence is calculated by dividing the number of existing cases by the number of people in the population under study or at risk for the condition.

vignette:
18. A77-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-year history of a lesion over her forearm that has increased gradually in size. She works outdoors in her garden 3 days weekly and does not wear sunscreen,

and she is concerned the lesion could be cancer. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of

the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Wide elliptical excision of the lesion

correct_explanation:
Observation only is appropriate in the case of seborrheic keratoses. Seborrheic keratoses are benign growths found in middle-aged and older adults. Seborrheic keratoses occur in areas of sun exposure and clinically present as
round to ovoid, brown, sharply demarcated, verrucous papules. Seborrheic keratoses can be confused for melanocytic growths, but unlike pigmented growths, they are not associated with malignant potential and are monitored
clinically. Seborrheic keratoses may become inflamed, especially at sites of friction. If treatment is needed, they can be removed using cryotherapy, electrodessication and curettage, or excision.
educational_objective:
Seborrheic keratoses are common benign growths, found in middle-aged and elderly adults. They commonly present as brown, sharply demarcated papules in sun-exposed sites. Seborrheic keratoses do not
represent melanocytic growths, but are related to a thickening of the epidermis, pigment deposition, and development of intraepidermal keratin cysts. Seborrheic keratoses are managed in most cases with clinical observation.
Removal can occur with cryotherapy, electrodessication and curettage, or excision.

vignette:
19. A25-year-old man comes to the physician 2 hours after the sudden onset of sharp right buttock pain that radiates to the back of his knee. The pain worsens when he sits for a prolonged period or drives. He is able to walk.

Use of over-the-counter ibuprofen has provided mild relief. He has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications. On examination, ipsilateral and contralateral straight-leg raise testing is positive. Muscle

strength is normal throughout. Sensation is intact throughout. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommendation of bed rest for 1 week

correct_explanation:
Lumbar disc herniation is a common cause of sciatica, also known as lumbar radiculopathy. Disc herniation most often occurs following chronic disc degeneration combined with a minor traumatic event, such as bending and lifting
a heavy object, causing an acute increase in the intradiscal pressure. Disc herniation typically presents as acute back pain with symptoms of lumbosacral radiculopathy, including acute extremity pain and/or weakness in a
dermatomal and myotomal distribution with respect to the impinged spinal nerve. Sciatica is diagnosed clinically through a combination of history and examination maneuvers, including the straight-leg raise test in which flexion of
the hip while the leg is held in extension at the knee reproduces pain in the lower back that generally shoots down the leg. Lumbar imaging with MRI or CT scan is useful for patients with severe motor or sensory dysfunction but is
not required for most patients with mild or moderate symptoms. Most patients with sciatica show spontaneous improvement with conservative management, including analgesia, physical therapy, and normal activity as tolerated.
educational_objective:
Sciatica is often caused by lumbar disc herniation. It typically presents with acute back pain with symptoms of lumbosacral radiculopathy, including acute extremity pain and/or weakness in a dermatomal and
myotomal distribution with respect to the impinged nerve, generally radiating down the back of the leg. It is typically a self-limited process, and most patients show spontaneous improvement with conservative management,
including analgesia, physical therapy, and normal activity as tolerated.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
20. A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a motor vehicle collision. He was sitting unrestrained on his aunt's lap in the front passenger seat during the collision, and the

automobile's air bags deployed on impact. Paramedics at the scene immobilized his spine with a cervical collar, and his head was taped to a backboard during transport to the hospital. He has no history of serious illness

and receives no medications. On arrival, he is crying and moving all extremities. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air

shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Examination shows abrasions over the face and neck. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest and abdomen

correct_explanation:
Blunt trauma to the head, neck, or chest, as seen in this pediatric patient, is a common presentation to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. The first steps in managing such patients are to assess the airway,
breathing, and circulation, along with immobilization of cervical spine until further examinations can be performed. Management after initial survey is dependent on any concerning findings such as airway compromise, respiratory
suppression, or circulatory dysfunction. In this patient, who was being held by a family member in the front seat of a vehicle in which the airbags deployed during collision, it is fair to assume that the patient was struck by the airbag.
On arrival, this patient is mildly tachycardic and mildly tachypneic, though for his age such vital signs may be appropriate. At the time of assessment, there is no clear indication of a primary survey related immediate life threat; thus,
he does not require immediate intervention prior to further diagnosis. His spine was immobilized with a cervical collar and backboard on scene. The most appropriate next step, given his stable presentation, is to assess integrity of
structures in the cervical spine and thorax, as these are most likely to be damaged due to airbag deployment. This is also particularly important for this patient because there are abrasions over his face and neck, again giving
evidence for airbag contact. If this patient were to have respiratory collapse from resultant laryngeal or tracheal injury, intubation would be necessary to maintain the patient’s airway. However, if a cervical spine fracture was not
identified prior to this, there is an increased possibility of spinal cord injury during intubation. Notably, x-rays have limited sensitivity for pediatric blunt traumatic injury; bony structures are not yet fully ossified at age 2 years.
Advanced studies such as CT scan or MRI may be necessary depending on the clinical presentation, though x-ray imaging is an appropriate first choice.
educational_objective:
Management of patients with blunt trauma to the head or neck involves assessment of airway, breathing, and circulation as well as immobilization of the spine until further assessments can be performed. For
a stable patient with no obvious neurologic deficits and a grossly benign examination, x-rays of the cervical spine and chest can be used to identify any fractures or pathologies not detected by physical examination.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
21. A52-year-old man comes to the physician 2 days after noticing that his eyes and skin appear yellow. Four days ago, he received the diagnosis of sinusitis and began treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. During
the past 6 months, he has traveled to Nicaragua and Belize. He has been sexually active with 12 partners during the past 2 years and uses condoms inconsistently. He drinks three to four beers weekly. He does not
smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg. Examination shows generalized jaundice and a diffuse, macular,
nonblanching rash over the chest and back. There is scleral icterus. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL
Serum
\ Bilirubin, total 5.5 mg/dL
Direct 2.2 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 58 U/L
AST 372 U/L
ALT 250 U/L
HBsAg negative
Hepatitis B surface antibody positive
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
correct_explanation:
The patient is presenting with acute hepatitis with jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, and increased serum liver enzyme concentrations. Causes of acute hepatitis include viral infections, excessive alcohol use, medications or
supplements, autoimmune disease, and ischemic injury. Intravenous drug use is a major risk factor for viral hepatitis, especially transmission of hepatitis B virus (HBV) and hepatitis C virus (HCV). Serologic testing for acute viral
hepatitis includes anti-hepatitis A virus (HAV) IgM and IgG antibodies, anti-HCV IgM and IgG antibodies, and more specific evaluation of multiple anti-HBV antibodies and antigens as a result of the propensity of HBV to cause
chronic and subacute infections. In this scenario, the patient has been found to be positive for hepatitis B surface antibody with negative hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAG), indicating the patient is likely immunized or has had a
previous hepatitis B infection. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole has been associated with acute liver injury, often with features of drug allergy, including fever or rash, as is seen in this patient. In the setting of recently beginning
treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, an antibiotic with known hepatotoxicity, discontinuation of the antibiotic is the most appropriate initial step in management.
educational_objective:
Acute hepatitis presents with jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, and increased serum liver enzyme concentrations with causes including viral infections, excessive alcohol use, medications or supplements,
autoimmune disease, and ischemic injury. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole has been known to cause acute liver injury with features of drug allergy, including fever and rash. Initial management in drug-induced acute liver injury is
discontinuation of the implicated medication.

vignette:
22. Apreviously healthy 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever and persistent cough productive of yellow sputum. He has not had shortness of breath. He does not smoke. His temperature

is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg. Scattered rhonchi are heard bilaterally. During the examination, he has an episode of severe coughing. An x-ray of the

chest shows no abnormalities. In addition to treatment of this patient's symptoms, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
correct_explanation:
This patient is presenting with 2 days of a low-grade fever, persistent productive cough, and a physical examination that only discloses scattered rhonchi. X-ray of this patient's chest shows no acute abnormalities. Because of this,
the most likely diagnosis is a viral respiratory illness such as bronchitis. General guidance for the treatment of viral respiratory infections is symptomatic treatment with antitussives and antipyretics. Antibiotic treatment is not
indicated in a viral respiratory infection, in contrast to bacterial respiratory infections where antibiotics are the mainstay of therapy. Antibiotic stewardship is an important part of the practice of medicine by physicians, as unnecessary
prescribing of antibiotics can lead to increased resistance patterns in generally susceptible bacterial lines, along with adverse effects of antibiotic use such as Clostridioides difficile infection. Patients should be counseled about
appropriate use and treatment in these cases, as community-held beliefs that antibiotics are useful for viral respiratory infections remain somewhat common.
educational_objective:
Treatment of viral respiratory infections, including bronchitis, includes symptomatic management with antitussives and antipyretics. Antibiotics are not indicated in the treatment of viral respiratory illnesses.
History that would be suggestive of a bacterial respiratory infection includes symptoms lasting longer than 10 days, worsening symptoms after an initial improvement, obvious consolidation on chest x-ray, or fever greater than

vignette:
23. A17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a scrotal mass that has become increasingly painful during the past 3 days. He is not certain how long the mass has beén present. There is no history of trauma. He is

sexually active with several partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Examination shows a tender mass posterior to the left testis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
correct_explanation:
Acute epididymitis, or infection of the epididymis, most commonly presents with unilateral scrotal pain associated with a tender, swollen mass over the posterior aspect of the testis. In severe cases, it can also present with localized
erythema, dysuria, and systemic symptoms, such as fever and rigors. Physical examination will show an intact cremasteric reflex, which helps differentiate acute epididymitis from testicular torsion, in which the cremasteric reflex is
negative. However, the sensitivity and specificity of these maneuvers is notably imperfect and limited, and they should not be relied on to determine the diagnosis. The underlying cause is most commonly infection with Chlamydia
trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae in men under age 35 years, whereas Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas species are the more common causative organisms in older men and in those practicing insertional anal intercourse.
Evaluation should include urine nucleic acid amplification testing for both C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae, as well as urinalysis and urine culture. Treatment includes empiric ceftriaxone for gonorrheal infection and doxycycline or
azithromycin for chlamydial infection in patients at risk for sexually transmitted infections. Levofloxacin or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are the recommended agents for patients at low risk for a sexually transmitted infection or in
those in whom an enteric organism is the suspected pathogen. Symptomatic management includes scrotal elevation, application of ice, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
educational_objective:
Acute epididymitis, or infection of the epididymis, most commonly presents with unilateral scrotal pain associated with a tender, swollen mass over the posterior aspect of the testis. It is commonly caused by
infection with Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae in men under age 35 years. Diagnosis is made with urine nucleic acid amplification testing. Treatment includes symptomatic management with scrotal elevation,
application of ice, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, as well as antibiotics such as ceftriaxone and doxycycline or azithromycin to treat the underlying infection.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
24. A52-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for treatment of acute diverticulitis. After 2 days of intravenous antibiotic therapy, she has a temperature of 39.1°C (102.4°F) and abdominal rigidity. Her leukocyte count is

17,400/mm with 15% bands. The physician explains to the patient that she will need to undergo sigmoid colectomy and that, depending on the findings, she may require a colostomy. The patient agrees to the operation

but refuses to undergo a colostomy. The patient's husband is in the hospital but is not with the patient at this time. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Obtain informed consent from the patient's husband
Obtain a psychiatric assessment of the patient's mental capacity
Perform the operation without a colostomy, regardless of the findings
Perform the operation and a colostomy if indicated

correct_explanation:
Before considering a patient’s decisional capacity to consent to a procedure or proceeding with a procedure, the patient must be provided with the information needed to make an informed decision. Ensuring informed consent has
been obtained is a physician’s duty before performing a procedure in a nonemergent setting. Informed consent fulfills the ethics principle of autonomy, which dictates that patients should be able to make their own decisions about
their health care, including whether to accept or decline a procedure. Informed consent also benefits the physician-patient relationship and encourages physicians to thoroughly review the indications, benefits, and risks of the
procedure, and whether alternatives could be considered. Informed consent in this case must include an explanation of possible operative findings and management options, as well as the risks and benefits of both agreeing to and
declining the options.
educational_objective:
Informed consent fulfills the ethics principle of autonomy. When obtaining informed consent for a procedure, the proposed procedure, the alternative treatment options, the risks and benefits of the procedure,
and the risks of refusing the procedure should all be explained to the patient in a way that they can understand.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
25. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her parents are concerned about her eating habits. During the past 8 months, she has stopped eating meals with the family, expressed concern about her weight, and
lectured the family about improving their dietary practices. The patient says that eating more nutritious foods has decreased her appetite. She says the fact that she has enough energy to be on the cross-country running
and cheerleading teams shows she is eating appropriately. She worries she does not have the right body shape for fashionable clothes and thinks she would be more popular if she could dress better. She receives grades
of A’s in school but worries she will not be able to maintain her grade point average because this year has been more challenging since she began taking several advanced-level classes. She says she has not been
spending much time with friends because of schoolwork demands. The patient is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 53 kg (116 Ib); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no
abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and affect; the patient becomes anxious when discussing school performance and her weight. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Anorexia nervosa is characterized by an intense fear of gaining weight, decreased self-worth related to body weight, and consequent restricting (eg, fasting, exercising) or binge eating/purging behavior (eg, vomiting, laxative or
diuretic misuse) leading to insufficient nutrition. Patients with anorexia nervosa often have a BMI less than 17 kg/m2, though patients with mild anorexia may have a BMI greater than 17 kg/m? (normal limit for BMI is 18.5 to 24.9
kg/m?). Amenorrhea is common and reflects insufficient nutrition. Physical examination of patients with anorexia nervosa can show dry, scaly skin and fine hair or hair loss caused by decreased protein stores, though these signs
are not present in all patients. In severe cases, signs of hypovolemia, such as tachycardia and hypotension, may be present. Risk factors for anorexia nervosa include perfectionistic tendencies (as illustrated by this patient’s school
worries) and involvement in sports that emphasize body aesthetics (eg, dance, gymnastics, cheerleading). Treatment of anorexia nervosa is through a combined medical and psychiatric approach and involves correcting fluid and
electrolyte derangements along with behavioral and pharmacologic therapy.
educational_objective:
Anorexia nervosa is characterized by an intense fear of gaining weight, decreased self-worth related to body weight, and consequent restricting (eg, fasting, exercising) or binge eating/purging behavior (eg,
vomiting, laxative or diuretic misuse) leading to insufficient energy intake. Amenorrhea and a low BMI are more often associated with anorexia nervosa than other eating disorders. Treatment of anorexia nervosa is through a
combined medical and psychiatric approach and involves correcting fluid and electrolyte derangements along with behavioral and pharmacologic therapy.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
26. During observation of a surgical procedure, a physician notices the anesthesiologist falling asleep; the observing physician says the anesthesiologist's name, and he wakes up and attends to the remainder of the operation

appropriately. After the procedure, the physician approaches the anesthesiologist who states that he was up late last evening attending to an emergency procedure. The surgeon later informs the physician that this

anesthesiologist frequently falls asleep in the operating room. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for the physician?

choices.text: No action is necessary since the surgeon has been notified
Recommend that the anesthesiologist undergo sleep studies
Report the anesthesiologist to the police
Report the anesthesiologist to the specialty society

correct_explanation:
Fatigue is an important and common challenge facing health care providers. Fatigue occurs due to a variety of factors, including long or irregular work hours, and can result in impaired cognitive performance and decision making. In
this case, the reason for the anesthesiologist’s fatigue is unclear, but the observing physician has been made aware of a pattern of behavior of the anesthesiologist sleeping during surgery, which is inappropriate and could
compromise patient safety. The most appropriate next step is for the observing physician to report the issue to the chief of the medical staff. The chief of the medical staff is responsible for overseeing physicians and other medical
personnel. The chief of the medical staff is the most appropriate person to identify and address the source of the problem.
educational_objective:
Fatigue is an important and common challenge facing health care providers. Fatigue often occurs due to long or irregular work hours and results in decreased performance and increased risk for patient
adverse events. The chief of the medical staff is responsible for overseeing physicians and other medical personnel at the hospital and is the most appropriate person to identify and address the source of the problem.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
27. A32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of tenderness and swelling of her neck. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is

38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination of the neck shows no masses. The thyroid gland is slightly enlarged and tender. No nodules are palpated. The

remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 0.3 uU/mL and thyroxine (T,) concentration of 11.5 yg/dL. Antithyroid antibodies are not detected.

A 131 thyroid scan shows decreased uptake. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis is a rare form of thyroiditis that is characterized by inflammation of the thyroid gland and the presence of granulomas. It is typically preceded by a viral infection, such as an upper
respiratory infection, and is more common in women. Symptoms may include pain and tenderness in the thyroid area, fever, fatigue, and a swollen thyroid gland, along with symptoms of hyperthyroidism (eg, anxiety, tremors, weight
loss, diarrhea, menstrual irregularities, hot flashes, tachycardia, hypertension, sweating). Treatment typically includes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and pain. The condition is
usually self-limiting, and the thyroid gland typically returns to normal function within a few weeks or months. However, in some cases the patient may experience temporary or permanent hypothyroidism following the initial period of
inflammation and generally transient hyperthyroid symptoms. Subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis should be suspected in any patient who has an enlarged, tender thyroid, history of recent viral illness, and/or
increased thyroxine concentration with decreased TSH concentration.
educational_objective:
Subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis is a rare form of thyroiditis that is characterized by inflammation of the thyroid gland and the presence of granulomas, often preceded by viral illness.
Physical examination will disclose an enlarged, tender thyroid. Results of laboratory studies will show decreased TSH and increased thyroxine concentrations. Treatment includes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and
glucocorticoids. Patients should be monitored for the development of hypothyroidism in the period following illness.

vignette:
28. Seven days after cesarean delivery for arrest of descent, a 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, remains in the hospital because of spiking temperatures to 39.2°C (102.5°F) since delivery. Treatment with broad-spectrum

antibiotics has not resolved the fever. She feels well when she does not have a fever. Laboratory studies at 35 weeks’ gestation were positive for Streptococcus agalactiae (group B), and she was treated with intrapartum

penicillin. Her temperature now is 38.3°C (101°F). Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis is an uncommon sequela of pregnancy that should be considered in this patient who is persistently febrile despite appropriate antibiotic treatment for endometritis. It is more common in patients with
existing pelvic infections at the time of delivery, such as endometritis or chorioamnionitis, and in those that have cesarean deliveries. It occurs due to the combination of pelvic vein inflammation (often from surgery or infection),
venous stasis, and the hypercoagulability of pregnancy, leading to thrombosis of the ovarian or other pelvic veins. These thromboses subsequently become infected, leading to persistent fevers despite antibiotic therapy. Patients
most commonly present in one of two ways. Patients with septic ovarian vein thrombophlebitis often appear ill, have abdominal pain in addition to their fever, and may have a palpable cord on abdominal examination. Deep septic
pelvic thrombophlebitis presents as this patient did, with minimal features other than a persistent fever and with the patient often feeling well when not febrile. Diagnosis may include laboratory studies with blood cultures or CT
imaging. However, these studies are often unremarkable, making the diagnosis primarily clinical. Treatment includes the addition of systemic anticoagulation to appropriate antibiotic therapy.
educational_objective:
Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis most commonly presents with postpartum fever that is unresponsive to appropriate antibiotics. The patient may appear well between fevers or appear ill with concurrent
abdominal pain. Physical examination, laboratory studies, and diagnostic imaging are all appropriate but are often nondiagnostic. Treatment includes the addition of systemic anticoagulation to appropriate antibiotic therapy.

vignette:
29. A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of generalized fatigue for 1 week. During this period, she has occasionally had light-headedness on standing up quickly. She has not had chest pain or shortness of
breath. She has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is
38/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. S, and S, are normal. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard best at the fourth left intercostal space with radiation
to the carotid arteries. There is no peripheral edema. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
This patient with fatigue, orthostatic hypotension, and ECG showing dissociation of the P waves and QRS complexes has a presentation consistent with third-degree atrioventricular block. Third-degree atrioventricular block occurs
when no sinus impulses are transmitted through the AV conduction pathway, resulting in complete dissociation between atrial and ventricular contraction. Ventricular contraction occurs secondary to a junctional rhythm, which can
cause bradycardia and decreased cardiac output. ECG shows P waves that are present at regular intervals and QRS complexes that are present at regular intervals; however, the P waves and QRS complexes have no association
with each other. Patients can present with variable symptoms depending on the rate of the escape rhythm stimulating the ventricles. Symptoms include fatigue, dyspnea, chest pain, and presyncope. Patients may also present with
syncopal episodes or sudden cardiac arrest. Bradycardia is common. Treatment for all patients with third-degree atrioventricular block is insertion of a cardiac pacemaker.
educational_objective:
Third-degree atrioventricular block occurs when no sinus impulses are transmitted through the AV conduction pathway, resulting in complete dissociation between atrial and ventricular contraction. ECG
shows complete dissociation between the P waves and the QRS complexes. Treatment is insertion of a cardiac pacemaker.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
30. A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain 1 hour after he ate dinner. He receives no medications. Immunizations are up-to-date. He
was adopted at birth, and there is no information available about his biological family history. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure 85/60 mm Hg. Examination
shows conjunctival icterus. There is guarding and moderate tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant. The spleen tip is palpable. Results of laboratory studies are shown:
Hemoglobin 8.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 11,000/mm?
Reticulocyte count 1%
Serum total bilirubin 4 mg/dL
Direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test result is negative. A blood smear shows small, uniform, spherical erythrocytes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's abdominal pain?
correct_explanation:
This patient with evidence of hemolytic anemia, high reticulocyte count, and a blood smear demonstrating small, uniform, spherical erythrocytes likely has hereditary spherocytosis. Hereditary spherocytosis can occur if there are
mutations in one or more proteins (eg, spectrin, ankyrin, band 3, and band 4.2) that link the erythrocyte inner membrane skeleton to the outer lipid bilayer. These mutations are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
Spherocytosis results from the progressive loss of erythrocyte membrane over time and gives the erythrocytes a spherical shape as the surface area decreases but the volume of the cell remains unchanged. This impairs the
erythrocyte’s ability to conform in small vessels of the microcirculation, especially within the spleen, where spherocytes accumulate. Patients often present with splenomegaly, hemolytic anemia, and pigmented gallstones which can
lead to biliary colic as seen in this patient. Peripheral smear will show spherocytes, which are dense, dark cells with loss of central pallor. Reticulocytes may be seen during acute hemolytic episodes, which appear as larger pale
blue erythrocytes. Definitive management involves splenectomy. In this scenario, biliary colic is the most likely cause of the patient’s abdominal pain secondary to gallstones formed from hyperbilirubinemia.
educational_objective:
Autosomal dominant mutations in ankyrin, spectrin, and band erythrocyte membrane proteins cause hereditary spherocytosis through loss of the normal connection between the inner membrane skeleton and
the outer lipid bilayer. Clinical symptoms can include jaundice, splenomegaly, hemolytic anemia, and biliary colic secondary to production of pigmented gallstones because of an increase in bilirubin concentration. A peripheral blood
smear typically exhibits spherocytes and reticulocytes. Definitive treatment is splenectomy.

vignette:
31. Aprospective multicenter study is conducted to determine if an oxygenation index (Ol) greater than 20 predicts death in patients who develop acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) after a bone marrow
transplantation. A total of 120 patients are enrolled. The results show:
—iaatients With ARDS
Number of Patients Number of Patients Total Number
With O1s20 With OI>20 of Patients
Survived 25 20 45
Died 15 60 75
Total 40 80 120
According to these results, which of the following represents the sensitivity of this index?
correct_explanation:
Sensitivity is the ability of a test to detect a disease if it is present. High sensitivity is therefore useful for ruling out a disease. Sensitivity can be calculated by the equation: sensitivity = (true positives) / (true positives + false
negatives), or TP/(TP+FN). The cutoff values for a test can be adjusted to optimize disease detection, resulting in changes to sensitivity and specificity by changing the number of false negatives and false positives. In the given
scenario, true positives represent patients with an oxygenation index (Ol) greater than 20 who later died, while false negatives represent patients with an Ol less than 20 who later died. The sensitivity can be calculated as:
sensitivity = 60 / (60 + 15) = 60 / 75 = 0.8, or 80%.
educational_objective:
The quality of a diagnostic test is measured by its sensitivity and specificity. High sensitivity tests are required for effective disease screening. Sensitivity can be calculated by dividing true positive results by
the sum of true positives and false negatives. In this example, sensitivity = 60 / (60 + 15) = 60 / 75 = 0.8, or 80%.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
32. An otherwise healthy 47-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of hot flashes that began 8 months ago and have become more frequent during the past 3 months. Menses now occur at

irregular 40- to 60-day intervals with light flow and last 2 to 3 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 months ago. Her pulse is 85/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Examination, including

pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
The most appropriate next step in management is the discussion of hormone therapy to treat this patient’s symptoms of menopause. As women age, their ovarian reserve is depleted and they have fewer ovulatory cycles until
menstruation stops completely, referred to as menopause, which typically begins around age 50 years. Menopause is characterized by the lack of ovarian estrogen production, resulting in manifestations such as vaginal atrophy, hot
flashes, and night sweats. Sleep disturbances and mood changes may also be present. In response to decreased estrogen concentrations, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) lack negative feedback
and are increased in the serum. Menopause is often a clinical diagnosis, but these laboratory values may be obtained if the diagnosis is unclear. Because many of the symptoms of menopause are caused by a deficiency of
estrogen, hormone replacement therapy (HRT) with estrogen (either with or without progesterone) mitigates many of the adverse effects of menopause. While HRT has been attributed to an increased risk for breast cancer,
hypercoagulability, and cardiovascular mortality, it is generally considered safe for a limited period of time at the lowest effective dose in patients who are otherwise healthy or at average risk for cardiovascular disease. The decision
whether to start HRT is individual, and the discussion should be tailored to each patient.
educational_objective:
Menopause often presents at approximately age 50 years with amenorrhea, hot flashes, night sweats, vaginal atrophy, sleep disturbances, and mood changes. These symptoms are caused by a deficiency in
estrogen secondary to depletion of ovarian reserve. Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen and/or progesterone often alleviates these symptoms. While hormone replacement therapy has been attributed to an increased risk
for breast cancer, hypercoagulability, and cardiovascular mortality, it is generally considered safe for a limited period of time at the lowest effective dose in patients who are otherwise healthy or at average risk for cardiovascular
disease.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
33. A 28-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination 2 days after undergoing HIV antibody/antigen testing. The patient is sexually active with only men and uses condoms inconsistently. He is asymptomatic

and has no history of serious illness. He takes no medications. Results of HIV antibody/antigen testing 6 months ago were negative. The patient does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is 180 cm (5

ft 11 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 Ib); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 724/mm3 (Normal2500), and plasma HIV viral load is 169,000

copies/mL. Results of serum studies are within the reference ranges. When told of his diagnosis, the patient begins to cry and is comforted by his mother. In addition to expressing empathy, the most appropriate next step

in management is to address which of the following with the patient?

choices.text: How to tell family and friends about the diagnosis
The possible stigma associated with a positive HIV antibody test result

correct_explanation:
After a patient expresses emotional distress about a medical condition, the physician should initially focus on feelings rather than facts and encourage the patient to elaborate on their emotions in an open-ended way. Listening to
this patient's concerns and validating the underlying fears about having HIV infection will decrease the patient's distress and improve the therapeutic alliance. Encouraging elaboration will also increase the physician’s understanding
about the source of the patient’s distress and allow the physician to tailor further discussion to the patient’s specific concerns. HIV infection can present with diffuse lymphadenopathy, diarrhea, sore throat, malaise, fever, and weight
loss. Patients may also present with opportunistic infections or may be entirely asymptomatic. Therapy typically includes a combination of at least three different drugs from at least two different antiretroviral classes. Patients who
receive prompt treatment and exhibit long-term compliance can be expected to live an equivalent life span to those who do not have HIV infection.
educational_objective:
After a patient expresses emotional distress about a medical condition, the physician should initially focus on feelings rather than facts and encourage the patient to elaborate on their fears and emotions in an
open-ended way.

vignette:
34. A 37-year-old man comes to the office for a routine follow-up examination. He has a 7-year history of bipolar disorder, most recent episode depressed, that has been well controlled for 18 months with lithium carbonate,
valproic acid, fluoxetine, propranolol, and levothyroxine. He had two manic episodes, 7 and 2 years ago, that resulted in psychiatric hospitalizations. The episodes were preceded and followed by 6 months of depression.
Physical examination today shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination his mood is normal. He says that he feels fine and would like to discontinue all or some of his medications. Discontinuation of which of the
following medications is most likely to increase this patient's risk for suicide?
correct_explanation:
Lithium carbonate is a mood-stabilizing medication used for treatment of acute mania and maintenance treatment for bipolar disorder (BD) to prevent the recurrence of manic or depressive episodes. It is also used to treat refractory
major depressive disorder (MDD). Lithium carbonate’s mechanism of action is unclear but is thought to involve altered cation transport, modulating reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, and exerting a neuroprotective effect. It
has antisuicide properties independent of its mood stabilizing properties. Many studies have shown that lithium carbonate decreases suicide rates for patients with mood disorders over the long term. The decrease in risk for suicide
is most prominent in BD (but is also present in MDD). Thus, discontinuing lithium carbonate is likely to increase this patient’s risk for suicide.
educational_objective:
Lithium carbonate is a mood-stabilizing medication used for treatment of acute mania and maintenance treatment for bipolar disorder. Its mechanism of action is unclear but is thought to involve altered cation
transport, modulating reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, and exerting a neuroprotective effect. Independent of its mood stabilizing properties, lithium carbonate has been associated with a decreased risk for suicide in
patients with bipolar disorder.

vignette:
35. A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 3 weeks after stepping on a nail. He was wearing tennis shoes at the time of the injury. His mother treated the puncture wound by cleansing it with soap and water.

Initially the pain subsided, but it has returned and worsened over the past 3 days; he now refuses to bear weight on the foot. He is afebrile. Examination shows redness around the puncture site; it is tender to palpation. An

x-ray of the foot shows an area of radiolucency with subperiosteal new bone formation of the metatarsal bone. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
correct_explanation:
Osteomyelitis is an infection of bone and bone marrow that typically presents acutely, subacutely, or chronically from direct inoculation or hematogenous spread from a distal site. Risk factors include traumatic injury, diabetes
mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, intravenous drug use, and the presence of prosthetic devices or indwelling hardware. In adults, it commonly occurs through direct spread from an adjacent soft tissue infection, and less
frequently from hematogenous seeding of bacteria to that site. In children, intravenous drug users, and dialysis patients with indwelling lines, hematogenous seeding is common given the propensity for bacteremia and distant
seeding of the involved site. Patients typically experience pain, difficulty bearing weight, and overlying tenderness to palpation. Laboratory studies may show leukocytosis and increased inflammatory markers. On imaging,
osteomyelitis can present with localized osseous erosive changes of the bone as seen on this patient's x-ray. Treatment of osteomyelitis involves prompt administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a
likely cause of osteomyelitis following a puncture wound to the foot, particularly if there has also been exposure to water or moist environments.
educational_objective:
Osteomyelitis is an infection of bone and bone marrow that typically presents acutely, subacutely, or chronically from direct inoculation or hematogenous spread from a distal site. Risk factors include
traumatic injury, diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, intravenous drug use, and the presence of prosthetic devices or indwelling hardware. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a likely cause of osteomyelitis following a puncture
wound to the foot, particularly if there has also been exposure to water or moist environments. Treatment involves the prompt administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
