vignette:
36. A 42-year-old primigravid woman at 34 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of decreased fetal movement. Pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes
treated with insulin. She has no history of serious illness or other pregnancy complications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall. She weighed 82 kg (180 Ib) prior to her pregnancy; BMI was 32 kg/m2. She has had an 18-kg (40-
Ib) weight gain during her pregnancy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. The cervix is not dilated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her
fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 110 mg/dL. A fetal heart tracing is shown. This pattern is unchanged during the next hour. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Bed rest in the left lateral decubitus position

correct_explanation:
Uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxemia can present with late decelerations on fetal heart rate tracing, which are defined as gradual decreases in the fetal heart rate that begin after the peak of uterine contraction and
nadir more than 30 seconds after the initiation of heart rate decline, as seen in this case. Risk factors for the development of uteroplacental insufficiency include diabetes, hypertension, advanced maternal age, anemia, cocaine
use, smoking, coagulopathies, late-term pregnancy, and uterine infection. Fetal hypoxemia and consequent late decelerations can also be caused by severe uterine contractions and maternal hypotension or hypoxia. Treatment
of uteroplacental insufficiency consists of supplemental oxygenation, movement of the patient onto the left side or onto all fours, and intravenous fluids. If late decelerations persist on fetal heart rate tracings, then urgent
cesarean delivery is indicated, as continued uteroplacental insufficiency and resultant fetal hypoxemia will result in deleterious effects on the fetus. This patient has persistent and recurrent late decelerations on her fetal heart
rate monitoring prior to the onset of labor, making urgent cesarean delivery the most appropriate next step in management.
educational_objective:
Uteroplacental insufficiency causes late decelerations on fetal heart rate tracing, which are defined as gradual decreases in the fetal heart rate that begin after the peak of uterine contraction. Risk factors
for uteroplacental insufficiency include diabetes, hypertension, advanced maternal age, cocaine or tobacco use, coagulopathies, prolonged uterine contraction, uterine infection, late-term pregnancy, or maternal hypotension or
hypoxia. Treatment of uteroplacental insufficiency consists of supplemental oxygenation, movement of the patient onto the left side or onto all fours, and intravenous fluids. If these fail and the decelerations are persistent, urgent
cesarean delivery is the

vignette:
37. Apreviously healthy 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of severe right orbital headache. She takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her blood pressure

is 170/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a supple neck. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the left eye and 20/60 in the right eye. The cup:disc ratio is 7:10 in the left eye and 9:10 in the right eye. Neurologic examination shows no

other focal findings. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Acute glaucoma refers to an increase in intraocular pressure and consequent optic nerve damage. Angle closure is the most common cause of acute glaucoma, whereas open-angle glaucoma is typically a chronic and progressive
optic neuropathy. The closure of the anterior chamber angle leads to the sudden accumulation of aqueous humor in the eyeball as well as increased intraocular pressure. Some patients’ eyes are anatomically predisposed to acute
angle closure (eg, lens is too far forward and puts pressure on the iris), as is likely the case for this patient. Secondary causes of acute glaucoma include sulfa-based medications (eg, topiramate) and the accumulation of blood or
inflammation in the angle. Patients typically present with acute unilateral vision loss (as in this case), eye pain, light halos, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Ocular examination commonly shows a red eye, corneal cloudiness, and
a poorly reactive mid-dilated pupil. A high cup:disc ratio (greater than 7:10) is consistent with glaucoma. Gonioscopy, which assists in visualizing the angle closure, confirms the diagnosis. Management involves acute control with
beta blockers, a-adrenergic agonists, miosis-causing medications, and acetazolamide or mannitol to decrease the intraocular pressure. Definitive treatment is laser peripheral iridotomy or cataract surgery.
educational_objective:
Acute glaucoma refers to an increase in intraocular pressure and consequent optic nerve damage. Angle closure is the most common cause of acute glaucoma. Patients typically present with acute vision
loss, eye pain, light halos, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Gonioscopy confirms the diagnosis. Management involves acute control with beta blockers, a-adrenergic agonists, miosis-causing medications, and acetazolamide or
mannitol to decrease the intraocular pressure. Definitive treatment is laser peripheral iridotomy or cataract surgery.

vignette:
38. A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a progressive rash and easy bruising during the past 2 weeks. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She enjoys horseback riding and first
noticed the rash on her legs when she took off her riding boots. She initially believed it was caused by the long time spent horseback riding that day. Her pulse is 62/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is
113/77 mm Hg. Examination shows a blood-filled blister on the right buccal mucosa. There is a petechial rash over both shins and dorsum of the feet. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 9000/mm%. Prothrombin time
is 12 sec (INR=1.1) and partial thromboplastin time is 29 sec. Results of thyroid, liver, and renal function tests are within the reference ranges. A blood smear shows decreased platelets. Which of the following is the most
appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is caused by autoantibodies against platelet surface antigens, most commonly glycoprotein Gpllb/Illa. It can be primary or secondary to a variety of disorders, such as HIV, hepatitis C,
systemic lupus erythematosus, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, and following viral illness. It may be idiopathic. It typically presents with thrombocytopenia, with platelet counts commonly less than 100,000/mm°. Patients often present
with petechiae, purpura, and mucosal bleeding (eg, epistaxis, vaginal bleeding, gastrointestinal bleeding), which may occasionally result in profound hemorrhage if severe. Laboratory studies are otherwise unremarkable, but bone
marrow biopsy often shows megakaryocyte hyperplasia. It can be treated with corticosteroids, such as prednisone, and intravenous immunoglobulin but may require splenectomy in refractory cases. As the antibodies responsible
for ITP are typically IgG antibodies, which can cross the placenta, in cases of pregnancy the fetus may be at risk for autoantibody-mediated destruction of platelets.
educational_objective:
Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by autoantibodies against platelet surface antigens, most commonly glycoproteins Gpllb/Illa. It has many causes, and treatment includes administration of
corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulin, and splenectomy. It can resolve spontaneously, but in some cases may persist for a prolonged duration. Complications include bleeding.

vignette:
39. A69-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine examination. He says he feels well. He has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and osteoarthritis. His medications are lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and lovastatin. He
smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 8 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test to decrease
this patient’s risk for a cardiovascular event?
correct_explanation:
Abdominal aortic aneurysms most commonly occur in male smokers with a positive family history and a history of atherosclerotic disease. Other risk factors include hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, and trauma. They
commonly occur in the infrarenal abdominal aorta and may present as a palpable, pulsatile abdominal mass if large and in a thin patient. Ruptured aneurysms require emergent surgical intervention and repair. Chronic aneurysms
are typically asymptomatic. The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends using ultrasonography to screen for abdominal aortic aneurysms in men aged 65 to 75 years who have a history of tobacco
use.
educational_objective:
Chronic abdominal aortic aneurysms are typically asymptomatic. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends using ultrasonography to screen for abdominal aortic aneurysms in men
aged 65 to 75 years who have a history of tobacco use.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
40. Apreviously healthy 37-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-week history of intermittent difficulty swallowing solids and liquids. The patient describes a sensation of something lodged in the center of his chest

and says that the sensation is often painful. He has not had any other symptoms. He takes no medications. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
This patient likely has a diffuse esophageal spasm. Diffuse esophageal spasm presents with severe dysphagia and chest pain, often acutely in the setting of swallowing. Patients typically present with abrupt onset chest pain, lasting
for a few minutes to hours, that is often self-terminating and frequently in response to the consumption of a triggering food or in the presence of an impacted food bolus. It may also occur in the absence of swallowing, such as in
association with gastroesophageal reflux disease. Barium swallow would show a “corkscrew” esophagus. Esophageal manometry can also be used in the diagnosis of esophageal spasm, which measures the pressure generated
along the length of the esophagus and lower esophageal sphincter. Spasms are typically not associated with weight loss or vomiting of undigested food.
educational_objective:
Diffuse esophageal spasm presents with severe dysphagia and chest pain, often acutely in the setting of swallowing. It may also occur in the absence of swallowing, such as in association with
gastroesophageal reflux disease. Barium swallow would show a “corkscrew” esophagus, not a focal hypopharyngeal diverticulum. Symptoms last for a few minutes to hours and are often self-terminating.

vignette:
41. An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of vaginal discharge and itching. She has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic

examination shows erythema of the perineum and thin, white vaginal discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Wet mount preparation of the discharge shows epithelial cells and a small number

of leukocytes. Addition of KOH preparation to the discharge produces no odor. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
correct_explanation:
The most likely explanation for the findings in this prepubertal patient with nonpathologic vaginal pruritus, an erythematous perineum, and nonpathologic vaginal discharge is nonspecific vulvovaginitis. Vaginal odor may also be
present. Risk factors include poor genital hygiene, exposure to irritating substances (eg, soaps, bubble baths), tight clothing, and obesity. While nonspecific vulvovaginitis is a common cause of vulvovaginitis in this age group, other
causes (eg, infection and foreign body) should be ruled out with appropriate evaluation. This typically includes physical examination, vaginal culture, wet mount and potassium hydroxide testing of the vaginal discharge, and nucleic
acid amplification testing for sexually transmitted infections (eg, Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis) for patients who may be at risk. These tests would all be expected to be normal in nonspecific vulvovaginitis, as
they were in this case.

vignette: TBD
educational_objective:
Nonspecific vulvovaginitis is a common cause of vulvovaginitis in prepubertal patients. It commonly presents with vaginal pruritus and odor, an erythematous perineum, and nonpathologic vaginal discharge.
Risk factors include poor genital hygiene, exposure to irritating substances (eg, soaps, bubble baths), tight clothing, and obesity. Other causes of vulvovaginitis (eg, infection and foreign body) should be ruled out with appropriate
evaluation, including physical examination, vaginal culture, wet mount and potassium hydroxide testing of the vaginal discharge, and nucleic acid amplification testing for sexually transmitted infections (eg, Neisseria gonorrhoeae
and Chlamydia trachomatis) for patients who may be at risk.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
42. Four days after undergoing open reduction and internal fixation of an intertrochanteric fracture of the right hip sustained in a fall, a 72-year-old woman has the sudden onset of fever and rigors. A central venous catheter

had been placed preoperatively in the right internal jugular vein for vascular access. She received perioperative cefazolin for 24 hours. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 16/min, and

blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Examination shows a well-healing incision. There are no localizing signs of infection. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented these findings?
correct_explanation:
This patient presents with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension in the postoperative period, which should raise suspicion for sepsis. Given the lack of localizing signs and the well-healing incision, the most likely source of the
infection is her central venous catheter. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) is a common occurrence and can cause significant morbidity and mortality. Unfortunately, practices regarding barrier protections
during placement of central lines may vary. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends hand washing and antisepsis prior to beginning the procedure, followed by use of maximal barrier precautions with sterile
gloves, gown, cap, mask, and a large sterile drape during catheter placement. Central lines should be kept covered and clean, and hands should be washed or sterilized prior to using the line. Central lines should be removed once
they are no longer needed. Blood cultures should be obtained, and the line should be removed as soon as CLABSI is suspected. CLABSI is treated with intravenous antibiotics, intravenous fluids, and pressor support as needed.
educational_objective:
Central line-associated bloodstream infection is a common occurrence and can cause significant morbidity and mortality. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends hand washing and
antisepsis prior to placing a central venous catheter, followed by use of maximal barrier precautions with sterile gloves, gown, cap, mask, and a large sterile drape during catheter placement. Central lines should be removed once
they are no longer needed.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette: TBD

2. Examination of the external

genitalia shows no abnormalities. Insertion of a speculum into the vagina is difficult. The cervix cannot be visualized or palpated. The uterus is not palpable. Pelvic ultrasonography and MRI of the pelvis confirm the

absence of a uterus and ovaries. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Androgen insensitivity syndrome is caused by a defect in the androgen receptor complex resulting in a genetically 46,XY male developing a female phenotype. Testes are present and produce testosterone normally, but absence of
a functioning androgen receptor prevents hormone binding and thereby prevents development of male sexual characteristics. Patients present with female external genitalia, scant pubic and axillary hair, absent uterus and fallopian
tubes, and a rudimentary vagina. Results of laboratory studies will show increased concentrations of testosterone, estrogen, and luteinizing hormone. Menses will not occur because of the lack of cycled progesterone and estrogen,
and the lack of a functional uterus with endometrial lining. The testes of these patients cannot functionally produce sperm, and patients are at high risk for developing testicular malignancy. In order to confirm the diagnosis in this
patient, the next best step in management is karyotype analysis to definitively confirm a 46,XY karyotype.
educational_objective:
Androgen insensitivity syndrome occurs as a result of a defect in the androgen receptor and results in persons with 46,XY chromosomes developing phenotypically female characteristics. Testes are present
and produce testosterone normally, but absence of a functioning androgen receptor prevents hormone binding, and thereby, prevents development of male sexual characteristics. Karyotype analysis is required to confirm the
diagnosis.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
44. A2-week-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 2-day history of sweating while feeding and decreased formula intake. He has not had fever, vomiting, diarrhea, or cough.

He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. On arrival, he appears cyanotic and is in moderate respiratory distress. He is at the 30th percentile for length and 20th percentile for weight.

Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 80/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 80%. A grade 4/6, systolic ejection murmur is

heard best at the middle and upper left sternal borders. Chest x-ray is shown. In addition to a displaced aorta, this patient most likely has which of the following sets of cardiac anomalies?

choices.text: Atrial septal defect (ASD) and left ventricular outflow tract obstruction
ASD and right ventricular outflow tract obstruction
Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and left ventricular outflow tract obstruction
PDA and right ventricular outflow tract obstruction
Ventricular septal defect (VSD) and left ventricular outflow tract obstruction

correct_explanation:
This infant with difficulty feeding, hypoxia, and a “boot-shaped” heart on chest x-ray has a presentation suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot. Tetralogy of Fallot consists of pulmonary infundibular stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular
septal defect (VSD), and right ventricular hypertrophy, resulting in a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis first noted in infancy. Right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction eventually leads to right ventricular hypertrophy. The
murmur heard with tetralogy of Fallot, which is typically a holosystolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border, is caused by RVOT obstruction, not as often by the VSD. Paroxysmal cyanosis that occurs during periods of
crying is a classic presentation, and these episodes are referred to as “tet” spells. Patients amid one of these spells often exhibit rapid, deep breathing, agitation, and progressive cyanosis. These periods of cyanosis occur becaus
of transient obstruction or occlusion of the RVOT leading to decreased blood flow through the pulmonary circulation, although the cause of the underlying transient obstruction is unclear. Treatment of tetralogy of Fallot is with
operative repair, which aims to relieve the RVOT obstruction, close the VSD, and separate the pulmonary and systemic circulation. The procedure is usually performed in the first 6 months of life and almost always within the first
year.
educational_objective:
Tetralogy of Fallot consists of pulmonary infundibular stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy, resulting in a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis first noted in infancy.
The murmur heard with tetralogy of Fallot relates to the underlying ventricular septal defect characterized by a holosystolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border.

vignette:
45. A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of an 8-month history of shaking of her hands that occurs when she tries to do things that require steadiness, such as writing, threading a needle, or
doing art work. Her teachers have reported that her handwriting is sometimes difficult to read. The shaking is worse when the patient is stressed or tired, but she says she is not bothered by it. She has no history of serious
illness and takes no medications. Her father also has mild shaking of the hands. The patient is 157 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 43 kg (95 Ib); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the eyes
shows full ocular movements and mild end-gaze nystagmus. There is a fast tremor of the hands when the patient holds her arms outstretched. When the patient draws spirals and straight lines, the tremor causes waviness
in the figures drawn. There is no dysmetria on finger-nose and heel-shin testing. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Essential tremor is a common adult action tremor that most often presents as a bilateral tremor of the upper extremities. Action tremors are exacerbated by activity and sustained antigravity postures and improve with rest. Essential
tremors specifically are exacerbated by stress and improve with small quantities of alcohol. The tremors may involve more body regions over time, including the extremities, head, voice, and eyes (though this patient’s mild end-
gaze nystagmus may be normal). The pathogenesis of essential tremor is unknown, though it is commonly heritable. Diagnosis is clinical and typically no further diagnostic studies are indicated. The first-line treatment is as-needed
or scheduled propranolol, a beta-blocker medication.
educational_objective:
Essential tremor is a common adult action tremor that most often presents as a bilateral tremor of the upper extremities. The pathogenesis of essential tremor is unknown, though it is commonly heritable.
Stress can worsen the tremor, and alcohol and propranolol can improve it. Diagnosis is clinical.

vignette:
46. An 11-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of a 1-year history of behavioral issues at school. The mother reports her daughter has become more isolated and her grades have fallen from A‘s and B’s to

C’s. The mother is also concerned about her daughter’s appearance. She has dyed her hair green and has an asymmetric haircut. The patient has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. When her mother

leaves the room, the patient says she is tired of everyone at school. She feels that she is "in the wrong body." She also hates her name and would prefer using a gender-neutral one. She states she has felt this way her

entire life but now feels that she has to say something. She has tried to talk with her parents about her feelings, but they dismiss her when she brings up her concerns. The patient says the few friends she has have become

"different" and interested in things she does not really like. She is also upset about her body changes and wants them to stop. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is fully

oriented and exhibits no deficits. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following disorders?

choices.text: Measurement of serum luteinizing hormone concentration

correct_explanation:
This patient is experiencing gender dysphoria. A transgender person is an individual whose sex assigned at birth differs from their gender identity, while gender dysphoria is a diagnosis that refers to clinically significant distress
caused by a difference between an individual’s sex assigned at birth and gender identity. Many, but not all, transgender individuals experience gender dysphoria, which commonly motivates them to seek gender-affirming
interventions (eg, changing their name or pronouns, pursuing hormonal or surgical treatment so that their external appearance aligns with their gender identity). An individual's assigned sex is the gender discerned at birth, while
gender identity refers to a patient’s internal sense of their gender. Though many individuals possess a sense of their gender identity as young children, individuals who experience gender dysphoria commonly begin to express their
gender identity in adolescence, during the identity versus role confusion stage of psychosocial development. This patient expresses having a gender identity different from her assigned sex. This is confirmed by her distress over
appearance, name, and expected social roles. Major depressive disorder (MDD) is the most common psychiatric comorbidity for patients with gender dysphoria, followed by specific phobia and adjustment disorder. Gender-affirming
treatment has been shown to decrease MDD and suicide rates.
educational_objective:
Gender dysphoria refers to clinically significant distress caused by a difference between an individual's sex assigned at birth and gender identity. Many, but not all, transgender individuals experience gender
dysphoria, which commonly motivates them to seek gender-affirming interventions. Gender dysphoria is commonly associated with major depressive disorder. Gender-affirming treatment has been shown to decrease major
depressive disorder and suicide rates in transgender individuals.

vignette:
48. A57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain is exacerbated by inspiration. She has no history of exertional chest pain or
shortness of breath. She has received estrogen and progestin replacement therapy since menopause 7 years ago. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 105/min and regular, respirations are 24/min, and blood
pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. A rub and decreased breath sounds are heard over the left posterior hemithorax. Heart sounds are normal. Examination of the lower extremities shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas
analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.48
Peco, 28 mm Hg
Poy 65 mm Hg
An x-ray of the chest shows blunting of the left costophrenic angle and a wedge-shaped opacity in the left lower lobe. An ECG shows right heart strain. Venous duplex ultrasonography of the lower extremities shows no
abnormalities. Ventilation-perfusion lung scans show a perfusion defect in the left lower lobe and are consistent with a high probability of pulmonary embolus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in
diagnosis?

choices.text: Spiral CT scan of the chest

correct_explanation:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of pleuritic chest pain, cough, hypoxia, and tachycardia. This constellation is suggestive of pulmonary embolism (PE). PE is a common disorder caused by occlusion of a pulmonary
artery with resultant impaired blood flow to a segment of lung. Risk factors include immobility, presence of deep venous thrombosis, obesity, recent surgery, pregnancy, use of oral contraceptives, hormone replacement, smoking,
trauma, fracture of long bones, and inherited thrombophilia. PE presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and hypoxia, though seldom are all common features present. PEs are often undetectable on chest x-ray, but emboli
with infarction can be seen on chest x-ray by secondary signs such as wedge-shaped areas of infarction or via the Westermark sign of unilateral oligemia. The test of choice for diagnosis involves CT angiography of the pulmonary
arteries in cases of high pretest probability. However, if the patient is unable to undergo this scan for any reason, a ventilation-perfusion lung scan can suffice for diagnosis, as seen in this case.
educational_objective:
Pulmonary embolism can present with pleuritic chest pain, cough, hemoptysis, shortness of breath, tachycardia, and hypoxia. Diagnosis is commonly made via CT angiography of the pulmonary arteries; a
ventilation-perfusion lung scan can be performed if CT angiography is not readily available or if contraindicated.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
49. An 80-year-old woman, who resides in a nursing care facility, is brought to the office by a nurse because of a 1-month history of moderate lower abdominal pain and constant low-volume urinary incontinence that now

requires use of an absorbent pad. She also has had frequent urinary tract infections during the past year. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and dementia. Her medications are insulin, labetalol, and

donepezil. She appears frail and sits in a wheelchair. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (113 Ib); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows a soft, nontender midline

mass below the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s urinary incontinence?
correct_explanation:
Overflow incontinence is caused by underactive or flaccid detrusor muscles or bladder outlet obstruction and is characterized by chronic urinary retention and a chronically distended bladder. Patients will have increased postvoid
residual bladder volume. It may be caused by physical barriers such as tumors or urethral stricture, neurologic lesions, or an adverse effect of some medications (eg, anticholinergics). This patient’s overflow incontinence is likely
due to neurogenic bladder, potentially related to diabetes mellitus or primary neurologic disease. When the intravesical hydrostatic pressure eventually overwhelms the internal and external urinary sphincter closing pressures, the
patient will experience passive leakage of urine. This patient likely has overflow incontinence with passive leakage of urine, frequent urinary tract infections, and a soft, nontender midline mass in the lower abdomen that is likely a
chronically overdistended bladder. Overflow incontinence is treated with managing inciting conditions, timed voiding, or placement of a urethral catheter.
educational_objective:
Overflow incontinence is caused by underactive or flaccid detrusor muscles or bladder outlet obstruction and is characterized by chronic urinary retention and a chronically distended bladder. Acommon
cause of overflow incontinence is neurogenic bladder. Neurogenic bladder is associated with diabetes mellitus and primary neurologic disease.

vignette:
50. An 18-year-old man is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 1-week history of increasingly severe pain, swelling, and locking sensation in his right knee. Last week, his knee was twisted and bent as he was
pinned during a wrestling match. He was unable to finish the match. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. The skin is intact. Examination of the right knee shows
2+ effusion. Range of motion of the left knee is full. Range of motion of the right knee in extension is limited by pain. McMurray testing of the right knee produces pain over the medial joint line. Lachman and abduction and
adduction stress tests are negative bilaterally. Dorsalis pedis pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to light touch is intact over the lower extremities. X-rays of the right knee show no abnormalities. An MRI of the medial
aspect of the right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Aspiration and manipulation of the knee
Physical therapy and use of crutches

correct_explanation:
The meniscus is a crescent-shaped fibrocartilage pad between the tibia and femoral condyle that helps to dissipate loading forces on the knee. Acute meniscal injuries commonly occur during a twisting motion, with chronic
meniscus injuries usually occurring in older patients because of repetitive degenerative tears. MRI is the imaging method of choice to evaluate the meniscus. Meniscus injuries typically are managed conservatively with rest and
physical therapy if there is minimal swelling, full range of motion, and lack of severe pain or mechanical symptoms, such as knee locking. In the setting of meniscal tears presenting mechanical symptoms, referral to orthopedics for
operative management is indicated. Operative interventions often include open intervention or arthroscopic repair and debridement. This patient is presenting with swelling and locking sensations with an MRI showing meniscus
injury and joint effusion. Because of the mechanical symptoms and continued severe pain, operative management is indicated.
educational_objective:
The meniscus is a crescent-shaped fibrocartilage pad between the tibia and femoral condyle that helps to dissipate loading forces on the knee. Acute meniscal injuries commonly occur during a twisting
motion. Meniscus tears typically can be managed conservatively with rest and physical therapy. In the setting of meniscal tears presenting mechanical symptoms as well as increasing pain and swelling, referral to orthopedics for
operative management is indicated. Operative interventions often include open intervention or arthroscopic repair and debridement.

vignette:
1. A22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a sore throat and difficulty opening his jaw. He has no history of serious illness, and he takes no medications. He is allergic to penicillin. His
temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. There is cervical lymphadenopathy bilaterally. Examination of the throat shows deviation of the uvula to the
right, edema of the soft palate on the left and bilateral pharyngeal erythema with exudates. After drainage of the abscess, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
correct_explanation:
Peritonsillar abscess describes the localized accumulation of pus between the palatine tonsil and the pharyngeal muscles; it is a potentially life-threatening condition because of the risk for local swelling and compression of the
airway. It is most common in adolescents, particularly those with a history of prior tonsillitis or pharyngitis. While the infection is often polymicrobial, gram-positive organisms such as Streptococcus or Staphylococcus species are
often predominant. Patients present with fever, severe neck pain, trismus, localized swelling and fluctuance overlying the tonsil, and may show signs of airway compromise such as a muffled voice or drooling. The diagnosis is
clinical but may be supported by radiography. The mainstay of treatment is needle aspiration or incision and drainage of the peritonsillar space followed by antibiotic therapy. Generally, B-lactams such as amoxicillin or augmented
aminopenicillins with B-lactamase inhibitors such as ampicillin-sulbactam are a suitable initial choice for coverage. However, patients allergic to penicillin, as in this case, may be treated with clindamycin, which provides broad
coverage of gram-positive, gram-negative, and anaerobic bacteria.
educational_objective:
Peritonsillar abscess describes the localized accumulation of pus between the palatine tonsil and the pharyngeal muscles, and it is a potentially life-threatening condition. Patients generally present with fever,
severe neck pain, trismus, localized swelling, and fluctuance overlying the tonsil. Treatment involves drainage of the peritonsillar space as well as antibiotic therapy. First-line antibiotic therapy includes B-lactams, but for those with
penicillin allergy, clindamycin is a suitable option.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
¥

vignette:
2. A 16-year-old boy who was diagnosed with HIV infection 1 year ago comes for a follow-up examination. He has had no opportunistic infections. Immunizations are up-to-date. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 550/mm?
(Normal2500), and plasma HIV viral load is less than 1000 copies/mL, a hundredfold decrease since he began triple antiretroviral therapy 1 year ago. He and his girlfriend are sexually active and use condoms consistently.
His plans for the summer include traveling to Africa for 2 weeks on a medical missionary trip, buying a cat, joining a swim team, and obtaining a part-time job in a day-care center which involves caring for toilet-trained
toddlers. Avoidance of which of the following activities is most likely to minimize his chances of opportunistic infection?
correct_explanation:
Toxoplasma gondii is an intracellular protozoan parasite. Transmission can occur through the ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or infected meat, direct transmission between a mother and fetus, or from organ transplantation,
which leads to invasion followed by dissemination of the parasite where it typically lies dormant. Thus, this patient should avoid cleaning the cat litter. 7; gondii is a ubiquitous organism, and nearly 10% of individuals will be
seropositive for it, but the parasite does not usually cause severe disease in immunocompetent individuals. However, for patients with HIV infection and CD4+ T-lymphocyte cell counts less than 100/mm’, reactivation can occur
with several distinct clinical syndromes, of which cerebral toxoplasmosis has the highest rate of morbidity. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions scattered throughout the brain. Seizures,
focal neurologic deficits, and systemic symptoms are common, as are signs of increased intracranial pressure. Patients with HIV infection and who test positive for Toxoplasma IgG antibodies are typically treated empirically with
sulfonamide and pyrimethamine therapy if cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected, but diagnosis is confirmed by a brain biopsy. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an AIDS-defining disease.
educational_objective:
Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, an intracellular protozoan parasite that is most commonly transmitted via the ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or infected meat. For immunocompromised
patients, particularly patients with HIV infection who have CD4+ T-lymphocyte cell counts less than 100/mmé, it can cause cerebral toxoplasmosis. This typically presents with seizures, focal neurologic deficits, systemic symptoms,
and increased intracranial pressure. Patients with HIV infection and who test positive for Toxoplasma IgG antibodies are treated empirically with sulfonamide and pyrimethamine therapy if cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected.
Diagnosis is confirmed by a brain biopsy. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an AIDS-defining disease.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
3. A 42-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 12 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit. She conceived a dichorionic-diamniotic twin gestation after in vitro fertilization. She has no history of serious
illness, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Two years ago, her first pregnancy ended in cesarean delivery at 39 weeks’ gestation because of breech presentation. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall. She weighed
68 kg (150 Ib) prior to her pregnancy; BMI was 25 kg/m2. She has had a 2-kg (4-Ib) weight gain during her pregnancy. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 12-week
gestation. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following pregnancy complications?
correct_explanation:
Twin pregnancies are identified by ultrasonography and further characterized by their chorionicity and amnionicity, with monochorionic and monoamniotic pregnancies generally associated with a higher risk of neonatal morbidity
and mortality. Preterm labor is the most common complication of twin pregnancies. Other common complications include intrauterine fetal growth restriction and fetal malpresentation, while less common complications include twin-
twin transfusion syndrome, fetal aneuploidy, and umbilical cord entanglement. This patient is at greatest risk for preterm labor, which occurs between 20 and 37 weeks of gestation with regular uterine contractions and accompanied
cervical change. As preterm delivery is associated with a high degree of fetal morbidity and mortality, preterm labor is usually treated with tocolytic therapy, hydration, and bed rest. Corticosteroids are also given to promote fetal lung
maturation if the gestational age is less than 34 weeks. Ultimately, the method of delivery depends on fetal well-being and presentation.
educational_objective:
Twin pregnancies are identified by ultrasonography and further characterized by their chorionicity and amnionicity, with monochorionic and monoamniotic pregnancies generally associated with a higher risk of
neonatal morbidity and mortality. The most common complication of twin pregnancy is preterm labor, or labor that occurs between 20 and 37 weeks of gestation. Preterm labor is typically treated with tocolytic therapy, hydration, and
bed rest. Less common complications of twin pregnancies include intrauterine fetal growth restriction, fetal malpresentation, twin-twin transfusion syndrome, fetal aneuploidy, and umbilical cord entanglement.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
¥

vignette:
4. On arrival to the postanesthesia care unit 15 minutes after undergoing fourth and fifth metacarpophalangeal arthroplasty, a 32-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis has a fingerstick blood glucose concentration of
350 mg/dL. During induction of general anesthesia, endotracheal intubation was complicated by arthritic changes to the cervical spine, and dexamethasone was administered to decrease airway edema. She received
lactated Ringer solution during the 60-minute procedure; intraoperative blood loss was minimal. Medications are prednisone and methotrexate. She is awake. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination
shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hyperglycemia?
correct_explanation:
The administration of glucocorticoids, such as dexamethasone, will induce transient hyperglycemia in patients. Glucocorticoids cause an increase in blood glucose concentration by stimulating the liver to release glucose. Some
other effects of glucocorticoids are reduced inflammation, increased blood pressure as a result of vasoconstriction, increased fat and protein metabolism, and immune suppression. In patients without diabetes, this increased blood
glucose concentration will subside quickly as the pancreas releases increased concentrations of insulin to combat the hyperglycemia. In patients with diabetes, care should be taken when choosing to use corticosteroids as blood
glucose concentration can remain increased for a longer time. Patients should be educated about this effect so that they can manage their medication or diet appropriately. This patient’s presentation is a normal response to
administration of a glucocorticoid, and given their benign physical examination, there should not be any further concern or workup.
educational_objective:
Glucocorticoids cause an increase in blood glucose concentration by stimulating the liver to release glucose. Some other effects of glucocorticoids are reduced inflammation, increased blood pressure as a
result of vasoconstriction, increased fat and protein metabolism, and immune suppression. In patients with diabetes, care should be taken when choosing to use corticosteroids, as blood glucose concentration can remain increased
for a longer time. Patients should be educated about this effect so that they can manage their medication or diet appropriately.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
5. Three days after an operation for aortic stenosis, a 67-year-old white man is being evaluated by the surgical team. A medical student takes one of the two patient information charts hanging outside the room. While reading
the chart, the student realizes that the ethnicity listed on the chart does not match the ethnicity of the patient. Verification of the name on the chart shows that the student has taken the chart for the other patient in the
double room. Both charts are labeled "room 456-1," instead of the chart for the window bed being labeled "456-2." Individual members of the team laugh at the mix-up, and a resident states that the charts are often
misnumbered due to patients shifting room position. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step by the senior member of the team?

choices.text: Emphasize during new intern orientation that chart information is often incorrect
Verbally reprimand the medical student for reading the incorrect chart
Verbally reprimand the members of the team who laughed
Verbally reprimand the nurse who mislabeled the chart

correct_explanation:
Asystems-based approach to error is rooted in an understanding that most errors occur due to a combination of human errors and a system that is designed in such a way that allows errors to occur. When an error occurs, root
cause analysis in combination with a systems-based approach can allow for identification of the underlying factors that lead to human errors, including the environment, equipment and technology, communication, culture, personnel
training, and other personal or human factors. The goal is to understand the underlying factors that allowed the error to occur and to prevent similar errors from happening in the future. In this example, there are several
environmental predispositions to such an error occurring, including patients being frequently moved, and charts being stored outside shared rooms and in a shared location. There is also a broader cultural problem such that errors
are not taken seriously. Finally, there are two human errors on the parts of both the nurse and the intern in mislabeling and misreading the chart. It is important to understand that errors occur due to a variety of failures, and error
prevention must address all of these failures. Hospital quality assurance committees have the expertise to conduct root cause analysis and address systems-based failures that may lead to error.
educational_objective:
A systems-based approach to error is rooted in an understanding that most errors occur due to a combination of human errors and a system that is designed in such a way that allows errors to occur. When
an error occurs, root cause analysis in combination with a systems-based approach can allow for identification of the underlying factors that lead to human errors, including the environment, equipment and technology,
communication, culture, personnel training, and other personal or human factors. Hospital quality assurance committees have the expertise to conduct root cause analysis and address systems-based failures that may lead to error.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
6. A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent mild pain in her right lower abdomen. She has not had fever, chills, changes in bowel habits, or urinary symptoms. Three years ago,
she underwent bilateral prophylactic mastectomy because her maternal grandmother, mother, and two older sisters have a history of breast cancer. The patient has no history of serious illness, and her only medication is a
calcium supplement containing vitamin D. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 116/68 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The
abdomen is soft and nondistended, and the liver is not enlarged. Examination of the right lower quadrant shows tenderness to deep palpation; there are no signs of peritonitis. On pelvic examination, a mass is palpated in
the right adnexal region; no other abnormalities are noted. Pelvic ultrasonography shows an 8 x 6-cm complex, multiseptate, right ovarian mass; there is no ascites. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step
in diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Ovarian cancer most commonly presents with abdominal distension, early satiety, and weight loss in patients who are postmenopausal. Signs and symptoms of advanced disease may also include bowel obstruction with
consequent nausea and vomiting, ascites, pleural effusions, and venous thromboembolism. In addition to these, physical examination may show a palpable adnexal mass on bimanual examination, as it did in this case, or
lymphadenopathy. Ultrasonography is recommended to identify or characterize the responsible lesion, with features including septations, cystic components, blood flow, and a heterogeneous structure. Risk factors for the
development of ovarian cancer include a family history, genetic mutation (BRCA), advanced age, smoking, nulliparity, and pelvic radiation therapy. The diagnosis is confirmed during surgical excision of the lesion, with treatment in
addition to surgery including chemotherapy. This patient has an extensive family history of breast cancer in first-degree relatives, indicating a possible BRCA mutation, as well as a large, septated ovarian mass on ultrasonography,
both of which put her at increased risk for ovarian cancer. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is operative exploration and removal of the mass to determine the diagnosis of possible ovarian carcinoma.
educational_objective:
Ovarian cancer classically presents with abdominal distension, early satiety, and weight loss in a patient who is postmenopausal. A significant risk factor for its development is a genetic mutation in BRCA,
which also increases the risk for breast cancer. Ultrasonography is the diagnostic imaging modality of choice and will show an ovarian mass that is heterogeneous with septations, as well as both cystic and solid components.
Diagnosis is made based on pathology of a surgically removed mass.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
7. A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of increasingly severe right lower abdominal pain. During this time, he also has had fever, nausea, and vomiting. He has not had chills. He
has no history of serious illness or operative procedures and takes no medications. Temperature is 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 120/60 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no
abnormalities. On abdominal examination, a 6 x 8-cm, tender mass is palpated in the right lower quadrant. There is no overlying erythema or induration. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 6 x 8-cm fluid collection
with an enhancing rim in the right lower quadrant. In addition to intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Appendicitis classically presents with right lower quadrant tender abdominal pain that is often periumbilical at onset with associated nausea, anorexia, fever, and leukocytosis. McBurney point, a sensitive location for tenderness on
palpation, is located at two-thirds the distance between the umbilicus and the inguinal ligament, as this is the common position of the appendix. Diagnosis is facilitated by CT scan, MRI, or ultrasonography, which may show
appendiceal enlargement, the presence of an appendicolith, appendiceal wall thickening, or periappendiceal fluid or fat stranding. In cases of perforated or ruptured appendicitis, an abscess can form. Treatment of appendicitis is
with urgent laparoscopic appendectomy to prevent complications, such as appendiceal rupture, sepsis, and death. In cases of stable patients with perforated appendicitis with associated abscess, intravenous antibiotics and
percutaneous drainage is preferred as there is a shorter length of hospital stay and fewer complications than with immediate operative intervention. In addition, percutaneous drainage may allow for inflammation to decrease in the
area prior to appendectomy, which may negate the need for extended bowel resection. In this scenario of a hemodynamically stable patient, the next best step in management is percutaneous drainage.
educational_objective:
Appendicitis typically presents with right lower quadrant tender abdominal pain that is often periumbilical at onset with associated nausea, anorexia, fever, and leukocytosis. Diagnosis is facilitated by CT scan,
MRI, or ultrasonography. In cases of perforated or ruptured appendicitis, an abscess can form. Treatment of appendicitis is with urgent laparoscopic appendectomy to prevent complications, such as appendiceal rupture, sepsis, and
death. In cases of stable patients with likely perforated appendicitis and associated abscess, intravenous antibiotics and percutaneous drainage is preferred as there is a shorter length of hospital stay and fewer complications than
with immediate operative intervention.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
8. A77-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of pain, numbness, and stiffness of her right forearm and hand. She has hypertension and atrial fibrillation. She had a myocardial
infarction 2 years ago. Her medications are metoprolol, lisinopril, and warfarin. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 60/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg.
Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The right forearm and hand are pale and cool with a capillary refill time of 8 seconds. Pulses are absent in the distal aspect of the right upper extremity. The right
axillary pulse and pulses in the left upper extremity are within normal limits. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 72/min. There are no acute changes. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.3 g/dL
Hematocrit 37%
Leukocyte count 10,500/mm°
Platelet count 354,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 14 sec (INR=1.5)
Partial thromboplastin time 27 sec
She is scheduled for embolectomy in 90 minutes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Addition of adenosine to the medication regimen
Addition of sodium nitroprusside to the medication regimen
Application of a heating pad to the right upper extremity

correct_explanation:
This patient with acute onset of severe arm pain, pallor, and pulselessness in the setting of a subtherapeutic INR has a presentation suggestive of acute critical limb ischemia. Thromboembolic events can cause critical limb
ischemia in patients with otherwise relatively normal peripheral vasculature. The most common cause of emboli to the lower extremity is from the heart, related to a variety of underlying pathology, such as atrial fibrillation in this
patient. Although she is on anticoagulation, her INR is in the subtherapeutic range, making her at risk for developing a cardiac thrombus. Symptoms of a thromboembolic event of the extremity include acute pain, swelling, pallor,
and pulselessness. Late manifestations include muscle and nerve death with severe pain and possible compartment syndrome. If acute limb ischemia is suspected, vascular surgery should be consulted immediately, and a heparin
drip should be started while awaiting definitive management with thrombectomy.
educational_objective:
Acute limb ischemia presents with severe pain, pallor, pulselessness, poikilothermia, and paresthesia. Patients with atrial fibrillation who are not adequately anticoagulated are at increased risk. Patients
should be started on anticoagulation immediately while awaiting definitive management with thrombectomy.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
9. A45-year-old woman comes to the physician requesting a second opinion of a recent diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS). She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and asks if cigarette smoking contributed
to her current condition. The physician finds a recently published study evaluating the relationship between cigarette smoking and MS. A total of 100,000 women between the ages of 18 and 40 years were polled about their
medical and social histories over a 10-year period. Data show that 205 participants reported developing MS. The rates of cigarette smoking in participants with MS were compared with those of 615 age- and
location-matched participants without MS. Which of the following best describes this study design?
correct_explanation:
This study compares one group of patients (ie, cases) with an outcome under study (eg, multiple sclerosis), against a second matched group (ie, controls) without that outcome and identifies the associated exposure within each
group (eg, smoking). This study design is known as a case-control study. Case-control studies can be conducted in a prospective or retrospective manner but are always observational studies. By grouping patients by outcome and
comparing differences in the odds of exposure, case-control studies can detect associations between exposure and outcome, such as exposure to smoking and outcome of developing multiple sclerosis in this study. This is
described statistically as an odds ratio (OR). Two unrelated variables will have an OR of 1.0, whereas positive association between an exposure and an outcome will have an OR greater than 1.0, and negatively associated
variables will have an OR less than 1.0. Case-control studies are therefore capable of establishing association between the exposure and outcome, but they do not establish causality.
educational_objective:
Case-control studies group patients according to disease outcome status and analyze the odds of exposure to a particular hazard. The appropriate statistical measure of case-control studies is the odds ratio.
Case-control studies can establish association between the exposure and outcome, but they do not establish causality.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
10. Apreviously healthy 57-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of a 7-hour history of palpitations. He takes no medications. He drinks six beers daily. He does not smoke. He is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and

weighs 70 kg (155 Ib); BMI is 25 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 126/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an

oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows no jugular venous distention. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. There is no pedal edema. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative. An ECG shows

atrial fibrillation at a ventricular rate of 114/min with no ischemic changes. The physician decides to administer oral digoxin. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to record an order on this patient's chart?
correct_explanation:
The appropriate writing of prescriptions and orders is crucial for accurate delivery of care and for patient safety. In many settings, the use and design of electronic medical records has been designed to minimize the opportunity for
prescriber errors. However, in many other settings, including this scenario, orders may need to be entered manually by the physician or written by hand. Orders must be written clearly and unambiguously. When writing by hand,
special attention must be paid to legibility. A variety of common errors and pitfalls are encountered in order writing. The placement and legibility of decimal points is a common problem and can lead to dangerous overdosing or
underdosing. Decimal points should be unmistakable and should be avoided when they are not necessary. Units should be unambiguous and written out fully when necessary to avoid confusion. Both “mcg” and “yg” can be
mistaken for “mg” and should be avoided. Of the choices given, writing “Digoxin 0.125 mg PO daily” is the most clear and unambiguous choice.
educational_objective:
Orders must be written clearly, legibly, and unambiguously because mistakes in interpretation of an order can lead to inaccurate delivery of care and dangerous overdoses or underdoses of a medication. The
physician should be alert to ways in which an order can be misinterpreted. Ambiguous decimal points, usage of “qd” or “qid,” and ambiguous units of measure are all common sources of preventable error. Of the choices given,
writing “Digoxin 0.125 mg PO daily” is the most clear and unambiguous choice.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
11. A37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 12 hours after the onset of severe epigastric pain that radiates to her back. Two weeks ago, abdominal ultrasonography showed gallstones, and she began a

low-fat diet. She has no other history of serious illness. On arrival, her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 28/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Abdominal examination

shows distention and ecchymoses over the periumbilical area. There is diffuse severe tenderness of all quadrants. Bowel sounds are absent. Serum studies show a total bilirubin concentration of 1 mg/dL, amylase activity

of 1400 U/L, and lipase activity of 950 U/L (N=14—280). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: 24-Hour urine collection for measurement of amylase activity

correct_explanation:
The patient’s increased activity of lipase and amylase in the setting of typical epigastric pain and history of gallstones are most consistent with acute pancreatitis. While there are numerous causes of acute pancreatitis, the most
common nontraumatic causes include gallstones and heavy alcohol consumption. Gallstones form in the setting of lithogenic bile and may subsequently pass out of the gallbladder through the cystic duct and eventually reach the
common bile duct. The main pancreatic duct also connects to the distal common bile duct, which is a conduit for pancreatic enzymes to reach the duodenum. If gallstones become lodged in the distal aspect of the common bile
duct, obstruction of pancreatic flow can lead to the release and activation of pancreatic enzymes within the pancreas, which causes substantial inflammation and pain. Additionally, as the flow of bile toward the duodenum is
obstructed, patients can develop hyperbilirubinemia and increased liver enzymes. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is often performed as a diagnostic step to evaluate for pancreatitis or other underlying causes of abdominal
pain. Treatment for gallstone pancreatitis is either with cholecystectomy and intraoperative cholangiography, or in most cases, with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) to retrieve the obstructing gallstone.
While awaiting procedural intervention, patients should be treated with intravenous fluids, pain medications, and antibiotics if there is suspicion for biliary tree infection. This patient most likely has acute pancreatitis and the most
appropriate next step in diagnosis is CT scan of the abdomen with contrast.
educational_objective:
Gallstone pancreatitis occurs when a gallstone becomes lodged in the common bile duct at a point distal to where the pancreatic duct enters the common bile duct. It typically presents with acute epigastric
pain and increased lipase and/or amylase activity. In this scenario of suspected acute gallstone pancreatitis, the

vignette:
12. A72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressive shortness of breath with exertion and nonproductive cough. She has systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) treated with lisinopril and
prednisone. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tight facial skin and telangiectasias over the cheeks. There is thick, taut skin
over the fingers. Bilateral basilar crackles are heard. On cardiac examination, a right ventricular heave is palpated at the left sternal border where a grade 2/6, systolic ejection murmur is also heard best. A fixed, split S, and
an S, gallop are heard. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
This patient with dyspnea, dry cough, a right ventricular heave, and an ECG showing multifocal atrial tachycardia has a presentation suggestive of cor pulmonale. Cor pulmonale describes right heart failure secondary to chronic
pulmonary pathology with increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right-sided heart pressures. It can result from any pulmonary pathology that increases pulmonary vascular resistance, examples of which include but are not
limited to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, interstitial lung disease, thromboembolic disease, systemic scleroderma, or primary pulmonary hypertension. If untreated, the persistent increase in pulmonary vascular resistance
will result in right heart failure, which presents with jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, right ventricular hypertrophy, and hepatomegaly with or without ascites. Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause, which in
this patient’s case is likely her systemic scleroderma.
educational_objective:
Cor pulmonale describes right heart failure secondary to chronic pulmonary pathology with increased right-sided heart pressures. It can result from any pulmonary pathology that increases pulmonary
vascular resistance.

vignette: TBD

1. Pelvic examination

shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 2.4 yU/mL, follicle-stimulating hormone concentration of 76 mIU/mL, and prolactin concentration of 13 ng/mL. Which of the

following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
The most appropriate next step in diagnosis of this patient is a karyotype analysis. Turner syndrome is a common cause of primary amenorrhea, which is secondary to ovarian dysgenesis in the setting of a 45,XO genotype. Other
signs of Turner syndrome include a short stature, cystic hygroma or webbed neck, swelling in the hands/feet, coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, horseshoe kidney, and infertility. Additionally, patients with a decreased
estrogen concentration fail to develop secondary sexual characteristics, such as breasts, and show an underdeveloped uterus. Vital signs will be within normal limits, and diagnosis is made through a karyotype analysis. Other
laboratory studies that may aid in diagnosis are increased concentrations of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) caused by the lack of negative feedback from estrogen. Turner syndrome management in
adolescents commonly involves monitoring for cardiac complications, growth hormone replacement, and estrogen replacement to promote increased development of secondary sexual characteristics.
educational_objective:
Turner syndrome is a cause of primary amenorrhea, which is secondary to ovarian dysgenesis in the setting of a 45,XO genotype. Other signs of Turner syndrome include a short stature, cystic hygroma or
webbed neck, swelling in the hands/feet, coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, horseshoe kidney, infertility, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics. Laboratory studies will typically show increased luteinizing hormone
and follicle-stimulating hormone concentrations. Diagnosis is made with a karyotype analysis.

vignette:
14. Ina recent study of Americans, the following data were presented:
Mortality Rate From Firearms
Group (per 100,000)
Native 2.2
African 1.2
Caucasian 0.8
Asian 0.1
The authors concluded that, in the USA, a greater number of Native Americans died of injuries sustained from firearms than did Caucasian Americans. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of the
authors’ conclusion?

choices.text: Incorrect, because of the cohort effect
Incorrect, because the conclusion is not adjusted for socioeconomic factors
Incorrect, because the conclusion is not adjusted for urban/rural differences

correct_explanation:
Correct interpretation of statistical data is important both when conducting clinical research and when applying research data clinically. Epidemiologic data in clinical research is often presented as a rate per unit of population. Rates
are often used to describe incidence, which is the number of new cases expressed as a percentage of the total population at risk over a specified period of time. When presented as a rate, the absolute number of cases is therefore
dependent on the size of the population in question. In the given example, while Native Americans had a higher rate of mortality per 100,000 people, the overall Native American population is much smaller than that of the
Caucasian population. Given the current composition of the US population, it is very likely that the authors’ conclusion is incorrect. It is important to be aware of other methods of describing incidence, such as person-time rate (ie,
number of incident events divided by the number of years each individual was observed, added for all individuals), or incidence risk (ie, number of incident events divided by number of individuals, multiplied by 100 to be expressed
as a percentage).
educational_objective:
Epidemiologic data in clinical research is often presented as a rate per unit of population. Rates are often used to describe incidence, which is the number of new cases expressed as a percentage of the total
population at risk over a specified period of time. When presented as a rate, the absolute number of cases is therefore dependent on the size of the population in question. In the given example, while Native Americans had a higher
rate of mortality per 100,000 people, the overall Native American population is much smaller than that of the Caucasian American population. Given the current composition of the US population, it is very likely that the authors’
conclusion is incorrect.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
15. An 8-year-old girl with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder is brought to the office by her mother for a well-child examination. The mother says that her daughter has been generally healthy and has been doing well in
school since beginning long-acting methylphenidate therapy 2 years ago. The mother is concerned about her daughter having to take the medication for an extended period of time. Medical history is otherwise
unremarkable and she takes no other medications. The patient is at the 25th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most
appropriate response to the mother regarding this patient's need for medication?

choices.text: She will likely need increased doses of the medication during adulthood
She will likely need to switch to a different medication as she approaches adulthood
She will outgrow the need for medication during late adolescence

correct_explanation:
Patients with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) exhibit chronic symptoms of hyperactivity, impulsivity, and/or inattention that occur in more than one setting and impair academic, social, and/or emotional function.
Symptoms typically start in childhood. Children with predominant hyperactivity symptoms are unable to sit still and may have difficulty taking turns (thought to result from a dysregulated dopamine reward pathway), whereas children
with predominant inattentive symptoms tend to daydream, process information slowly, and demonstrate difficulty in completing tasks (related to norepinephrine dysregulation). The prognosis of children with ADHD is guarded, as it
has been shown that only 10% to 20% of children with the condition experience symptom remission in adulthood. Stimulants, which include amphetamine salts and methylphenidate, are first-line treatments that increase synaptic
dopamine and norepinephrine. Many children continue to respond well to the same medication at the same dose as they transition into adulthood.
educational_objective:
Attention-deficit/nyperactivity disorder presents with chronic symptoms of hyperactivity, impulsivity, and/or inattention that occur in more than one setting and impair academic, social, and/or emotional
function. The prognosis is guarded, as only a small subset of patients experiences symptom remission by adulthood. Stimulants, which include amphetamine salts and methylphenidate, are first-line treatments that increase
synaptic dopamine and norepinephrine. Many children continue to benefit from the same medication at the same dose as they transition into adulthood.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
