vignette:
17. Four days after undergoing uncomplicated left total hip replacement, a hospitalized 75-year-old man has a 1-day history of progressive confusion. He began ambulating on postoperative day 1 and previously had been

alert, fully oriented, and cognitively intact. He has been receiving hydrocodone for pain as needed; he has requested one dose during the past 24 hours. He has hypertension well controlled with atenolol. He has no other

history of serious illness and takes no other medications. On admission, the patient said he did not drink alcohol; today, his brother says that the patient drinks six to eight 12-oz beers daily. The patient’s temperature is

37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows lateral gaze palsy. The surgical incision is clean, dry, and nonerythematous. Neurologic

examination shows ataxia. On mental status examination, he is alert but not oriented to person, place, or time. He identifies only one of three objects after six attempts. He recalls zero of three objects after 5 minutes.

Results of a complete blood count, measurement of serum electrolyte and glucose concentrations, and liver and renal function tests are within the reference ranges. Urine toxicology screening is negative. An ECG shows

no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Vitamin B,, or thiamine, plays a complex role in neuronal physiology including in axon conduction, glucose utilization, and neurotransmitter synthesis. Thiamine deficiency results in neuronal damage through a mechanism that likely
involves oxidative toxicity. Thiamine deficiency is most commonly encountered in the setting of alcohol use disorder because of poor nutritional intake, thiamine malabsorption, and impaired cellular utilization of thiamine. Thiamine
deficiency causes two potential syndromes: Wernicke encephalopathy and Korsakoff dementia. The classic triad of Wernicke encephalopathy consists of encephalopathy, ataxia, and oculomotor dysfunction as a result of neuronal
damage in the cerebellum, midbrain, and pons. Common ocular manifestations include nystagmus and horizontal gaze palsy caused by damage to the abducens nuclei. Over time, thiamine deficiency can result in damage and
atrophy of the mammillary bodies, visible on MRI of the brain, which manifests as Wernicke encephalopathy. The symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy are reversible but increase the risk for developing Wernicke-Korsakoff
syndrome in chronic alcohol users if not immediately treated with high-dose parenteral thiamine. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is an irreversible condition that features psychosis, anterograde and retrograde amnesia, and the
consequent tendency to confabulate, or verbalize false stories or memories, to compensate for the inability to remember. This patient presents with classic findings of Wernicke encephalopathy and should be treated with immediate
administration of parenteral thiamine.
educational_objective:
Vitamin B,, or thiamine, deficiency causes Wernicke encephalopathy, characterized by encephalopathy, ataxia, and oculomotor dysfunction. Thiamine deficiency is most commonly encountered in the setting
of alcohol use disorder because of poor nutritional intake, thiamine malabsorption, and impaired cellular utilization of thiamine. Treatment is with intravenous administration of thiamine.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
18. A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of increasingly severe pain of his right knee associated with redness and swelling for the past 6 hours. He has had two episodes of pain in his right

great toe over the past 8 months and missed 2 weeks of work in construction during each episode. He has been otherwise healthy. Examination of the right knee shows marked tenderness, swelling, and erythema.

Laboratory findings are within the reference range except for a serum uric acid concentration of 7.6 mg/dL. Examination of synovial fluid aspirate shows uric acid crystals. Which of the following is the most appropriate

initial pharmacotherapy?
correct_explanation:
This patient is most likely presenting with a gout flare because of his acute symptoms and increased serum uric acid concentration. Gout is an acute, monoarticular arthropathy resulting from an intra-articular inflammatory reaction
to precipitation of monosodium urate crystals. Deposition of uric acid crystals may occur in the surrounding tissues leading to the development of tophi. Gout typically presents with atraumatic joint pain, erythema, and swelling. The
most common joint involved is the first metatarsophalangeal, but other joints include the knees and elbows. Increased intake of foods that are rich in purines such as seafood and red meat has been shown to increase the risk for
gout flares, as they result in increased production of uric acid. Other causes of increased uric acid concentrations include diuretic use, tumor lysis syndrome, alcohol consumption, and obesity. Arthrocentesis generally shows
10,000-50,000 leukocytes/mm? with a mixture of neutrophils and lymphocytes. Needle-like birefringent crystals are shown on microscopic examination. Treatment of an acute flare consists of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
(NSAIDs) such as naproxen or indomethacin as well as colchicine, and/or corticosteroids. The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient is indomethacin.
educational_objective:
Gout is an acute, monoarticular arthropathy resulting from an intra-articular inflammatory reaction to precipitation of monosodium urate crystals. Gout typically presents with atraumatic joint pain, erythema,
and swelling. The most common joint involved is the first metatarsophalangeal, but other joints include the knees and elbows. Treatment of an acute flare consists of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as naproxen or
indomethacin as well as colchicine, and/or corticosteroids.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
*

vignette:
19. A14-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of a 3-week history of cough. One month ago, she had the onset of nasal congestion and runny nose. Two days later, she was noted to have a cough.

The nasal congestion and runny nose resolved spontaneously after 7 days; the cough has not improved. Her father describes the cough as a “dry, smoker’s cough.” The patient has had similar symptoms twice during the

past 6 months. Each episode resolved spontaneously after 2 weeks. At the age of 3 months, she had bronchiolitis. She has eczema treated with topical hydrocortisone. She was born at term following an uncomplicated

pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. She receives no other medications. Her mother has a childhood history of asthma, and her father has seasonal allergies. The patient attends day care 5 days weekly. She

coughs intermittently in the examination room. She is at the 20th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is

103/72 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Asthma, particularly cough-variant asthma, is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. Asthma often presents with episodic wheezing and shortness of breath with or without a cough, but it can also present with an isolated cough.
Patients should be assessed for other atopic symptoms such as allergic rhinitis or eczema as these conditions commonly occur in conjunction with asthma. Other causes of chronic cough include gastroesophageal reflux disease
and rhinosinusitis. Patients in whom asthma is suspected should undergo spirometry with measurement of FEV, and FVC. As asthma is a reversible and episodic condition, spirometry is frequently normal unless the patient is
exhibiting symptoms at or around the time of spirometry. Therefore, most patients undergo a methacholine challenge test. Methacholine is a potent stimulator of bronchoconstriction, and as asthma is defined by airway
hyperreactivity, patients with asthma tend to experience bronchospasm at lower doses of methacholine than patients without asthma. An improvement in FEV, by at least 12% with bronchodilators is diagnostic of asthma. Treatment
depends on the severity but may include short-acting bronchodilators and/or inhaled corticosteroids. In general, diagnoses of asthma are not made prior to 2 to 3 years of age. Infants cough and wheeze for many reasons and
knowing whether primary airway hyperreactivity (a feature of asthma) is present is challenging, as infants are generally not able to perform pulmonary function testing. In the infant age group, if symptoms of bronchoreactivity are
present, physicians may treat the symptoms in the same manner as asthma if a consistent clinical response is detected.
educational_objective:
Asthma may present with an isolated cough in the absence of wheezing or shortness of breath. Diagnosis is made by bronchial provocation with methacholine followed by a response to bronchodilators.
Patients with mild intermittent asthma may be treated with short-acting bronchodilators, but patients with moderate or severe disease often require further treatment with inhaled corticosteroids and/or long-acting bronchodilators. In
the infant age group, if symptoms of bronchoreactivity are present, physicians may treat the symptoms in the same manner as asthma if a consistent clinical response is detected.

vignette:
20. Apreviously healthy 24-year-old nurse is brought to the emergency department because of weakness of the lower extremities for 24 hours. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min,
and blood pressure is 112/78 mm Hg. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the upper and lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na* 134 mEq/L
Cl- 94 mEq/L
K+ 2.4 mEq/L
HCO,” 34 mEq/L
Mg2* 2.4 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL
Glucose 118 mg/dL
Urine
Na* 46 mEq/L
K+ 64 mEq/L
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypokalemia?
correct_explanation:
This patient’s hypokalemia is likely caused by surreptitious diuretic use and factitious disorder. In factitious disorder, patients consciously produce symptoms (eg, purposely injure themselves) for primary gain. Primary gain is the
motivation to be cared for, which constitutes an unconscious motivator for the patient’s conscious production of symptoms. Early losses, neglect, or abuse may disrupt patient identity and relationships, and adopting the sick role
may represent an attempt to cope with stress and stabilize their identity and relationships. In patients with hyponatremia and hypokalemia, normal kidney function would lead to decreased urinary excretion of sodium and potassium.
This patient’s surreptitious use of diuretics led to low serum sodium and potassium concentrations with abnormally increased concentrations of urine sodium and potassium. Treatment of factitious disorder includes regular follow-up
with one physician who oversees management (as opposed to symptom-triggered appointments) and possible psychotherapy.
educational_objective:
Surreptitious diuretic use will lead to hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis with corresponding increased concentrations of urine sodium and potassium.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
21. A 47-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of a nonpainful, nonitchy lesion over his left forearm. Three years ago, he underwent a renal transplant for chronic renal failure secondary to IgA

nephropathy. His only medication is tacrolimus. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely

diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Squamous cell carcinoma is the second most common form of skin cancer after basal cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is related to chronic ultraviolet damage or chronic inflammation. Additional risk factors for
the development of squamous cell carcinoma include immunosuppression, especially in patients with a history of solid organ transplantation. Squamous cell carcinoma usually occurs at sites of chronic sun exposure including the
face, ears, neck, and distal extremities. Squamous cell carcinoma typically presents as a rough plaque or nodule with focal erosion or ulceration and overlying hyperkeratotic scale. Pathology shows parakeratosis, loss of the
epidermal granular layer, full thickness epidermal atypia, keratin pearls, and invasion into the dermis. Squamous cell carcinoma is treated with excision-based therapies, including Mohs micrographic surgery or electrodessication
and curettage. The location of this lesion on sun-exposed skin, chronicity of the lesion, and the patient's immunosuppression status are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma.
educational_objective:
Squamous cell carcinoma is the second most common form of skin cancer and is associated with chronic ultraviolet damage. Additionally, immunosuppression associated with solid organ transplantation
severely increases patients’ risk for development of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. Individual lesions may present as chronic, rough, eroded, or as plaques or nodules with overlying hyperkeratotic crust. Treatment modalities
for squamous cell carcinoma include standard excision, Mohs micrographic surgery, and electrodessication and curettage.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
22. A 62-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of leg swelling and progressive shortness of breath. He has not had fever or cough. He smoked
one and one-half packs of cigarettes daily for 45 years but quit 1 year ago. His medications are theophylline and albuterol and ipratropium inhalers. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are
22/min, and blood pressure is 150/76 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention 10 cm above the sternal angle. Breath sounds are markedly decreased throughout all lung fields. Cardiac examination shows
decreased heart sounds with no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. The liver edge is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. There is 2+ pitting edema to the knees. His FEV, is 1.05 L (40% of predicted). Arterial blood gas
analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.42
Pco, 48 mm Hg
Poy 45 mm Hg
HCO3- 30 mEq/L
An x-ray of the chest shows hyperinflated lungs with apical bullae. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Pulmonary hypertension can be primary (eg, genetic mutation causing smooth-muscle hypertrophy and increased pulmonary vascular resistance) or secondary (eg, obstructive sleep apnea, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease,
chronic venous thromboembolic disease, pulmonary fibrosis, heart failure). It presents with signs of right-sided heart failure including dependent edema, jugular venous distention, and hepatic congestion. Cardiac examination
typically discloses a precordial heave, delayed or loud pulmonic valve closure, and tricuspid or pulmonary insufficiency due to chronic hypertrophy of the right side of the heart. Treatment depends on the cause of pulmonary
hypertension. In this case, the cause is most likely secondary to progression and severity of the patient’s chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Because of this, therapy should be focused on improving oxygenation status.
Given that his Pog is 45 mm Hg, supplemental oxygen should reduce the pulmonary vascular constriction contributing to pulmonary hypertension.
educational_objective:
Pulmonary hypertension can be primary (eg, genetic mutation causing smooth-muscle hypertrophy and increased pulmonary vascular resistance) or secondary (eg, obstructive sleep apnea, chronic
obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic venous thromboembolic disease, pulmonary fibrosis, heart failure). Patients will present with signs of right-sided heart failure and dependent edema, increased jugular venous pressure, and
shortness of breath. Treatment is based on the cause of pulmonary hypertension.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
23. A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of muscle spasms of the face and neck; his eyes appear to be rolling up inside his head. He began treatment with haloperidol 24

hours ago for paranoid ideation. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. He is fully oriented and cognitively intact, but he is adamant that he has

been poisoned. Which of the following is most appropriate to add to his medication regimen?
correct_explanation:
Acute dystonic reactions are involuntary, painful muscle spasms that occur most frequently in response to potent dopamine-2 (D2) antagonists, such as typical antipsychotics (eg, haloperidol). The underlying pathophysiology is an
imbalance in the dopaminergic-cholinergic pathways of the basal ganglia (eg, increased cholinergic activity and decreased dopaminergic activity). Acute dystonic reactions are treated with diphenhydramine or benztropine, which
are both anticholinergic medications that work to restore the proper balance in the dopaminergic and cholinergic pathways. Common presentations include torticollis (ie, head tilted to the side and down), retrocollis (ie, head tilted
back), opisthotonos (ie, arching of the back), and oculogyric crisis (ie, upward deviation of the eyes). Patients rarely present with laryngospasm and stridor. Risk factors for development include male sex, young age, recent cocaine
use, and a history of acute dystonic reaction.
educational_objective:
An acute dystonic reaction most commonly occurs in response to typical antipsychotics. The patient typically presents with torticollis, retrocollis, opisthotonos, and/or oculogyric crisis. Treatment involves
anticholinergic medications, such as diphenhydramine or benztropine. These restore the dopaminergic-cholinergic balance in the basal ganglia.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
24. A60-year-old man with stage 4 chronic kidney disease comes to the office for a follow-up examination. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Medications are insulin, lisinopril, furosemide, amlodipine, and
aspirin. Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 15/min, and blood pressure 145/85 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination discloses no abnormalities. There is 1+ lower extremity edema.
Laboratory studies show a serum intact parathyroid hormone concentration of 258 pg/mL (N=10—60). Measurement of additional serum laboratory studies is most likely to show which of the following?
Phosphorus Calcium Calcitriol
correct_explanation:
One of the complications of long-term diabetes mellitus is diabetic nephropathy. Diabetic nephropathy is a chronic process that occurs following nonenzymatic glycosylation of the glomerular basement membrane and efferent
arterioles, characteristically demonstrating Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions on light microscopy. It progresses over time in patients with diabetes mellitus, initially beginning as microalbuminuria, which can subsequently lead to
macroalbuminuria and then end-stage kidney disease. Secondary hyperparathyroidism is commonly a result of chronic hypocalcemia in the setting of end-stage kidney disease. Hypocalcemia in end-stage kidney disease occurs
as a result of decreased native kidney production of calcitriol (also known as active vitamin D), which leads to decreased systemic absorption of calcium, and an increased concentration of phosphate because of retention by the
kidney. Increased phosphate also complexes with calcium in serum, decreasing the serum total calcium concentration. In patients with chronic kidney disease, 1a-hydroxylase activity is decreased, and thus, calcitriol
concentration is decreased. In turn, hypocalcemia is sensed by the normally functioning parathyroid gland, which increases synthesis of parathyroid hormone to attempt to normalize serum calcium concentration through
osteolysis, conversion of vitamin D, and gastrointestinal absorption.
educational_objective:
Diabetic nephropathy is a chronic process that occurs following nonenzymatic glycosylation of the glomerular basement membrane and efferent arterioles, characteristically disclosing Kimmelstiel-Wilson
lesions on light microscopy. Patients with chronic kidney disease, particularly stage 4 and 5, are known to develop secondary hyperparathyroidism. Laboratory studies show increased parathyroid hormone and phosphorus
concentrations, as well as decreased calcium and calcitriol concentrations.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
25. A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for an initial well-child visit to establish care. The patient's family recently emigrated from Eastern Europe. The mother is concerned about her son's behavior at home
and at school. He has been easily distracted, has difficulty completing his chores at home, has been fidgety during classes, and often disrupts others by talking out of turn. His mother says that as an infant he underwent
surgical correction of a cleft palate and a heart defect, but she does not have his medical records with her today. The patient is at the 5th percentile for height and weight and the 10th percentile for BMI. Examination shows
an elongated face with narrow palpebral fissures, low-set ears, a broad nasal bridge, micrognathia, downward turned mouth, and small teeth. Results of which of the following laboratory studies are most likely to be
abnormal in this patient?
correct_explanation:
Thymic-parathyroid dysplasia, known as DiGeorge syndrome, is a disorder caused by a microdeletion in the 22q11.2 chromosome, which results in abnormal development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. It presents
early in childhood with thymic hypoplasia and impaired immunity, conotruncal cardiac defects (eg, ventricular septal defects, truncus arteriosus), hypocalcemia caused by parathyroid hypoplasia, and craniofacial abnormalities, such
as low-set ears, hypertelorism, micrognathia, and cleft lip and palate. It is also associated with developmental delay, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and autism spectrum disorder. Severe hypocalcemia can lead to seizures
as well as laryngospasm, bronchospasm, and emesis. Results of laboratory studies will show a low calcium concentration and possibly leukopenia. Chest x-ray may show the absence of a thymic shadow, as well as a narrow
mediastinum and right-sided aortic arch, as suggested by this patient's reported history of heart defect. Further evaluation typically includes an echocardiogram and ultrasonography of the kidneys. Treatment is supportive and
calcium repletion is critical, especially in cases of seizures.
educational_objective:
Thymic-parathyroid dysplasia, known as DiGeorge syndrome, can lead to acute hypocalcemia and can present with seizures. Characteristic findings include signs of improper development of the third and
fourth pharyngeal pouches, including low-set ears, hypertelorism, micrognathia, cleft lip and palate, thymic hypoplasia with impaired immunity, and parathyroid hypoplasia with associated hypocalcemia. Treatment is supportive and
calcium repletion is critical, especially in cases of seizures.

vignette:
26. A4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of shortness of breath and wheezing at a birthday party. Witnesses report that he was acting normally until he was noted to be in

distress; they did not see him choke on anything. He has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is

90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Examination shows decreased breath sounds over the left hemithorax. Inspiratory and expiratory chest x-rays are shown. Which of the

following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Acute onset of difficulty breathing and wheezing raises suspicion for foreign body aspiration. Foreign body aspiration can cause obstruction of the airway, leading to impaired oxygenation and ventilation. Young children are at
increased risk for foreign body aspiration because of their ability to stand and mobilize independently, ability to grasp and put small objects into their mouths, and an immature swallowing mechanism. Foreign bodies can be located
anywhere in the airway between the larynx and the bronchi. Children can present with severe respiratory distress, cyanosis, and stridor, or may have a less severe presentation with partial airway obstruction, presenting with cough,
tachypnea, decreased air entry on auscultation, or wheezing. Chest x-ray can show hyperinflation of one lung, which is caused by air trapping and partial airway obstruction in which air is able to pass via inspiration, but not
exhalation. Foreign bodies are typically in the right lung because of the more vertical anatomic position of the right main bronchus. Management of foreign body aspiration involves flexible or rigid bronchoscopy to remove the object.
Object removal is necessary as retained foreign bodies can be complicated by airway inflammation and infection.
educational_objective:
Children with foreign body aspiration can present with respiratory distress, cyanosis, and stridor, or may have a less severe presentation with partial airway obstruction, cough, tachypnea, decreased air entry
on auscultation, or wheezing. Management of foreign body aspiration involves flexible or rigid bronchoscopy to remove the object.

vignette:
27. Ahospitalized 59-year-old man has undergone three unsuccessful attempts at endoscopic sclerotherapy of esophageal varices during the past 4 days. On admission, he had a 1-week history of recurrent upper
gastrointestinal bleeding. He has necrotizing pancreatitis, splenic vein thrombosis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. His medications are insulin, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and pancrelipase. He has a history of
alcohol use disorder but has not consumed alcohol during the past 8 years. He has no other history of psychiatric illness. He is an inmate in a federal prison and has 18 years remaining on his sentence. He asks that no
further efforts to control the bleeding be undertaken. His brother, who has not visited the patient in 6 years, says this is the patient's way of committing suicide; the brother insists that efforts to extend the patient's life be
continued. The patient appears cachectic but alert. His pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 88/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 4 L/min of oxygen by nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of
94%. Physical examination shows scattered ecchymoses and petechiae over the upper extremities. On mental status examination, he provides an accurate account of his current condition and the probable outcome,
including death, if he continues to bleed. He says he is “down” but then says he means “tired.” He reports no suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Attempt to obtain emergency legal guardianship of the patient for medical decision-making
Continue treatment in accordance with the brother’s wishes

correct_explanation:
According to the ethical principle of autonomy, a capacitated patient's wishes about end-of-life care should be respected. There are several methods to determine a patient’s wishes, including communicating with the patient directly
if the patient has capacity, or reviewing advance directives, durable powers of attorney, and consulting with close family members. If these sources of information conflict, a capacitated patient’s wishes supersede the other sources.
To meet the criteria for decisional capacity, patients must express a consistent choice, demonstrate an understanding of the risks and benefits of the choice, demonstrate an appreciation of the significance of the choice for their
personal circumstances, and illustrate an ability to reason through the options. Given the concern for suicidality, the physician has a duty to evaluate the patient for depression and suicidality to ensure that a psychiatric disorder is
not interfering with the patient’s decisional capacity. Not all patients with psychiatric disorders lack decisional capacity, but some patients with depression have an inaccurately bleak outlook on their future. However, this patient
denies depressed mood and suicidality and demonstrates an accurate understanding and appreciation of his future, so he appears to possess decisional capacity. Therefore, his wishes to withdraw care should be respected.
educational_objective:
A capacitated patient's expressed wishes about end-of-life care should be respected. There are several methods to determine a patient’s wishes, including communicating with the patient directly if the patient
has capacity, or reviewing advance directives, durable powers of attorney, and consulting with close family members. If these sources of information conflict, a capacitated patient's wishes supersede the other sources.

vignette:
28. A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 2-hour history of severe weakness involving the right side of her face. The weakness has been present since the patient awoke from
sleep. She is now drooling from the right side of her mouth. She has had an upper respiratory illness for the past 3 days, with symptoms of nasal congestion, cough, and muffling of sounds and pain in her right ear. Medical
history is otherwise unremarkable. She has been taking acetaminophen as needed for the ear pain. Vital signs are normal. The patient is awake and alert. Her speech is dysarthric. The right side of her face is severely
weakened, with inability to sustain eye closure against resistance. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely natural evolution of her condition if left
untreated?

choices.text: Improvement with normalization in 2 to 3 days
Progression to involve the left limbs
Progression to involve the left side of the face
Progression to involve the right limbs

correct_explanation:
Bell palsy refers to a facial nerve palsy that leads to unilateral facial paralysis. It is most commonly caused by viral-mediated inflammation or immune reaction in the setting of herpes simplex or herpes zoster, although it can also be
idiopathic or caused by other viral infections, as in this case. It presents acutely with unilateral facial paralysis that includes the forehead, consistent with its lower motor neuron pathologic involvement. It can also be associated with
loss of taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and decreased lacrimation. Symptoms typically peak around 3 weeks after onset with slow recovery beginning within 6 months. Diagnosis is most commonly based on clinical
symptoms, but electrodiagnostic tests, such as EMG and imaging of the face and head, can be used if the diagnosis is unclear. Initial treatment consists of oral glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, and antiviral therapy in severe
cases.
educational_objective:
Bell palsy refers to isolated facial nerve palsy that is typically secondary to herpes simplex or herpes Zoster, although it can also be idiopathic or caused by other viral infections. Patients present with complete
ipsilateral facial weakness that involves the forehead. Dull ear pain in conjunction with taste abnormalities can also occur. Initial treatment consists of glucocorticoids, and in severe cases, antiviral therapy. Most patients improve
gradually over several months.

vignette:
29. A 56-year-old woman comes to the clinic for examination prior to undergoing a dental procedure. She will be visiting her dentist frequently for multiple procedures to have braces placed on her teeth because of severe

temporomandibular joint pain; she is concerned about her risk for infection. She has mitral valve prolapse and intermittent palpitations. She also has hypertension and osteopenia. Her only medication is atenolol. Her blood

pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated for this patient for which of the following procedures?
correct_explanation:
Endocarditis prophylaxis is recommended for patients with high-risk cardiac features undergoing procedures that put them at increased risk for the development of bacterial endocarditis. These cardiac features include prosthetic
heart valves, prior infective endocarditis, unrepaired congenital cyanotic heart disease or repaired disease with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation near prosthetic material, repaired congenital defects with a catheter-based
intervention (for the first 6 months after the procedure), and valvular regurgitation in a heart transplant recipient. High-risk procedures include dental procedures with gingival manipulation or perforation of the oral mucosa,
respiratory tract procedures in which the mucosa is violated, procedures on infected soft tissue, and cardiac surgery with prosthetic material. Amoxicillin is the most commonly prescribed antibiotic for bacterial endocarditis
prophylaxis and is given as a single dose of 2 g 30 minutes prior to the procedure. This patient does not present with high-risk cardiac features, so there is no indication for endocarditis prophylaxis.
educational_objective:
Indications for endocarditis prophylaxis prior to invasive procedures include prosthetic heart valves, prior infective endocarditis, unrepaired congenital cyanotic heart disease or repaired disease with residual
shunts or valvular regurgitation near prosthetic material, repaired congenital defects with a catheter-based intervention (for the first 6 months after the procedure), and valvular regurgitation in a heart transplant recipient.

vignette:
30. A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for a preoperative evaluation before undergoing elective cataract removal. He has a 3-month history of progressive mild shortness of breath with exertion. He takes no
medications. He drinks three beers daily. His blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. Examination shows no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 26%
Mean corpuscular volume 75 ums
Leukocyte count 6000/mm3
Platelet count 700,000/mm?
Prothrombin time 11 sec (INR=1)
Serum
Glucose 89 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 142 U/L
AST 55 U/L
Urine
Glucose 2+
Protein 1+
Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's hematologic condition?

choices.text: Measurement of serum vitamin B12 (cobalamin) concentration every 2 years
Measurement of serum vitamin B12 (cobalamin) concentration every 2 years

correct_explanation:
Gastrointestinal blood loss resulting in chronic iron deficiency most likely explains this patient’s progressive shortness of breath and laboratory findings of microcytic anemia. Anemia can be an indicator of colorectal cancer. The
United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends routine colorectal cancer screening for all patients at average risk for colon cancer beginning at age 45 years and continuing until age 75 years. Colorectal
cancer is common, and early detection and treatment have been demonstrated to reduce morbidity and mortality. A variety of tests may be used for colorectal cancer screening. Colonoscopy remains the gold-standard screening
test, as it allows direct visualization and excision of polyps throughout the length of the colon. Other direct visualization tests such as flexible sigmoidoscopy may be acceptable in some patients. Other testing strategies include
stool-based tests, such as fecal occult blood and fecal immunochemical tests, and CT colonography. In patients with unexplained iron deficiency anemia (IDA), colonoscopy is necessary to rule out colorectal carcinoma.

educational_objective:
Anemia can be an indicator of colorectal cancer. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends routine colorectal cancer screening for all patients at average risk for colon cancer beginning
at age 45 years and continuing until age 75 years. Colorectal cancer is common, and early detection and treatment have been demonstrated to reduce morbidity and mortality. A variety of screening tests are available, although
colonoscopy remains the gold standard.

vignette:
31. A27-year-old man with asthma comes to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and wheezing for 24 hours. His symptoms began 1 week ago with increasing wheezing. Treatment with
inhaled B-adrenergic agonists and corticosteroids has been ineffective. He appears mildly dehydrated and in moderate to severe respiratory distress with labored breathing and use of accessory muscles. His pulse is
90/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.25
Pco, 51 mm Hg
Po, 65 mm Hg
HCO,” 20 mEq/L
Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with a compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis with a compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with a compensatory metabolic alkalosis

correct_explanation:
Asthma is characterized by reversible obstruction to airflow caused by spasm of smooth muscle in the bronchi and small airways. Asthma often presents with episodic exacerbations that can be triggered by an allergen or other
environmental exposures, exercise, or seasonal changes. Asthma exacerbations present with shortness of breath, cough, tachypnea, increased work of breathing, wheezing, and hypoxemia in severe cases. A variety of acid-base
disturbances can occur in the setting of asthma. Mild asthma exacerbations may lead to hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis. This patient’s arterial blood gas analysis shows an anion gap metabolic acidosis, identified by a pH
of less than 7.35 (acidemia) with decreased HCO3° and increased Pcop. Inadequate respiratory ventilation may lead to hypoxemia, which in turn can cause metabolic acidosis due to end-organ anaerobic metabolism and
production of lactate. Respiratory acidosis can also occur in the setting of severe exacerbations with significant degrees of airway obstruction, leading to retention of CO, despite tachypnea and increased work of breathing.

Metabolic acidosis with a compensatory respiratory alkalosis (Choice A) is incorrect. While this patient’s arterial blood gas analysis shows a metabolic acidosis, he also has an increased Pcoo, suggestive of a mixed respiratory and
metabolic acidosis. Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by a decreased Pcog, which this patient does not have. Respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis will result in hyperventilation and decreased Pcog, but airway
obstruction prevents this compensation from occurring in severe asthma exacerbations.
Metabolic alkalosis with a compensatory respiratory acidosis (Choice B) is incorrect. Metabolic alkalosis can occur from acute hypovolemia, gastrointestinal losses of hydrogen ions, administration of alkali, states of increased
aldosterone, use of loop or thiazide diuretics, Bartter or Gitelman syndrome, or in milk-alkali syndrome due to renal losses of hydrogen ions. Hypoventilation may occur in order to retain COp. This clinical scenario would be
identifiable by an increased serum HCO3° with an increased Pcog. This patient’s arterial blood gas results are not consistent with this diagnosis.
Pure respiratory acidosis (Choice D) occurs as a result of diminished ventilation and retention of acidic COj, most commonly from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or asthma, obesity-hypoventilation syndrome, sleep apnea,
or following the use or overdose of sedatives. This would be identifiable by a pH of less than 7.35 (acidemia), increased Pcoz and normal HCO3-. This patient’s decreased HCO3” suggests an additional metabolic acid-base
disturbance.

vignette: TBD

32. A 16-year-old girl comes to the office because of a 1-month history of green, sticky discharge from the right nipple. She initially noticed the discharge on her bra and was also able to express it manually. She has not had

breast pain or skin changes. During the past 3 months, she has had a 4.5-kg (10-Ib) weight gain despite no change in appetite. She also has had frequent frontal headaches since beginning oral contraceptive therapy

3 months ago. Six months ago, she was diagnosed with major depressive disorder and was started on fluoxetine therapy. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is

sexually active with one partner and uses condoms inconsistently. On examination, scant greenish discharge can be expressed from the right breast. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of

the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
This patient, who is premenopausal and presenting with unilateral green, sticky nipple discharge, is most likely experiencing mammary ductal ectasia. Mammary ductal ectasia refers to a widening of the lactiferous ducts, often near
the nipple, that is associated with inflammation. These ectatic ducts are often asymptomatic until they become blocked, at which time they may become painful and nodular or cystic. Multicolored or green sticky discharge is
pathognomonic. While nipple discharge is a common occurrence in adult women, it is much less common in adolescents and teenagers. Evaluation should include a complete history and physical examination, focusing on whether
the discharge is unilateral or bilateral, its characteristics, and its provoking factors. The history should include a detailed medication reconciliation, as some medications may be associated with nipple discharge. Physical
examination should evaluate for breast abnormalities, including breast masses or areas of pain or fluctuance. Laboratory studies may include a culture of the discharge to rule out underlying infection. Ultrasonography can be used
to confirm the diagnosis of ductal ectasia. Complications include infection, such as mastitis or breast abscess. Treatment is primarily symptomatic, although surgery can be used to treat patients who do not respond to noninvasive
treatment.
educational_objective:
Mammary ductal ectasia refers to a widening of the lactiferous ducts near the nipple associated with inflammation and a consequent nodular or cystic formation. Ductal ectasia may be asymptomatic or
painful, and unilateral multicolored, sticky nipple discharge is pathognomonic. Diagnosis can be confirmed with ultrasonography. Complications include infection, such as breast abscess. Treatment is primarily symptomatic,
although surgery can be used to treat patients who do not respond to noninvasive treatment.

vignette: TBD
4. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
correct_explanation:
Primary amenorrhea is described as the absence of menarche at age 15 years with appropriate secondary sexual characteristics or at age 13 years without secondary sexual characteristics. Prior to this, amenorrhea is not
considered pathologic. Patients experiencing primary amenorrhea should undergo further evaluation to determine the cause. Common causes of primary amenorrhea include functional hypothalamic amenorrhea, constitutional
delays of puberty, gonadal dysgenesis (eg, Turner syndrome), Millerian agenesis, hyperprolactinemia, gonadotropin-releasing hormone deficiency, polycystic ovary syndrome, and an imperforate hymen. Initial evaluation includes
pelvic ultrasonography to ensure the presence of a uterus, followed by measurements of follicle-stimulating hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, prolactin, and testosterone to further elucidate the underlying pathology. This
patient is 14 years old and has secondary sexual characteristics; thus, she does not meet the definition for primary amenorrhea, and the most appropriate management is reassurance that her amenorrhea is likely a normal variant.
educational_objective:
Primary amenorrhea is described as the absence of menarche at age 15 years with appropriate secondary sexual characteristics or at age 13 years without secondary sexual characteristics. Prior to this,
amenorrhea is not considered pathologic. A female patient who is 14 years old and has secondary sexual characteristics does not meet the definition for primary amenorrhea, and it is appropriate to provide reassurance that her
amenorrhea is likely a normal variant.

vignette:
34. Ahospitalized 57-year-old man is confused, agitated, and combative 2 days after undergoing laparoscopic resection for hepatocellular carcinoma. His medications are omeprazole, propranolol, and hydrocodone. He has
drunk one gallon of Scotch whiskey weekly for 3 years. He has used heroin once daily for 3 years. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg.
Physical examination shows a tremor of the hands. On mental status examination, he is not oriented to person, place, or time and reports seeing cockroaches on the hospital bed. Laboratory studies show:
Platelet count 46,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 15.8 sec (INR=1.4)
Serum
Albumin 2.2 g/dL
Total bilirubin 3.1 mg/dL
AST 66 U/L
ALT 98 U/L
Ammonia 11 g/dL
Urine toxicology screening is negative. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
correct_explanation:
This patient demonstrates confusion after resection of hepatocellular carcinoma, a long-term complication of cirrhosis caused by alcohol use disorder. He also shows signs of chronic liver disease (eg, synthetic liver dysfunction),
including thrombocytopenia and prolonged prothrombin time/INR, consistent with cirrhosis caused by alcohol use disorder. Delirium tremens is a serious complication of alcohol withdrawal. Alcohol use increases the central nervous
system activity of y-aminobutyric acid, the main inhibitory neurotransmitter. Abrupt discontinuation of alcohol therefore leads to sympathetic overdrive. Uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal typically presents with tremors, anxiety,
restlessness, headache, nausea, and diaphoresis, which can occur hours after the cessation of alcohol use. Delirium tremens, the most concerning and life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, involves severe confusion
and disorientation, fluctuations in consciousness, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability (eg, fluctuations in heart rate and blood pressure with hyperthermia, sometimes fever). As in this case, delirium tremens can
begin 2 to 5 days after the patient’s last alcoholic drink. Patients with delirium tremens are at risk of death from associated dysrhythmias or respiratory failure. Delirium tremens is managed supportively with benzodiazepines, such
as lorazepam, to address agitation and prevent the symptoms of withdrawal, as well as fluids, nutritional supplementation, and frequent assessment, including vital sign checks. Other complications of alcohol withdrawal include
alcoholic hallucinosis (eg, auditory or visual hallucinations without confusion or autonomic instability) and seizures.
educational_objective:
Delirium tremens is an alcohol withdrawal syndrome that typically presents 2 to 5 days following the cessation of alcohol use. It typically presents with autonomic instability (eg, tachycardia, tachypnea,
hypertension, hyperthermia), tremors, anxiety, hallucinations, confusion, delirium, ataxia, and may result in convulsions, coma, and death. It is typically treated with benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam.

vignette:
35. A4-month-old female infant is brought to the office by her mother for a well-child examination. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and

vaginal delivery. She is breast-feeding well and gaining weight. She has been smiling and cooing and has begun rolling onto her side. The mother says she na .

noticed an asymmetric appearance to her daughter's face and head 4 weeks ago that has slightly worsened since that time. The patient otherwise has been : I

well. Family history is noncontributory. The infant is 63 cm (25 in; 50th percentile) long and weighs 6200 g (13 Ib 110z; 50th percentile); head circumference is d

40 cm (16 in; 25th percentile). Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an open and flat anterior fontanel and a palpable ridge between

the right parietal and temporal bones. The right eye and eyebrow appear superiorly displaced compared with the left. The remainder of the physical

examination discloses no abnormalities. CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Craniosynostosis refers to the premature ossification that occurs between the plates of the cranial bones leading to deformity of the skull. Most infants with this condition are asymptomatic. Genetic causes may involve
abnormalities in expression of FGF and TGF. The fontanelles are cartilaginous gaps that exist between these bony plates that, along with the cartilaginous sutures, allow for movement, growth, and compression of the cranial
bones particularly during childbirth when the skull passes through the pelvis and vaginal canal. Closure of one or more of these regions prematurely leads to abnormal growth and fusion of the skull. The resulting deformity can
be both cosmetic (abnormal head shape) and pathologic (limiting normal central nervous system growth). Several patterns of deformity can occur depending on which sutures prematurely fuse. In this patient, fusion of the
coronal suture arrests the anterior-posterior growth of the skull. This leads to continued medial-lateral growth in disproportion to anterior-posterior direction. As a result, anterior plagiocephaly or brachycephaly can develop. The
cause of this patient’s elevated right eye compared with the left is most likely due to coronal craniosynostosis.
educational_objective:
Craniosynostosis refers to the premature ossification that occurs between the cartilaginous plates of the cranial bones leading to deformity of the skull. Most infants with this condition are asymptomatic.
Closure of one or more of these regions prematurely leads to abnormal growth and fusion of the skull. The resulting deformity can be both cosmetic (abnormal head shape) and pathologic (limiting normal central nervous system
growth).

vignette:
36. A57-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has felt sad and tearful and has thought about killing herself for the past 2 weeks. Her symptoms began 1 week after losing $25,000 during a weekend of

gambling. She reports that she had boundless energy all week and gambled continuously throughout the weekend without needing to sleep. She says, "I felt great even when | was losing and did not realize what | had

done until a week later." Twice yearly for the past 10 years, she has had similar gambling episodes but has never lost this much money before. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination,

she is distraught and tearful. She says that she has not developed a plan to take her own life but admits to wishing for a "convenient car accident." Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_explanation:
Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder characterized by acute episodes of mania. Acute mania typically manifests with three or more of the following symptoms: euphoric or irritable mood, increased energy, a decreased need for sleep,
increased goal-directed activity, rapid speech and thinking, irresponsibility (as evidenced by this patient’s out-of-character spending), and grandiose thinking. Some patients demonstrate associated psychotic symptoms (eg,
paranoid delusions, hallucinations). A loss of insight, as evidenced by this patient’s lack of awareness of her deleterious actions during the manic episode, is common. This patient most likely has type 1 bipolar disorder which
requires a history of mania to meet diagnostic criteria. Depressive episodes are not required for the diagnosis but are common, particularly after a manic episode, as in this case. Management requires mood stabilizing
pharmacotherapy (eg, mood stabilizers or mood-stabilizing antipsychotics) for acute mania. Once acute mood episodes resolve, patients with bipolar disorder should continue mood-stabilizing maintenance therapy to prevent future
episodes of mania or depression.
educational_objective:
Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder characterized by acute episodes of mania and may include episodes of depression. Acute mania typically manifests with three or more of the following symptoms: euphoric
or irritable mood, increased energy, a decreased need for sleep, increased goal-directed activity, rapid speech and thinking, irresponsibility, and grandiose thinking. Management for acute mania requires mood stabilizing
pharmacotherapy (eg, mood stabilizers or mood-stabilizing antipsychotics).

vignette:
37. Apreviously healthy 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of fever, nonproductive cough, and increasing shortness of breath. She is no longer able to walk up one flight of
stairs without resting. She takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She has been sexually active with multiple partners, and they use condoms inconsistently. She appears
cachectic and in moderate respiratory distress. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 104/68 mm Hg. Examination shows submental and cervical
lymphadenopathy. There is diffuse white exudate over the buccal mucosa. Pulmonary examination shows good air movement; no crackles or rhonchi are heard. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.8 g/dL, and leukocyte count is 3800/mm%. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.48
Pco, 30 mm Hg
Po, 68 mm Hg
An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
correct_explanation:
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly P. carinii) is an opportunistic, yeast-like fungal organism that can cause pneumonia in immunocompromised patients. Chest x-ray typically shows diffuse, bilateral infiltrates often prominently about
the hila, though as seen in this patient’s chest x-ray, it also can show no abnormalities. Methenamine silver or toluidine blue stains selectively stain the cyst walls and are used to confirm the diagnosis. P. jirovecii primarily affects
immunosuppressed patients. This patient likely has undiagnosed HIV/AIDS, as in addition to P. jirovecii pneumonia, the patient has a history of multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. The cervical lymphadenopathy
and white exudate on the buccal mucosa also support this diagnosis and may represent Candida infection. Patients with HIV infection with CD4+ T-lymphocyte counts below 200/mm® are at risk for developing pneumonia from P.
jirovecii. Treatment consists of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, atovaquone, or pentamidine. Patients with low oxygen tension should also receive corticosteroids along with antibiotics to limit inflammation and hypoxia during the
initial treatment phase.
educational_objective:
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly P. carinii) is an opportunistic, yeast-like fungal organism that can cause pneumonia in immunocompromised patients. Chest x-ray typically shows diffuse, bilateral infiltrates.
Treatment consists of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, atovaquone, or pentamidine. ————

vignette:
38. A 24-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of pain with urination and urinary frequency. She has a 1-year history of frequent bladder infections characterized by similar symptoms.

The infections occur after sexual intercourse and resolve with antibiotic therapy. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is currently sexually active with one male partner, and they use

condoms consistently. Examination shows bladder tenderness and urethral elevation; no other abnormalities are noted. Urine culture grows Escherichia coli. Which of the following is most likely to prevent recurrence of

these symptoms?

choices.text: Obtain a swab of the urethra of the patient's partner
Perform cystoscopy to rule out detrusor instability
Perform cystoscopy to rule out anatomic cause
Recommend weetly self-catheterization to determine postvoid residual volume

correct_explanation:
Urinary tract infections (UTIs) classically present in women with dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic discomfort. They are often caused by Escherichia coli and gram-negative enteric flora. If untreated, bacteria can
travel up the ureter to infect the kidney, resulting in pyelonephritis. Urinalysis typically shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites along with WBCs on microscopy. Treatment includes antibiotics covering common pathogens (eg, E. coli),
such as in this patient. Recurrent UTIs can be a result of congenital urinary tract abnormalities. UTIs are more common in women due to the shorter urethra and favorable regional environment for bacterial growth. In addition,
sexual intercourse can introduce bacteria into the urethra, leading to recurrent UTIs. Therefore, antibiotic treatment taken following sexual intercourse can help prevent the development of UTIs in this patient.
educational_objective:
Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are more common in women due to the shorter urethra and favorable regional environment for bacterial growth. Sexual intercourse can introduce bacteria into the urethra,
leading to recurrent UTIs. Patients with frequent, recurrent, persistent UTIs triggered by sexual intercourse may be candidates for postcoital antibiotic prophylaxis.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
39. An asymptomatic 32-year-old man comes to the physician 2 days after his male sexual partner was diagnosed with gonorrhea. He has not had penile discharge or dysuria. Over the past 4 months, he and his partner have

had unprotected sexual intercourse several times weekly. Four months ago, HIV testing of the patient and his partner was negative. Examination shows no abnormalities. A Gram stain of mucus from a urethral swab is

negative for diplococci. A urethral culture is ordered. He gives written consent for HIV antibody testing and serologic testing for syphilis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in therapy?

choices.text: Withhold any treatment until results of the culture are known

correct_explanation:
Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted, gram-negative diplococci and can cause pharyngitis, urethritis, epididymitis, vaginitis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease. It can also cause proctitis in patients who have
receptive anal intercourse, as well as disseminated infection if it persists untreated. In male patients, it most commonly presents as urethritis with mucopurulent discharge, although it may also be asymptomatic. In contrast, when
patients present with disseminated infection, there are often no proceeding symptoms suggesting a sexually transmitted infection. These patients present with fevers, malaise, polyarthritis or oligoarthritis, tenosynovitis, and
vesiculopustular dermatitis. They may also present solely with purulent arthritis of one or more extremity joints (eg, knees, elbows, ankles). Evaluation of these patients with exposure to a sexually transmitted infection or with
symptoms of urethritis includes a Gram stain and culture of a urethral swab. In gonorrhea, organisms may not be visible on a Gram stain because N. gonorrhoeae is an intracellular organism. Cultures or nucleic acid amplification
testing of the urine or urethral swab often yield the diagnosis. Screening for extragenital infections with oral and rectal swabs is also recommended in nonmonogamous men who have sex with men. Testing and treatment for
coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis should also occur. While testing is being completed, patients with a known exposure to a sexually transmitted infection should be treated with appropriate antibiotic therapy. Treatment often
consists of intramuscular ceftriaxone, as well as azithromycin or doxycycline to treat a potential concurrent chlamydia infection.
educational_objective:
Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted infection that can cause pharyngitis, urethritis, epididymitis, and proctitis, although it is also frequently asymptomatic. When left untreated, it can also cause
disseminated disease. Evaluation includes Gram stain and culture of a urethral swab, as well as nucleic acid amplification tests of urine or urethral, oral, and rectal swabs. Patients at high risk for infection, such as those who are
symptomatic or who have a known exposure, should be treated empirically while waiting for test results. Treatment often consists of intramuscular ceftriaxone, as well as azithromycin or doxycycline to treat a potential concurrent
chlamydia infection.

vignette: TBD

3. Her pulse is 48/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Pupils are dilated and nonreactive to light. She
is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is started. After fluid resuscitation, her hemodynamic status is stabilized. ACT scan of the head shows a large intracranial hematoma with a massive midline shift. After consulting
with a neurosurgeon, the most appropriate next step is to contact which of the following?
correct_explanation:
This patient presents with a gunshot wound that may or may not be self-inflicted. In addition to requirements to report abuse or suspected abuse of children or elders, almost every state in the United States has a legal requirement
for reporting nonaccidental or suspected nonaccidental injuries. Such injuries include those sustained from firearms, knives, or other sharp implements. Some states also include provisions for reporting powder burns, inhalational
burns, large burns, or other types of burns that may reasonably be connected to illegal activity. Some states have specific statutes relating to the reporting of injuries that may be the result of domestic violence. Almost all states
mandate that such injuries be reported to the local and/or state police department. Physicians should be aware of laws pertaining to reporting of nonaccidental injuries in their state.
educational_objective:
In addition to requirements to report abuse or suspected abuse of children or elders, almost every state in the United States has a legal requirement for reporting nonaccidental or suspected nonaccidental
injuries. Almost all states mandate that such injuries be reported to the local and/or state police department. Physicians should be aware of laws pertaining to reporting of nonaccidental injuries in their state.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
41. A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of a wound on her right foot that she first noticed 8 weeks ago. During the past 3 days, it has increased in size and depth and has become moderately painful. She does

not recall any injury to her foot. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her medications are insulin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, and daily aspirin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 Ib); BMI is

36 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/95 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3 = 3-cm full-thickness wound over the second and third metatarsal heads

of the plantar aspect of the right foot; there is necrotic tissue and eschar but no exposed tendon or bone. The plantar aspect of the right forefoot is tender to palpation. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses in the right

lower extremity are 1+. Semmes-Weinstein 5.07 monofilament testing shows absent sensation over the right foot. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Arterial Doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremities

correct_explanation:
MRI of the foot is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis of this patient. The patient has poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and is presenting with fever, worsening foot pain, and ulceration overlying the second and third
metatarsal heads on the plantar aspect of the foot. Because of this, a thorough workup into any underlying infections should be pursued, particularly MRI. A combination of factors leads to increased risk for foot infections in diabetic
patients. These include immune compromise inherent to diabetes, decreased sensation in the feet allowing deep wounds to go undetected by patients, decreased motor function leading to altered pressure points and swelling of the
lower extremities, and decreased autonomic nervous system function leading to impaired sweat regulation and increased risk for dryness, cracking, and fissuring on the feet causing portals for bacterial entry. When a diabetic foot
ulcer is present, x-rays of the foot will help to evaluate for the presence of osteomyelitis, abscess, and gas in the soft tissue, either of which could require surgical management and will dictate the treatment plan for this patient.
Surgical management is generally the definitive treatment, though antibiotics should be initiated immediately. Conservative measures can be pursued first if medically appropriate for the patient.
educational_objective:
Diabetic patients are at an increased risk for soft-tissue infections on the feet because of decreased immune status and neuropathy of sensory, motor, and autonomic nerves. Deep ulcers that have exposed
bone or probe to bone may be complicated by abscess, osteomyelitis, or gas gangrene. MRI is the best modality for evaluating diabetic foot abscess.

vignette:
42. A27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of increasing pain and progressive swelling and stiffness of her ankles. Despite nightly application of ice to her ankles, ibuprofen therapy, and

decreased activity during the past 3 months, her pain has worsened, she has had swelling of her ankles throughout the day, and she has had morning stiffness of her ankles. She has sustained no recent trauma to her

ankles. She had a severe right ankle sprain in college. Her only other medication is an oral contraceptive. She is an avid tennis player and plays twice weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows

swelling and moderate effusion of both ankles. Range of motion of both ankles is full but produces mild pain. X-rays of the ankles are shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
correct_explanation:
Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease that causes extensive inflammation in synovial tissues. The clinical course is characterized by joint destruction, periarticular bone loss, and synovial hypertrophy, along with extra-
articular manifestations such as rheumatoid nodules, pulmonary fibrosis, and skin rash. Patients often present with symmetric involvement of multiple joints, most commonly the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal
joints of the hands, with x-rays showing articular erosions and progressive joint space narrowing. Ulnar deviation of the fingers along with boutonniere and swan neck deformities commonly occur. This patient is presenting with
bilateral ankle pain and swelling without signs of osteoarthritis or degenerative changes on x-ray. Testing includes serum rheumatoid factor, a sensitive test for rheumatoid arthritis, and anticyclic citrullinated peptide antibody test, a
specific test for rheumatoid arthritis. Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis involves the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen, and disease modifying antirheumatic drugs such as methotrexate. For this patient,
rheumatoid arthritis is the most likely diagnosis because of the bilateral joint involvement, lack of trauma, and the presence of morning stiffness and moderate ankle effusion.
educational_objective:
Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease that causes inflammation in synovial tissues. Presentation includes bilateral joint involvement with synovial hypertrophy and can include extra-articular
manifestations such as rheumatoid nodules, pulmonary fibrosis, and skin rash. Serology testing includes rheumatoid factor, which is sensitive for rheumatoid arthritis, and anticyclic citrullinated peptide antibody testing, which is
specific for rheumatoid arthritis. Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis involves the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen, and disease modifying antirheumatic drugs such as methotrexate.

vignette:
43. Apreviously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and easy bruising. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is
100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows ecchymoses over the lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 53,000/mm?
Lymphocytes 10%
_ Myeloblasts 90%
Platelet count 63,000/mm?
Serum
Creatinine 1.9 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase 2233 U/L
A bone marrow biopsy specimen confirms acute myelogenous leukemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells

correct_explanation:
Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) is a neoplasm arising from cells within the myeloid lineage that presents with pancytopenia and myeloblasts on peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy. Common presenting symptoms
include fatigue, easy bruising and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia, malaise, fevers, and weight loss. Treatment is generally with cytarabine and daunorubicin and is sometimes followed by consolidation therapy and stem cell
transplantation, though regimens vary depending on tumor characteristics. Treatment of AML or baseline cell turnover can lead to tumor lysis syndrome due to the destruction of tumor cells, resulting in release of their contents,
manifesting as hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia, and hyperuricemia. Hydration and urine alkalization can help prevent resulting kidney injury. Alkalinization increases the urine pH, making uric acid more soluble and
readily excreted. It also prevents precipitation of uric acid in renal tubules, which would lead to kidney injury. Intravenous fluid hydration also helps to improve urine output and prevent further kidney injury.
educational_objective:
The abrupt destruction of many tumor cells results in interstitial and serum release of their contents, manifesting as hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia, and hyperuricemia, the latter of which
results in acute kidney injury. Hydration and urinary alkalinization can help prevent the precipitation of uric acid and acute kidney injury.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
Y

vignette:
44. A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of bruising without any trauma. He has not had bleeding from his nose or mouth. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital

signs are within normal limits. Examination shows ecchymoses in various stages of healing over the upper extremities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference range. His prothrombin time is 20 seconds

(INR=2), and partial thromboplastin time is 25 seconds. This patient most likely has a deficiency of which of the following?
correct_explanation:
Factor VII deficiency is a rare bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency in the blood clotting factor VII. This factor is produced in the liver and is essential for the formation of a blood clot. The deficiency of factor VII is usually
inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Symptoms of factor VII deficiency can range from mild to severe and can include bruising, nosebleeds, and bleeding after injury or surgery. Since factor VII is a part of the extrinsic
pathway of coagulation, it is expected that a patient would have normal partial thromboplastin time, normal bleeding time, and increased prothrombin time. Treatment for factor VII deficiency depends on the severity of the bleeding
symptoms. Mild cases may not require treatment, while more severe cases may require replacement therapy with factor VII concentrate or fresh frozen plasma. Complications of factor VII deficiency can include joint damage from
recurrent bleeding, and in severe cases, life-threatening bleeding episodes.
educational_objective:
Factor VII deficiency is a rare bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency in the blood clotting factor VII. This is generally inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Patients with factor VII deficiency generally
present with a range of mild to severe bleeding. Characteristically, patients will have laboratory studies showing increased prothrombin time with normal partial thromboplastin time and bleeding time.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
45. A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of ringing in her ears. The sound gradually intensified during the first year and has been unchanged since that time. The ringing is more noticeable

when she is in a quiet environment but otherwise does not fluctuate throughout the day. She reports that her hearing is otherwise normal. She has hypertension treated with lisinopril. She has smoked one pack of

cigarettes daily for 25 years and drinks one glass of wine daily. Her blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg; other vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the external auditory canals shows no abnormalities.

Finger-rub testing shows no abnormalities. Audiometry shows mild high-frequency hearing loss bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: MRI of the brain and internal auditory canals

correct_explanation:
Tinnitus refers to internally generated sounds. The most common cause of tinnitus is sensorineural hearing loss ordinarily resulting from noise trauma. The internally generated sound frequently mimics the frequency of the hearing
loss. Other common causes of tinnitus include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, atherosclerotic disease, and obesity. Rarer causes of tinnitus include Meniere disease and vestibulocochlear cranial nerve lesions (eg, acoustic
neuroma). For some patients, tinnitus is idiopathic. Most but not all patients with tinnitus have hearing loss. The pathophysiology of tinnitus is unclear. Depression, anxiety, and insomnia can worsen tinnitus. Diagnostic workup may
include audiometry to evaluate for hearing loss. Neuroimaging is only done if there is asymmetry in sound perception across the two ears. Angiography is only done if tinnitus is pulsatile, which suggests a vascular cause. No further
testing is indicated for this patient. Management includes stress reduction, cognitive therapy, and masking with external sounds to distract from the internal sound.
educational_objective:
Tinnitus, or internally generalized sound, is most commonly related to sensorineural hearing loss but may also be idiopathic. Audiometry is commonly used in patients with tinnitus to assess for associated
hearing loss. In patients with symmetric and non-pulsatile tinnitus, no further testing is indicated. Management includes stress reduction, cognitive therapy, and masking with external sounds to distract from the internal sound.

Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette:
46. An 18-year-old basketball player is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after collapsing during a game. He was successfully resuscitated at the scene. On arrival, he is awake and alert. His temperature is

37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiography shows

systolic anterior motion of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve causing a subaortic obstruction. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Placement of a permanent ventricular pacemaker
Surgical excision of the endocardium of the left ventricular free wall

correct_explanation:
This young, otherwise healthy patient with collapse during exercise and ECG showing left ventricular hypertrophy likely has hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. This condition, which is suspected to have autosomal dominant
inheritance, results in hypertrophy of myocytes leading to a focal obstruction in the left ventricular outflow tract. It classically presents with syncope or sudden cardiac death in an otherwise healthy, young athlete. Due to the
narrowed left ventricular outflow tract, any hemodynamic influence that prevents the stenting open of the tract (eg, low preload leading to low stroke volume caused by Valsalva maneuver, standing, or hypovolemia) will result in an
exacerbation of the murmur because of increased turbulent blood flow. Significant derangements in hemodynamics can cause complete obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract, commonly causing obstruction by abnormal
motion of the mitral valve. Resultant reduction in cardiac output leads to syncope. Arrhythmogenic foci are also a common cause of mortality. Medications that increase diastolic filling by reducing the pulse, such as B-adrenergic
blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers, are the mainstay of treatment.
educational_objective:
In hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, outflow tract obstruction and/or arrhythmia can cause exertional syncope. Maneuvers that decrease preload or decrease afterload accentuate the murmur due to
increased incursion of the interventricular septum into the left ventricular outflow tract. It classically presents with dyspnea, syncope, or sudden cardiac death in an exercising young athlete with a potential family history of a similar
event. Medications that increase diastolic filling by reducing the pulse, such as B-adrenergic blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers, are the mainstay of treatment.

following is the most appropriate
